subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Advisors,

The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the thread below.

Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning, successful open source project.?

This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.

Cheers,
Chris.


From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com] 
Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
To: Luke, Chris
Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org; tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte

The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project lifecycle document here:
https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be interesting and much appreciated.

Cheers,
--Colin

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 11:22 PM, Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:

I skimmed the thread and definitely think the AG can provide some guidance.?

Could I ask for a succinct statement of the query and its background? To make sure we answer the right question :)

I'll save my own detailed?comments for later, save that as Neela suggests the word 'mature' has much implied meaning for end users?around fitness for purpose derived in no small part?from having mileage under its belt (preferably miles that were honest about their?emissions too).?

Cheers,
Chris

From: Neela Jacques
Sent: 9/24/15, 6:36 PM
To: Colin Dixon
Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org, tsc at lists.opendaylight.org, Todd Benzies, Philip Robb, Luke, Chris
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte
TSC members, developers.? 

Can I suggest that you ask our Advisory Group members what they would expect as users from a Mature project? This is exactly the type of question we shouldn't be guessing as to what end users want and expect but getting real input and data. Mature is inherently a label who's primary use is to convey a certain level of expectations for an end-users. We should make sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does. Unfortunately for him it doesn't so much matter whether he meets his own definition of mature but whether he meets ours). Phil and Todd can facilitate formulating the questions, and/or creating a forum for discussion.? 

-Neela


Nicolas (Neela) Jacques | Executive Director | OpenDaylight Project |?650-704-7029

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com> wrote:
Comments inline... 

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that
> he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of Releases
> (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.

That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding
something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.

Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the

History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues

chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
section" during Graduation Reviews.

Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release Reviews
and look at their Security Issues sections.? That's just taking a look at the supporting collateral
backing the claim for having followed the Mature Release process.
?

Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...

Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right
wikis at the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that
says all the most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever)
can be "Mature", as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing
a step that would block such projects from reaching "Mature"?

Yeah, that is an interesting question.? Part of the intention as I remember it originally
was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its requirements are
mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it be stuff that would be?
pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example: Working code base.? Definitely
tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for without having a code base in front of you,
but not all that hard to determine about a code base you are looking at).

Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not* the Simultaneous Release
process... its most definitely simpler.? For example, the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole?
heartedly endorse) layer on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks know what you thought you thought you were
doing so there was some hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually delivered
so there's some clarity there".? Stuff happens, and if you chain people to their Release Plans,
they will be both timid in them, and also incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into
them things that other folks need that are less central to what they care about.? So I would be very reluctant to consider 'late' or
'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan, because I suspect they'd incent very damaging
compensating behaviors.? If someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project
thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly incent turning them away
(the opposite of what we want).? And if I depend on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm going to be dinged for it.? It tends to
discourage, rather than encourage collaboration and striving.

In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here, is part of why *actually* changing
the governance (with the attendant thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me, feels
like very broad creep by interpretation.? The project lifecycle change process forces rather a lot more deliberation.

I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to rework the project lifecycle".? I'm going to have
my own principles around that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not political,
and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those personal biases (much as I may be fond of them,
and wish others would adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding on such a discussion.

Ed

?

Daniel Farrell
Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
https://twitter.com/dfarrell07

----- Original Message -----
> Dan,
>
> From my point of view, roughly yes.? Part of the question though is how far
> a stretch it is.
> If the TSC were holding a Release Review for a project, opinions about the
> contents of its 'Security Issues' section that
> are germane to the handling of 'Security Issues' seems perfectly in scope.
> My opinion is that adding a 'Security Issues' section to
> the Graduation Review outside of the process of actually adding that
> section, or sticking such a section under another section
> should properly involve revising the Project Lifecycle to do so.
>
> I would also argue for the heuristic: "Would a reasonable engineer
> obviously see something as part of the stated section a priori"
> is a good litmus test.? I would maintain that a reasonable engineer, when
> preparing their Security Issue's section for a Release Review
> would reasonably think to include information about what security issues
> have been raised and how they were handled.? For the TSC to provide a bit
> more clarity around that for Release Reviews seems completely reasonable.
>
> I would maintain that a reasonable engineer looking at a Graduation Review,
> seeing a 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' who
> has gone through several Releases, dutifully producing Release Plans and
> Release Reviews that had the recommended sections that had not been
> objected to, would reasonable think that pointing to
> them covers that.? I would not expect a reasonable engineer to
> spontaneously think that he should add information to the Graduation Review
> 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security
> Issues'.? In essence, asking him to do so would be surprising relative to
> the actual Project Lifecycle as written.
>
> Ed

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Dear Chris and All,

There is a large difference, in my mind, between stable and mature.

It is correct that to be effective, a given release needs to be mature.

The usual definition of a mature release is that it is fully functional and
well-documented, that in runs fault-free on a sufficient, verified set 
of hardware and
OS platforms, and that a body of users (not just committers) verifies
that it can be used without substantial issues on the afore-mentioned
platforms, for an identified set of benchmark functions and use cases.

At present, we have heard several opinions that the documentation
is not in the required state, and whether the code release works on a
given switch/router in a given configuration or not, is to be determined
by trial and error.

Best regards
Harvey


On 9/28/2015 10:28 AM, Luke, Chris wrote:
> Advisors,
>
> The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the thread below.
>
> Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning, successful open source project.?
>
> This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.
>
> Cheers,
> Chris.
>
>
> From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
> To: Luke, Chris
> Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org; tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte
>
> The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project lifecycle document here:
> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
> This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be interesting and much appreciated.
>
> Cheers,
> --Colin
>
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 11:22 PM, Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:
>
> I skimmed the thread and definitely think the AG can provide some guidance.
>
> Could I ask for a succinct statement of the query and its background? To make sure we answer the right question :)
>
> I'll save my own detailed comments for later, save that as Neela suggests the word 'mature' has much implied meaning for end users around fitness for purpose derived in no small part from having mileage under its belt (preferably miles that were honest about their emissions too).
>
> Cheers,
> Chris
>
> From: Neela Jacques
> Sent: 9/24/15, 6:36 PM
> To: Colin Dixon
> Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org, tsc at lists.opendaylight.org, Todd Benzies, Philip Robb, Luke, Chris
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte
> TSC members, developers.
>
> Can I suggest that you ask our Advisory Group members what they would expect as users from a Mature project? This is exactly the type of question we shouldn't be guessing as to what end users want and expect but getting real input and data. Mature is inherently a label who's primary use is to convey a certain level of expectations for an end-users. We should make sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does. Unfortunately for him it doesn't so much matter whether he meets his own definition of mature but whether he meets ours). Phil and Todd can facilitate formulating the questions, and/or creating a forum for discussion.
>
> -Neela
>
>
> Nicolas (Neela) Jacques | Executive Director | OpenDaylight Project | 650-704-7029
>
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com> wrote:
> Comments inline...
>
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
>> I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that
>> he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of Releases
>> (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.
> That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding
> something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.
>
> Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the
>
> History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues
>
> chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
> section" during Graduation Reviews.
>
> Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release Reviews
> and look at their Security Issues sections.  That's just taking a look at the supporting collateral
> backing the claim for having followed the Mature Release process.
>   
>
> Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...
>
> Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right
> wikis at the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that
> says all the most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever)
> can be "Mature", as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing
> a step that would block such projects from reaching "Mature"?
>
> Yeah, that is an interesting question.  Part of the intention as I remember it originally
> was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its requirements are
> mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it be stuff that would be
> pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example: Working code base.  Definitely
> tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for without having a code base in front of you,
> but not all that hard to determine about a code base you are looking at).
>
> Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not* the Simultaneous Release
> process... its most definitely simpler.  For example, the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole
> heartedly endorse) layer on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
> As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks know what you thought you thought you were
> doing so there was some hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually delivered
> so there's some clarity there".  Stuff happens, and if you chain people to their Release Plans,
> they will be both timid in them, and also incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into
> them things that other folks need that are less central to what they care about.  So I would be very reluctant to consider 'late' or
> 'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan, because I suspect they'd incent very damaging
> compensating behaviors.  If someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project
> thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly incent turning them away
> (the opposite of what we want).  And if I depend on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
> I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm going to be dinged for it.  It tends to
> discourage, rather than encourage collaboration and striving.
>
> In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here, is part of why *actually* changing
> the governance (with the attendant thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me, feels
> like very broad creep by interpretation.  The project lifecycle change process forces rather a lot more deliberation.
>
> I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to rework the project lifecycle".  I'm going to have
> my own principles around that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not political,
> and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those personal biases (much as I may be fond of them,
> and wish others would adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding on such a discussion.
>
> Ed
>
>   
>
> Daniel Farrell
> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
> https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
>
> ----- Original Message -----
>> Dan,
>>
>>  From my point of view, roughly yes.  Part of the question though is how far
>> a stretch it is.
>> If the TSC were holding a Release Review for a project, opinions about the
>> contents of its 'Security Issues' section that
>> are germane to the handling of 'Security Issues' seems perfectly in scope.
>> My opinion is that adding a 'Security Issues' section to
>> the Graduation Review outside of the process of actually adding that
>> section, or sticking such a section under another section
>> should properly involve revising the Project Lifecycle to do so.
>>
>> I would also argue for the heuristic: "Would a reasonable engineer
>> obviously see something as part of the stated section a priori"
>> is a good litmus test.  I would maintain that a reasonable engineer, when
>> preparing their Security Issue's section for a Release Review
>> would reasonably think to include information about what security issues
>> have been raised and how they were handled.  For the TSC to provide a bit
>> more clarity around that for Release Reviews seems completely reasonable.
>>
>> I would maintain that a reasonable engineer looking at a Graduation Review,
>> seeing a 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' who
>> has gone through several Releases, dutifully producing Release Plans and
>> Release Reviews that had the recommended sections that had not been
>> objected to, would reasonable think that pointing to
>> them covers that.  I would not expect a reasonable engineer to
>> spontaneously think that he should add information to the Graduation Review
>> 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security
>> Issues'.  In essence, asking him to do so would be surprising relative to
>> the actual Project Lifecycle as written.
>>
>> Ed
>>
>> dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
>>
>>> Trying to summarize to help others bootstrap this large thread.
>>>

>>>
>>> Working code base
>>> Active Community
>>> History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)
>>>
>>> And that the third (Mature Release Process) expands into having a:
>>>
>>> Release Plan
>>> Release Review
>>>
>>> Where each expands a "rough" set of recommended of sections.
>>>
>>> I think the implication is that if a project has the appropriate wikis
>>> with the appropriate sections and they were delivered at the appropriate
>>> times, then it's out of scope to make any claim about the content of
>>> those sections.
>>>
>>> The root issue seems to be if that's true, or if the TSC can, while
>>> reviewing
>>> that content as part of a Graduation Review, have expectations for the
>>> content of those sections. For example, would a project doing a horrible
>>> job
>>> security-wise would be in-scope for consideration during the Graduation
>>> Review?
>>>
>>> Do I have this summery reasonably correct?
>>>
>>> Daniel Farrell
>>> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
>>> https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
>>>
>>> ----- Original Message -----
>>>> At the end of the day, a developer who is seeking to do the right thing
>>>> should be able to look at the Project Lifecycle and Mature Release
>>> process,
>>>> and minimally be able to

>>>>

>>>> Graduation Review, I need working code, an active community, and to
>>> follow

>>>>

>>> Plan

>>>> sections.

>>>> doing my Release.
>>>>
>>>> What I cannot do is look forward in time to the addition after the fact
>>> of
>>>> new requirements, based on the intent of motivating preambles and other
>>>> things.
>>>>
>>>> The Project Lifecycle, complete with descriptions of the Graduation
>>> Review
>>>> is here:
>>>> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#ProjectTypes
>>>>
>>>> The Mature Release Process is here:
>>>>
>>> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#MatureReleaseProcess
>>>> I'd strongly encourage folks to read them in their entirety to understand
>>>> the relationship between the requirements therein, and other motiviation
>>> or
>>>> aspirational
>>>> statements proximate to those requirements.
>>>>
>>>> Further comments inline.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> colin at colindixon.com>
>>> wrote:
>>>>> Inline.
>>>>>
>>>>> hagbard at gmail.com>
>>>>> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>> Comments inline..
>>>>>> colin at colindixon.com>
>>>>>> wrote:
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> I'm just going to focus very concretely on what you feel should or
>>>>>>> shouldn't go into the graduation review because I'm having trouble
>>>>>>> separating it from the rest of the content here.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> 1.) I can't tell concretely what you're saying you feel is OK or not
>>>>>>> w.r.t security here. Are you saying you agree that asking for
>>> projects to
>>>>>>> not have known vulnerabilities of certain importance to be mature is
>>>>>>> reasonable or unreasonable.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>> Clearly we can require that information in the Release Reviews
>>>>>> prospectively, 'Security Issues' is in that scope there.  I do not see
>>>>>> anything we can do in graduation reviews other than referencing
>>> Release
>>>>>> Reviews (and Release Plans) per the expectations
>>>>>> present at the time we performed those Release Reviews.
>>>>>>
>>>>> So, in your mind, you see that as being unreasonable?
>>>>>
>>>> Speaking just of my opinion and reading, I would find it entirely
>>>> reasonable to require beefing up the Security Issue section of a Release
>>>> Review as you have described, as that is where that section lives.
>>>> I do not see that as providing license to insert things into the
>>> Graduation
>>>> Review Template.
>>>>
>>>> In particular, the only requirement I see in the Mature Release process
>>> is:
>>>> "... should have a Release Plan published at the beginning of it's
>>> release
>>>> cycle by its committers, and a Release Review just prior to the project
>>>> release." and then goes on to say what sections those should have.
>>>>
>>>> That's the extent of the stated requirements for a project that I see for
>>>> following the Mature Release process.  I can clearly see desiring to add
>>>> other requirements to the Mature Release process, or other items
>>>> to the Release Plan or Release Review to be considered to have followed
>>>> that process.  But those are *changes* to the Mature Release process.
>>>>
>>>> The Graduation Review requires having a history of following the Mature
>>>> Release Process.  The Mature Release process requires two things, a
>>> Release
>>>> Plan and a Release Review, and defines the sections in them.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> 2.) I feel like our mature release process clearly says that
>>>>>>> coordination between projects is a critical part. Asking people to
>>> state
>>>>>>> how they did or didn't meet agreed-upon cross-project deliverables
>>> seems
>>>>>>> within scope.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>> Could you point me to that in the Mature Release process?  I am not
>>>>>> seeing there something that maps in my mind to this, though I do
>>> sometimes
>>>>>> miss things.
>>>>>>
>>>>> I did several mails ago, but again, the first two sentences of the
>>> mature
>>>>> release process as defined in the lifecycle are: "The basic idea
>>> behind the
>>>>> mature release process is to define the most straight forward way to
>>> insure
>>>>> that projects can coordinate with each other. The idea is to have
>>> simple,
>>>>> clear, public declarations of what they are going to do and when, and
>>> that
>>>>> they've done it."
>>>>>
>>>> Which, in context, is a lovely statement for the motivation for *why* the
>>>> Release Plans and Release Reviews are required following it, and why they
>>>> have the sections they do.
>>>> But its a pure preamble to a set of requirements for two very specific
>>>> documents (Release Plan and Release Review) that are the actual
>>>> requirements of the Mature Release process.
>>>> If we are going to choose to interpret that "To encourage x we are going
>>> to
>>>> require y and z" implies that we can, via interpretation, and without
>>>> altering our governance insert any and all additional requirements that
>>> may
>>>> also
>>>> serve x... I'm not sure what meaning is left in the governance.
>>>>
>>>> In particular, I can come up with plausible justifications for a wide
>>> array
>>>> of additional requirement (both wise and unwise) as being motivated by
>>> that
>>>> preamble sentence.  Allowing the motivation for a declared requirements
>>> to
>>>> justify
>>>> the addition of new requirements purely by interpretation allows
>>>> interpretation with very few bounds.
>>>>
>>>> Its also worth noting that our broader governance requires the TSC to
>>>> recommend changes in the project lifecycle to the board.  One possible
>>> way
>>>> of looking at that requirement is that it causes a very deliberate and
>>>> broad debate
>>>> about the wisdom of adding new requirements.  Very few things in our
>>>> governance require both the TSC and the board to both act (though often
>>> the
>>>> board *does* seek the TSCs input when not required), changing the project
>>>> lifecycle is one of them.  I am personally very leery of sidestepping
>>> that,
>>>> particularly with justifications that can largely sidestep that process.
>>>>
>>>> Ed
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>> 3.) It seems like some of your issues are asking for people to meet
>>>>>>> certain bars vs. merely read out where they fell on some axis, e.g.,
>>>>>>> fixing
>>>>>>> security vulnerabilities and where deliverables fell in reality vs.
>>> the
>>>>>>> defined milestones. My personal opinion is that we don't at least
>>> call
>>>>>>> out
>>>>>>> the bar we'd like people to meet, it will be difficult for the TSC to
>>>>>>> have
>>>>>>> a consistent standard for what's required and projects will have a
>>> harder
>>>>>>> time providing the TSC with the information they're looking for.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> I have three positions:
>>>>>> 1)  I feel *many* of the suggestions being offered are not
>>> supportable by
>>>>>> the current project lifecycle and mature release process, and thus
>>> would
>>>>>> require their revision.
>>>>>> 2)  I feel that *some* of the suggestions really need to be debated
>>> more
>>>>>> deeply, as IMHO they will, on net, incent very poor behavior in the
>>>>>> community.  Fortunately, those suggestions
>>>>>> also fall, IMHO, under #1, which provides the necessary scope to
>>> debate
>>>>>> them as part of considering an overall change in the project
>>> lifecycle.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Chris,

"mature" project is a good topic for sure. It'd be really helpful to have someone who knows the current definition/flow well enough to give us some dump first and with  some Q&A time.  

Regards,

Alex

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:28 AM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

Advisors,

The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the thread below.

Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning, successful open source project.?

This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.

Cheers,
Chris.


From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
To: Luke, Chris
Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org; tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte

The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project lifecycle document here:
https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be interesting and much appreciated.

Cheers,
--Colin

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 11:22 PM, Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:

I skimmed the thread and definitely think the AG can provide some guidance. 

Could I ask for a succinct statement of the query and its background? To make sure we answer the right question :)

I'll save my own detailed comments for later, save that as Neela suggests the word 'mature' has much implied meaning for end users around fitness for purpose derived in no small part from having mileage under its belt (preferably miles that were honest about their emissions too). 

Cheers,
Chris

From: Neela Jacques
Sent: 9/24/15, 6:36 PM
To: Colin Dixon
Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org, tsc at lists.opendaylight.org, Todd Benzies, Philip Robb, Luke, Chris
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte TSC members, developers.  

Can I suggest that you ask our Advisory Group members what they would expect as users from a Mature project? This is exactly the type of question we shouldn't be guessing as to what end users want and expect but getting real input and data. Mature is inherently a label who's primary use is to convey a certain level of expectations for an end-users. We should make sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does. Unfortunately for him it doesn't so much matter whether he meets his own definition of mature but whether he meets ours). Phil and Todd can facilitate formulating the questions, and/or creating a forum for discussion.  

-Neela


Nicolas (Neela) Jacques | Executive Director | OpenDaylight Project | 650-704-7029

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com> wrote:
Comments inline... 

On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that 
> he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of 
> Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.

That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.

Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the

History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues

chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
section" during Graduation Reviews.

Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release Reviews and look at their Security Issues sections.  That's just taking a look at the supporting collateral backing the claim for having followed the Mature Release process.
 

Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...

Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right wikis at the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that says all the most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever) can be "Mature", as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing a step that would block such projects from reaching "Mature"?

Yeah, that is an interesting question.  Part of the intention as I remember it originally was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its requirements are mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it be stuff that would be pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example: Working code base.  Definitely tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for without having a code base in front of you, but not all that hard to determine about a code base you are looking at).

Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not* the Simultaneous Release process... its most definitely simpler.  For example, the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole heartedly endorse) layer on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks know what you thought you thought you were doing so there was some hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually delivered so there's some clarity there".  Stuff happens, and if you chain people to their Release Plans, they will be both timid in them, and also incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into them things that other folks need that are less central to what they care about.  So I would be very reluctant to consider 'late' or 'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan, because I suspect they'd incent very damaging compensating behaviors.  If someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly incent turning them away (the opposite of what we want).  And if I depend on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm going to be dinged for it.  It tends to discourage, rather than encourage collaboration and striving.

In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here, is part of why *actually* changing the governance (with the attendant thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me, feels like very broad creep by interpretation.  The project lifecycle change process forces rather a lot more deliberation.

I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to rework the project lifecycle".  I'm going to have my own principles around that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not political, and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those personal biases (much as I may be fond of them, and wish others would adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding on such a discussion.

Ed

 

Daniel Farrell
Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
https://twitter.com/dfarrell07

----- Original Message -----
> Dan,
>
> From my point of view, roughly yes.  Part of the question though is 
> how far a stretch it is.
> If the TSC were holding a Release Review for a project, opinions about 
> the contents of its 'Security Issues' section that are germane to the 
> handling of 'Security Issues' seems perfectly in scope.
> My opinion is that adding a 'Security Issues' section to the 
> Graduation Review outside of the process of actually adding that 
> section, or sticking such a section under another section should 
> properly involve revising the Project Lifecycle to do so.
>
> I would also argue for the heuristic: "Would a reasonable engineer 
> obviously see something as part of the stated section a priori"
> is a good litmus test.  I would maintain that a reasonable engineer, 
> when preparing their Security Issue's section for a Release Review 
> would reasonably think to include information about what security 
> issues have been raised and how they were handled.  For the TSC to 
> provide a bit more clarity around that for Release Reviews seems completely reasonable.
>
> I would maintain that a reasonable engineer looking at a Graduation 
> Review, seeing a 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' 
> who has gone through several Releases, dutifully producing Release 
> Plans and Release Reviews that had the recommended sections that had 
> not been objected to, would reasonable think that pointing to them

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
I'm sure Phil (who I think is on this list) can give us that detail; though just pulling that email thread up gives you a lot of background. 

Chris.

(the thread starts here: https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-September/003783.html )

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Alex_Zhang [mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com]
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 15:25
> To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; advisory-
> group at lists.opendaylight.org
> Subject: RE: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
> 
> Chris,
> 
> "mature" project is a good topic for sure. It'd be really helpful to have
> someone who knows the current definition/flow well enough to give us
> some dump first and with  some Q&A time.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Alex
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-
> group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:28 AM
> To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> Subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
> 
> Advisors,
> 
> The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation
> review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the
> thread below.
> 
> Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined
> (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the
> word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning,
> successful open source project.?
> 
> This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the
> end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.
> 
> Cheers,
> Chris.
> 
> 
> From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
> To: Luke, Chris
> Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org;
> tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at
> Graduation Review Tempalte
> 
> The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement
> about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we
> start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that
> graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project
> lifecycle document here:
> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
> This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that
> question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope
> for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we
> might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any
> input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be
> interesting and much appreciated.
> 
> Cheers,
> --Colin
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 11:22 PM, Luke, Chris
> <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:
> 
> I skimmed the thread and definitely think the AG can provide some
> guidance.
> 
> Could I ask for a succinct statement of the query and its background? To
> make sure we answer the right question :)
> 
> I'll save my own detailed comments for later, save that as Neela suggests the
> word 'mature' has much implied meaning for end users around fitness for
> purpose derived in no small part from having mileage under its belt
> (preferably miles that were honest about their emissions too).
> 
> Cheers,
> Chris
> 
> From: Neela Jacques
> Sent: 9/24/15, 6:36 PM
> To: Colin Dixon
> Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org, tsc at lists.opendaylight.org, Todd Benzies,
> Philip Robb, Luke, Chris
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at
> Graduation Review Tempalte TSC members, developers.
> 
> Can I suggest that you ask our Advisory Group members what they would
> expect as users from a Mature project? This is exactly the type of question
> we shouldn't be guessing as to what end users want and expect but getting
> real input and data. Mature is inherently a label who's primary use is to
> convey a certain level of expectations for an end-users. We should make
> sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether
> they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume
> such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of
> maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does.
> Unfortunately for him it doesn't so much matter whether he meets his own
> definition of mature but whether he meets ours). Phil and Todd can facilitate
> formulating the questions, and/or creating a forum for discussion.
> 
> -Neela
> 
> 
> Nicolas (Neela) Jacques | Executive Director | OpenDaylight Project | 650-
> 704-7029
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com>
> wrote:
> Comments inline...
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> > I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that
> > he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of
> > Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.
> 
> That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding
> something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.
> 
> Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the
> 
> History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues
> 
> chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
> section" during Graduation Reviews.
> 
> Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release
> Reviews and look at their Security Issues sections.  That's just taking a look at
> the supporting collateral backing the claim for having followed the Mature
> Release process.
> 
> 
> Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...
> 
> Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right wikis at
> the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that says all the
> most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever) can be "Mature",
> as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing a step that would block
> such projects from reaching "Mature"?
> 
> Yeah, that is an interesting question.  Part of the intention as I remember it
> originally was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its
> requirements are mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it
> be stuff that would be pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example:
> Working code base.  Definitely tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for
> without having a code base in front of you, but not all that hard to determine
> about a code base you are looking at).
> 
> Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not*
> the Simultaneous Release process... its most definitely simpler.  For example,
> the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole heartedly endorse) layer
> on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
> As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks
> know what you thought you thought you were doing so there was some
> hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually
> delivered so there's some clarity there".  Stuff happens, and if you chain
> people to their Release Plans, they will be both timid in them, and also
> incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into them things that other folks
> need that are less central to what they care about.  So I would be very
> reluctant to consider 'late' or 'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan,
> because I suspect they'd incent very damaging compensating behaviors.  If
> someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project
> thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly
> incent turning them away (the opposite of what we want).  And if I depend
> on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
> I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm
> going to be dinged for it.  It tends to discourage, rather than encourage
> collaboration and striving.
> 
> In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here,
> is part of why *actually* changing the governance (with the attendant
> thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me,
> feels like very broad creep by interpretation.  The project lifecycle change
> process forces rather a lot more deliberation.
> 
> I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to
> rework the project lifecycle".  I'm going to have my own principles around
> that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not
> political, and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those
> personal biases (much as I may be fond of them, and wish others would
> adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding
> on such a discussion.
> 
> Ed
> 
> 
> 
> Daniel Farrell
> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
> https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> > Dan,
> >
> > From my point of view, roughly yes.  Part of the question though is
> > how far a stretch it is.
> > If the TSC were holding a Release Review for a project, opinions about
> > the contents of its 'Security Issues' section that are germane to the
> > handling of 'Security Issues' seems perfectly in scope.
> > My opinion is that adding a 'Security Issues' section to the
> > Graduation Review outside of the process of actually adding that
> > section, or sticking such a section under another section should
> > properly involve revising the Project Lifecycle to do so.
> >
> > I would also argue for the heuristic: "Would a reasonable engineer
> > obviously see something as part of the stated section a priori"
> > is a good litmus test.  I would maintain that a reasonable engineer,
> > when preparing their Security Issue's section for a Release Review
> > would reasonably think to include information about what security
> > issues have been raised and how they were handled.  For the TSC to
> > provide a bit more clarity around that for Release Reviews seems
> completely reasonable.
> >
> > I would maintain that a reasonable engineer looking at a Graduation
> > Review, seeing a 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)'
> > who has gone through several Releases, dutifully producing Release
> > Plans and Release Reviews that had the recommended sections that had
> > not been objected to, would reasonable think that pointing to them
> > covers that.  I would not expect a reasonable engineer to
> > spontaneously think that he should add information to the Graduation
> > Review 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section
> > for 'Security Issues'.  In essence, asking him to do so would be
> > surprising relative to the actual Project Lifecycle as written.
> >
> > Ed
> >
> > dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> >
> > > Trying to summarize to help others bootstrap this large thread.
> > >
> > > Ed's saying that the Graduation Review requires three primary things:
> > >
> > > Working code base
> > > Active Community
> > > History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)
> > >
> > > And that the third (Mature Release Process) expands into having a:
> > >
> > > Release Plan
> > > Release Review
> > >
> > > Where each expands a "rough" set of recommended of sections.
> > >
> > > I think the implication is that if a project has the appropriate
> > > wikis with the appropriate sections and they were delivered at the
> > > appropriate times, then it's out of scope to make any claim about
> > > the content of those sections.
> > >
> > > The root issue seems to be if that's true, or if the TSC can, while
> > > reviewing that content as part of a Graduation Review, have
> > > expectations for the content of those sections. For example, would a
> > > project doing a horrible job security-wise would be in-scope for
> > > consideration during the Graduation Review?
> > >
> > > Do I have this summery reasonably correct?
> > >
> > > Daniel Farrell
> > > Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
> > > https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
> > >
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > At the end of the day, a developer who is seeking to do the right
> > > > thing should be able to look at the Project Lifecycle and Mature
> > > > Release
> > > process,
> > > > and minimally be able to
> > > > follow them, either directly, or by clearly seeing what they need
> > > > to
> > > figure
> > > > out.
> > > >
> > > > If I am a developer looking at it, I can clearly see that to do a
> > > > Graduation Review, I need working code, an active community, and
> > > > to
> > > follow
> > > > the Mature Release process
> > > > (defined below).  Great, check.
> > > >
> > > > I can clearly see in the Mature Release Process that I need a
> > > > Release
> > > Plan
> > > > going into the Release and a Release Review when delivering a
> > > > Release for a Release to be considered mature, and that they
> > > > should have certain sections.
> > > > If I am unclear about the sort of thing to put into those
> > > > sections, I can go inquire after the current best practice for
> > > > them for at the time I am doing my Release.
> > > >
> > > > What I cannot do is look forward in time to the addition after the
> > > > fact
> > > of
> > > > new requirements, based on the intent of motivating preambles and
> > > > other things.
> > > >
> > > > The Project Lifecycle, complete with descriptions of the
> > > > Graduation
> > > Review
> > > > is here:
> > > > https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#ProjectTyp
> > > > es
> > > >
> > > > The Mature Release Process is here:
> > > >
> > > https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#MatureReleas
> > > eProcess
> > > >
> > > > I'd strongly encourage folks to read them in their entirety to
> > > > understand the relationship between the requirements therein, and
> > > > other motiviation
> > > or
> > > > aspirational
> > > > statements proximate to those requirements.
> > > >
> > > > Further comments inline.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > colin at colindixon.com>
> > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > > Inline.
> > > > >
> > > > > hagbard at gmail.com>
> > > > > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > >> Comments inline..
> 
> > > > >>
> > > > >> colin at colindixon.com>
> > > > >> wrote:
> > > > >>
> > > > >>> I'm just going to focus very concretely on what you feel
> > > > >>> should or shouldn't go into the graduation review because I'm
> > > > >>> having trouble separating it from the rest of the content here.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>> 1.) I can't tell concretely what you're saying you feel is OK
> > > > >>> or not w.r.t security here. Are you saying you agree that
> > > > >>> asking for
> > > projects to
> > > > >>> not have known vulnerabilities of certain importance to be
> > > > >>> mature is reasonable or unreasonable.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Clearly we can require that information in the Release Reviews
> > > > >> prospectively, 'Security Issues' is in that scope there.  I do
> > > > >> not see anything we can do in graduation reviews other than
> > > > >> referencing
> > > Release
> > > > >> Reviews (and Release Plans) per the expectations present at the
> > > > >> time we performed those Release Reviews.
> > > > >>
> > > > >
> > > > > So, in your mind, you see that as being unreasonable?
> > > > >
> > > >
> > > > Speaking just of my opinion and reading, I would find it entirely
> > > > reasonable to require beefing up the Security Issue section of a
> > > > Release Review as you have described, as that is where that section
> lives.
> > > > I do not see that as providing license to insert things into the
> > > Graduation
> > > > Review Template.
> > > >
> > > > In particular, the only requirement I see in the Mature Release
> > > > process
> > > is:
> > > >
> > > > "... should have a Release Plan published at the beginning of it's
> > > release
> > > > cycle by its committers, and a Release Review just prior to the
> > > > project release." and then goes on to say what sections those should
> have.
> > > >
> > > > That's the extent of the stated requirements for a project that I
> > > > see for following the Mature Release process.  I can clearly see
> > > > desiring to add other requirements to the Mature Release process,
> > > > or other items to the Release Plan or Release Review to be
> > > > considered to have followed that process.  But those are *changes* to
> the Mature Release process.
> > > >
> > > > The Graduation Review requires having a history of following the
> > > > Mature Release Process.  The Mature Release process requires two
> > > > things, a
> > > Release
> > > > Plan and a Release Review, and defines the sections in them.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >>
> > > > >>
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>> 2.) I feel like our mature release process clearly says that
> > > > >>> coordination between projects is a critical part. Asking
> > > > >>> people to
> > > state
> > > > >>> how they did or didn't meet agreed-upon cross-project
> > > > >>> deliverables
> > > seems
> > > > >>> within scope.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Could you point me to that in the Mature Release process?  I am
> > > > >> not seeing there something that maps in my mind to this, though
> > > > >> I do
> > > sometimes
> > > > >> miss things.
> > > > >>
> > > > >
> > > > > I did several mails ago, but again, the first two sentences of
> > > > > the
> > > mature
> > > > > release process as defined in the lifecycle are: "The basic idea
> > > behind the
> > > > > mature release process is to define the most straight forward
> > > > > way to
> > > insure
> > > > > that projects can coordinate with each other. The idea is to

> > > > Which, in context, is a lovely statement for the motivation for
> > > > *why* the Release Plans and Release Reviews are required following
> > > > it, and why they have the sections they do.
> > > > But its a pure preamble to a set of requirements for two very
> > > > specific documents (Release Plan and Release Review) that are the
> > > > actual requirements of the Mature Release process.
> > > > If we are going to choose to interpret that "To encourage x we are
> > > > going
> > > to
> > > > require y and z" implies that we can, via interpretation, and
> > > > without altering our governance insert any and all additional
> > > > requirements that
> > > may
> > > > also
> > > > serve x... I'm not sure what meaning is left in the governance.
> > > >
> > > > In particular, I can come up with plausible justifications for a
> > > > wide
> > > array
> > > > of additional requirement (both wise and unwise) as being
> > > > motivated by
> > > that
> > > > preamble sentence.  Allowing the motivation for a declared
> > > > requirements
> > > to
> > > > justify
> > > > the addition of new requirements purely by interpretation allows
> > > > interpretation with very few bounds.
> > > >
> > > > Its also worth noting that our broader governance requires the TSC
> > > > to recommend changes in the project lifecycle to the board.  One
> > > > possible
> > > way
> > > > of looking at that requirement is that it causes a very deliberate
> > > > and broad debate about the wisdom of adding new requirements.
> > > > Very few things in our governance require both the TSC and the
> > > > board to both act (though often
> > > the
> > > > board *does* seek the TSCs input when not required), changing the
> > > > project lifecycle is one of them.  I am personally very leery of
> > > > sidestepping
> > > that,
> > > > particularly with justifications that can largely sidestep that process.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
what do you mean by state?
To  me - mature means that project is fully functioning and being used externally and the only feedback are bug fixes and minor enhancements envisioned after 2 releases.
If there are major enhancements within 2 releases - it is in incubation mode still.

One can change the number of releases....

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 3:36 PM
To: Alex_Zhang; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

I'm sure Phil (who I think is on this list) can give us that detail; though just pulling that email thread up gives you a lot of background. 

Chris.

(the thread starts here: https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-September/003783.html )

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Alex_Zhang [mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com]

> 
> "mature" project is a good topic for sure. It'd be really helpful to have
> someone who knows the current definition/flow well enough to give us
> some dump first and with  some Q&A time.
> 
> Regards,
>
