> -----Original Message-----
> From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-
> group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:28 AM
> To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> Subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
> 
> Advisors,
> 
> The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation
> review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the
> thread below.
> 
> Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined
> (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the
> word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning,
> successful open source project.?
> 
> This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the
> end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.
> 
> Cheers,
> Chris.
> 
> 
> From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
> To: Luke, Chris
> Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org;
> tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at
> Graduation Review Tempalte
> 
> The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement
> about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we
> start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that
> graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project
> lifecycle document here:
> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
> This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that
> question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope
> for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we
> might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any
> input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be
> interesting and much appreciated.
> 
> Cheers,
> --Colin
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 11:22 PM, Luke, Chris
> <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:
> 
> I skimmed the thread and definitely think the AG can provide some
> guidance.
> 
> Could I ask for a succinct statement of the query and its background? To
> make sure we answer the right question :)
> 
> I'll save my own detailed comments for later, save that as Neela suggests the
> word 'mature' has much implied meaning for end users around fitness for
> purpose derived in no small part from having mileage under its belt
> (preferably miles that were honest about their emissions too).
> 
> Cheers,
> Chris
> 
> From: Neela Jacques
> Sent: 9/24/15, 6:36 PM
> To: Colin Dixon
> Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org, tsc at lists.opendaylight.org, Todd Benzies,
> Philip Robb, Luke, Chris
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at
> Graduation Review Tempalte TSC members, developers.
> 
> Can I suggest that you ask our Advisory Group members what they would
> expect as users from a Mature project? This is exactly the type of question
> we shouldn't be guessing as to what end users want and expect but getting
> real input and data. Mature is inherently a label who's primary use is to
> convey a certain level of expectations for an end-users. We should make
> sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether
> they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume
> such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of
> maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does.
> Unfortunately for him it doesn't so much matter whether he meets his own
> definition of mature but whether he meets ours). Phil and Todd can facilitate
> formulating the questions, and/or creating a forum for discussion.
> 
> -Neela
> 
> 
> Nicolas (Neela) Jacques | Executive Director | OpenDaylight Project | 650-
> 704-7029
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com>
> wrote:
> Comments inline...
> 
> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> > I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that
> > he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of
> > Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.
> 
> That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding
> something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.
> 
> Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the
> 
> History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues
> 
> chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
> section" during Graduation Reviews.
> 
> Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release
> Reviews and look at their Security Issues sections.  That's just taking a look at
> the supporting collateral backing the claim for having followed the Mature
> Release process.
> 
> 
> Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...
> 
> Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right wikis at
> the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that says all the
> most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever) can be "Mature",
> as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing a step that would block
> such projects from reaching "Mature"?
> 
> Yeah, that is an interesting question.  Part of the intention as I remember it
> originally was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its
> requirements are mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it
> be stuff that would be pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example:
> Working code base.  Definitely tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for
> without having a code base in front of you, but not all that hard to determine
> about a code base you are looking at).
> 
> Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not*
> the Simultaneous Release process... its most definitely simpler.  For example,
> the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole heartedly endorse) layer
> on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
> As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks
> know what you thought you thought you were doing so there was some
> hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually
> delivered so there's some clarity there".  Stuff happens, and if you chain
> people to their Release Plans, they will be both timid in them, and also
> incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into them things that other folks
> need that are less central to what they care about.  So I would be very
> reluctant to consider 'late' or 'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan,
> because I suspect they'd incent very damaging compensating behaviors.  If
> someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project
> thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly
> incent turning them away (the opposite of what we want).  And if I depend
> on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
> I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm
> going to be dinged for it.  It tends to discourage, rather than encourage
> collaboration and striving.
> 
> In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here,
> is part of why *actually* changing the governance (with the attendant
> thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me,
> feels like very broad creep by interpretation.  The project lifecycle change
> process forces rather a lot more deliberation.
> 
> I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to
> rework the project lifecycle".  I'm going to have my own principles around
> that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not
> political, and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those
> personal biases (much as I may be fond of them, and wish others would
> adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding
> on such a discussion.
> 
> Ed
> 
> 
> 
> Daniel Farrell
> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
> https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> > Dan,
> >
> > From my point of view, roughly yes.  Part of the question though is
> > how far a stretch it is.
> > If the TSC were holding a Release Review for a project, opinions about
> > the contents of its 'Security Issues' section that are germane to the
> > handling of 'Security Issues' seems perfectly in scope.
> > My opinion is that adding a 'Security Issues' section to the
> > Graduation Review outside of the process of actually adding that
> > section, or sticking such a section under another section should
> > properly involve revising the Project Lifecycle to do so.
> >
> > I would also argue for the heuristic: "Would a reasonable engineer
> > obviously see something as part of the stated section a priori"
> > is a good litmus test.  I would maintain that a reasonable engineer,
> > when preparing their Security Issue's section for a Release Review
> > would reasonably think to include information about what security
> > issues have been raised and how they were handled.  For the TSC to
> > provide a bit more clarity around that for Release Reviews seems
> completely reasonable.
> >
> > I would maintain that a reasonable engineer looking at a Graduation
> > Review, seeing a 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)'
> > who has gone through several Releases, dutifully producing Release
> > Plans and Release Reviews that had the recommended sections that had
> > not been objected to, would reasonable think that pointing to them
> > covers that.  I would not expect a reasonable engineer to
> > spontaneously think that he should add information to the Graduation
> > Review 'History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section
> > for 'Security Issues'.  In essence, asking him to do so would be
> > surprising relative to the actual Project Lifecycle as written.
> >
> > Ed
> >
> > dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
> >
> > > Trying to summarize to help others bootstrap this large thread.
> > >
> > > Ed's saying that the Graduation Review requires three primary things:
> > >
> > > Working code base
> > > Active Community
> > > History of Releases (using Mature Release Process)
> > >
> > > And that the third (Mature Release Process) expands into having a:
> > >
> > > Release Plan
> > > Release Review
> > >
> > > Where each expands a "rough" set of recommended of sections.
> > >
> > > I think the implication is that if a project has the appropriate
> > > wikis with the appropriate sections and they were delivered at the
> > > appropriate times, then it's out of scope to make any claim about
> > > the content of those sections.
> > >
> > > The root issue seems to be if that's true, or if the TSC can, while
> > > reviewing that content as part of a Graduation Review, have
> > > expectations for the content of those sections. For example, would a
> > > project doing a horrible job security-wise would be in-scope for
> > > consideration during the Graduation Review?
> > >
> > > Do I have this summery reasonably correct?
> > >
> > > Daniel Farrell
> > > Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
> > > https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
> > >
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > At the end of the day, a developer who is seeking to do the right
> > > > thing should be able to look at the Project Lifecycle and Mature
> > > > Release
> > > process,
> > > > and minimally be able to
> > > > follow them, either directly, or by clearly seeing what they need
> > > > to
> > > figure
> > > > out.
> > > >
> > > > If I am a developer looking at it, I can clearly see that to do a
> > > > Graduation Review, I need working code, an active community, and
> > > > to
> > > follow
> > > > the Mature Release process
> > > > (defined below).  Great, check.
> > > >
> > > > I can clearly see in the Mature Release Process that I need a
> > > > Release
> > > Plan
> > > > going into the Release and a Release Review when delivering a
> > > > Release for a Release to be considered mature, and that they
> > > > should have certain sections.
> > > > If I am unclear about the sort of thing to put into those
> > > > sections, I can go inquire after the current best practice for
> > > > them for at the time I am doing my Release.
> > > >
> > > > What I cannot do is look forward in time to the addition after the
> > > > fact
> > > of
> > > > new requirements, based on the intent of motivating preambles and
> > > > other things.
> > > >
> > > > The Project Lifecycle, complete with descriptions of the
> > > > Graduation
> > > Review
> > > > is here:
> > > > https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#ProjectTyp
> > > > es
> > > >
> > > > The Mature Release Process is here:
> > > >
> > > https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases#MatureReleas
> > > eProcess
> > > >
> > > > I'd strongly encourage folks to read them in their entirety to
> > > > understand the relationship between the requirements therein, and
> > > > other motiviation
> > > or
> > > > aspirational
> > > > statements proximate to those requirements.
> > > >
> > > > Further comments inline.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > colin at colindixon.com>
> > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > > Inline.
> > > > >
> > > > > hagbard at gmail.com>
> > > > > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > >> Comments inline..
> 
> > > > >>
> > > > >> colin at colindixon.com>
> > > > >> wrote:
> > > > >>
> > > > >>> I'm just going to focus very concretely on what you feel
> > > > >>> should or shouldn't go into the graduation review because I'm
> > > > >>> having trouble separating it from the rest of the content here.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>> 1.) I can't tell concretely what you're saying you feel is OK
> > > > >>> or not w.r.t security here. Are you saying you agree that
> > > > >>> asking for
> > > projects to
> > > > >>> not have known vulnerabilities of certain importance to be
> > > > >>> mature is reasonable or unreasonable.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Clearly we can require that information in the Release Reviews
> > > > >> prospectively, 'Security Issues' is in that scope there.  I do
> > > > >> not see anything we can do in graduation reviews other than
> > > > >> referencing
> > > Release
> > > > >> Reviews (and Release Plans) per the expectations present at the
> > > > >> time we performed those Release Reviews.
> > > > >>
> > > > >
> > > > > So, in your mind, you see that as being unreasonable?
> > > > >
> > > >
> > > > Speaking just of my opinion and reading, I would find it entirely
> > > > reasonable to require beefing up the Security Issue section of a
> > > > Release Review as you have described, as that is where that section
> lives.
> > > > I do not see that as providing license to insert things into the
> > > Graduation
> > > > Review Template.
> > > >
> > > > In particular, the only requirement I see in the Mature Release
> > > > process
> > > is:
> > > >
> > > > "... should have a Release Plan published at the beginning of it's
> > > release
> > > > cycle by its committers, and a Release Review just prior to the
> > > > project release." and then goes on to say what sections those should
> have.
> > > >
> > > > That's the extent of the stated requirements for a project that I
> > > > see for following the Mature Release process.  I can clearly see
> > > > desiring to add other requirements to the Mature Release process,
> > > > or other items to the Release Plan or Release Review to be
> > > > considered to have followed that process.  But those are *changes* to
> the Mature Release process.
> > > >
> > > > The Graduation Review requires having a history of following the
> > > > Mature Release Process.  The Mature Release process requires two
> > > > things, a
> > > Release
> > > > Plan and a Release Review, and defines the sections in them.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >>
> > > > >>
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>> 2.) I feel like our mature release process clearly says that
> > > > >>> coordination between projects is a critical part. Asking
> > > > >>> people to
> > > state
> > > > >>> how they did or didn't meet agreed-upon cross-project
> > > > >>> deliverables
> > > seems
> > > > >>> within scope.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Could you point me to that in the Mature Release process?  I am
> > > > >> not seeing there something that maps in my mind to this, though
> > > > >> I do
> > > sometimes
> > > > >> miss things.
> > > > >>
> > > > >
> > > > > I did several mails ago, but again, the first two sentences of
> > > > > the
> > > mature
> > > > > release process as defined in the lifecycle are: "The basic idea
> > > behind the
> > > > > mature release process is to define the most straight forward
> > > > > way to
> > > insure
> > > > > that projects can coordinate with each other. The idea is to
> > > > > have
> > > simple,
> > > > > clear, public declarations of what they are going to do and
> > > > > when, and
> > > that
> > > > > they've done it."
> > > > >
> > > >
> > > > Which, in context, is a lovely statement for the motivation for
> > > > *why* the Release Plans and Release Reviews are required following
> > > > it, and why they have the sections they do.
> > > > But its a pure preamble to a set of requirements for two very
> > > > specific documents (Release Plan and Release Review) that are the
> > > > actual requirements of the Mature Release process.
> > > > If we are going to choose to interpret that "To encourage x we are
> > > > going
> > > to
> > > > require y and z" implies that we can, via interpretation, and
> > > > without altering our governance insert any and all additional
> > > > requirements that
> > > may
> > > > also
> > > > serve x... I'm not sure what meaning is left in the governance.
> > > >
> > > > In particular, I can come up with plausible justifications for a
> > > > wide
> > > array
> > > > of additional requirement (both wise and unwise) as being
> > > > motivated by
> > > that
> > > > preamble sentence.  Allowing the motivation for a declared
> > > > requirements
> > > to
> > > > justify
> > > > the addition of new requirements purely by interpretation allows
> > > > interpretation with very few bounds.
> > > >
> > > > Its also worth noting that our broader governance requires the TSC
> > > > to recommend changes in the project lifecycle to the board.  One
> > > > possible
> > > way
> > > > of looking at that requirement is that it causes a very deliberate
> > > > and broad debate about the wisdom of adding new requirements.
> > > > Very few things in our governance require both the TSC and the
> > > > board to both act (though often
> > > the
> > > > board *does* seek the TSCs input when not required), changing the
> > > > project lifecycle is one of them.  I am personally very leery of
> > > > sidestepping
> > > that,
> > > > particularly with justifications that can largely sidestep that process.
> > > >
> > > > Ed
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >>
> > > > >>
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>> 3.) It seems like some of your issues are asking for people to
> > > > >>> meet certain bars vs. merely read out where they fell on some
> > > > >>> axis, e.g., fixing security vulnerabilities and where
> > > > >>> deliverables fell in reality vs.
> > > the
> > > > >>> defined milestones. My personal opinion is that we don't at
> > > > >>> least
> > > call
> > > > >>> out
> > > > >>> the bar we'd like people to meet, it will be difficult for the
> > > > >>> TSC to have a consistent standard for what's required and
> > > > >>> projects will have a
> > > harder
> > > > >>> time providing the TSC with the information they're looking for.
> > > > >>>
> > > > >>
> > > > >>
> > > > >> I have three positions:

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
Hi, just muy .2 cents

Stable project for me means exactly that: the software runs and has no erratic behaviour and I can therefore trust it when I use it. Mature is when I have good documentation on top of that.

Best, /PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

Network Innovation & Virtualisation

Fragen sind da, um gestellt zu werden.

>what do you mean by state?
>To  me - mature means that project is fully functioning and being used externally and the only feedback are bug fixes and minor enhancements envisioned after 2 releases.
>If there are major enhancements within 2 releases - it is in incubation mode still.
>
>One can change the number of releases....

>> sure that whatever process we ask a project to follow to measure whether
>> they get this label fits as well as we can with what an end-user would assume
>> such a label means (My 7 year old definitely thinks he exhibits a high level of
>> maturity, and based on his own definition of maturity he probably does.

>> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 3:25 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com>
>> wrote:
>> Comments inline...
>>
>> On Thu, Sep 24, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:
>> > I would not expect a reasonable engineer to spontaneously think that
>> > he should add information to the Graduation Review 'History of
>> > Releases (using Mature Release Process)' section for 'Security Issues'.
>>
>> That's not what I had in mind, which makes me think I'm misunderstanding
>> something. I wasn't around when this was written, so that seems likely.
>>
>> Sticking with the security example, I'm proposing we make use of the
>>
>> History of Releases -> Release Review -> Security Issues
>>
>> chain to consider "opinions about the contents of [the] 'Security Issues'
>> section" during Graduation Reviews.
>>
>> Sure... I would find it pretty reasonable to follow the links to the Release
>> Reviews and look at their Security Issues sections.  That's just taking a look at
>> the supporting collateral backing the claim for having followed the Mature
>> Release process.
>>
>>
>> Coming back to what I may be misunderstanding...
>>
>> Is "Maturity" here just about following the process, creating the right wikis at
>> the right times and such? A project with a Release Review that says all the
>> most horrible things (late, introduced malware, whatever) can be "Mature",
>> as long as they follow the process? Or am I missing a step that would block
>> such projects from reaching "Mature"?
>>
>> Yeah, that is an interesting question.  Part of the intention as I remember it
>> originally was to have Mature be mostly mechanical and not political (thus its
>> requirements are mostly mechanical, and not political), and to try to have it
>> be stuff that would be pretty obviously true or false after the fact (example:
>> Working code base.  Definitely tricky to lay out a precise set of ticky boxes for
>> without having a code base in front of you, but not all that hard to determine
>> about a code base you are looking at).
>>
>> Late is an interesting question, because the Mature Release process is *not*
>> the Simultaneous Release process... its most definitely simpler.  For example,
>> the TSC *can* (and does, often for reasons I whole heartedly endorse) layer
>> on quite a bit more structure than the Mature Release Process does.
>> As written, the Mature Release Process is mostly about "Did you let folks
>> know what you thought you thought you were doing so there was some
>> hope of non-insider engaging" and "Did you let folks know what you actually
>> delivered so there's some clarity there".  Stuff happens, and if you chain
>> people to their Release Plans, they will be both timid in them, and also
>> incredibly resistant to actually trying to put into them things that other folks
>> need that are less central to what they care about.  So I would be very
>> reluctant to consider 'late' or 'didn't deliver everything listed in release' plan,
>> because I suspect they'd incent very damaging compensating behaviors.  If
>> someone shows up to a project willing to do some useful work the project
>> thinks is a good idea... dinging the project for it not happening will strongly
>> incent turning them away (the opposite of what we want).  And if I depend
>> on something from another project for one of my deliverables...
>> I am very unlikely to take the risk of putting that deliverable in my plan if I'm
>> going to be dinged for it.  It tends to discourage, rather than encourage
>> collaboration and striving.
>>
>> In some sense, thinking through things like the question you just raised here,
>> is part of why *actually* changing the governance (with the attendant
>> thought and care) seems much more reasonable to me than what, to me,
>> feels like very broad creep by interpretation.  The project lifecycle change
>> process forces rather a lot more deliberation.
>>
>> I'm actually quite open to discussions about "Lets look at whether we want to
>> rework the project lifecycle".  I'm going to have my own principles around
>> that which I feel passionate about (like trying to keep it mechanical and not
>> political, and trying to make it obvious to a reasonable engineer)... but those
>> personal biases (much as I may be fond of them, and wish others would
>> adopt them, and much as I'd advocate for them) are not necessarily binding
>> on such a discussion.
>>
>> Ed
>>
>>
>>
>> Daniel Farrell
>> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
>> https://twitter.com/dfarrell07
>>

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Hi,

for me a stable software (project) requires:
* it is documented on a expert level, what the software should do
* the software has no known major bugs --> so I can expect that the promised functions are working
* a software QA is running to avoid major bugs
* major bugs are fixed within x (x=?) days
* minor bugs should be fixed

for me a mature software (project) requires:
* it is documented on a expert and non expert level, what the software should do
* it is documented how to use the software
* a documentation covering securitiy is available to describe the secure installation and usage of the software
* the software features are bound to major version numbers
   * bug fixes keep the major version number, but add a new minor version number
   * feature enhancements of the software require a new major version number
* the software has no known major bugs and only a few minor bugs
* an extended software QA is running to avoid major bugs
* a bugtools is available to document bugs and possible workarounds
   * major bugs are fixed within x days
   * minor bugs are fixed within y days or a workaround is available
* a security management process is in place to handle CVEs
* the software is used by many users - I do not expect, that a software part of Opendaylight used by only one company/user can reach the mature state.

Regards
Ralf

On 28.09.2015 19:28, Luke, Chris wrote:
> Advisors,
>
> The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the graduation review of a project that would indicate a project is ?mature?; please see the thread below.
>
> Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already defined (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic use of the word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a ?fully functioning, successful open source project.?
>
> This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list and at the end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.
>
> Cheers,
> Chris.
>
>
> From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
> Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
> To: Luke, Chris
> Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org; tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
> Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at Graduation Review Tempalte
>
> The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an agreement about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project lifecycle document here:
> https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
> This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in scope for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents. Any input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be interesting and much appreciated.
>
> Cheers,
> --Colin

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Hi,
I agree with the notion that the s/w should be in-use by more than one independant external user.  Perhaps more specifically it should be at least 2 independant users/organisations, and the software should be used in a production environment (ie, not for lab experimentation).  
 
Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters

Mobile 07920 230623

Hi,

for me a stable software (project) requires:
* it is documented on a expert level, what the software should do
* the software has no known major bugs --> so I can expect that the promised functions are working
* a software QA is running to avoid major bugs
* major bugs are fixed within x (x=?) days
* minor bugs should be fixed

for me a mature software (project) requires:
* it is documented on a expert and non expert level, what the software should do
* it is documented how to use the software
* a documentation covering securitiy is available to describe the secure installation and usage of the software
* the software features are bound to major version numbers
   * bug fixes keep the major version number, but add a new minor version number
   * feature enhancements of the software require a new major version number
* the software has no known major bugs and only a few minor bugs
* an extended software QA is running to avoid major bugs
* a bugtools is available to document bugs and possible workarounds
   * major bugs are fixed within x days
   * minor bugs are fixed within y days or a workaround is available
* a security management process is in place to handle CVEs
* the software is used by many users - I do not expect, that a software part of Opendaylight used by only one company/user can reach the mature state.

Regards
Ralf

The challenging part is demonstrating "many users" in a production setting, especially when it's not yet mature. It's sometimes difficult to know that this is the case, for example.

This is good stuff everyone, keep it coming!

Chris.

>Likewise.
>
>The challenging part is demonstrating "many users" in a production
>setting, especially when it's not yet mature. It's sometimes difficult to
>know that this is the case, for example.
>
>This is good stuff everyone, keep it coming!
>
>Chris.
>
>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-
>> group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of CHIOSI, MARGARET T
>> Sent: Tuesday, September 29, 2015 06:52
>> To: ralf at trezeciak.de; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
>> Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
>> 
>> I like Ralf's description. Thorough.
>> 
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-
>> group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Ralf Trezeciak
>>(Privat)
>> Sent: Tuesday, September 29, 2015 4:50 AM
>> To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
>> Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
>> 
>> Hi,
>> 
>> for me a stable software (project) requires:
>> * it is documented on a expert level, what the software should do
>> * the software has no known major bugs --> so I can expect that the
>> promised functions are working
>> * a software QA is running to avoid major bugs
>> * major bugs are fixed within x (x=?) days
>> * minor bugs should be fixed
>> 
>> for me a mature software (project) requires:
>> * it is documented on a expert and non expert level, what the software
>> should do
>> * it is documented how to use the software
>> * a documentation covering securitiy is available to describe the secure
>> installation and usage of the software
>> * the software features are bound to major version numbers
>>    * bug fixes keep the major version number, but add a new minor
>>version
>> number
>>    * feature enhancements of the software require a new major version
>> number
>> * the software has no known major bugs and only a few minor bugs
>> * an extended software QA is running to avoid major bugs
>> * a bugtools is available to document bugs and possible workarounds
>>    * major bugs are fixed within x days
>>    * minor bugs are fixed within y days or a workaround is available
>> * a security management process is in place to handle CVEs
>> * the software is used by many users - I do not expect, that a software
>>part
>> of Opendaylight used by only one company/user can reach the mature
>>state.
>> 
>> Regards
>> Ralf
>> 
>> On 28.09.2015 19:28, Luke, Chris wrote:
>> > Advisors,
>> >
>> > The TSC is asking for any suggestions we may have regarding the
>> graduation review of a project that would indicate a project is
>>?mature?;
>> please see the thread below.
>> >
>> > Note that the TSC indicates that the meaning of ?mature? is already
>> defined (see link below). We?re not being asked to debate the semantic
>>use
>> of the word, rather the state a project must be in to qualify as a
>>?fully
>> functioning, successful open source project.?
>> >
>> > This is our first formal such request; I suggest we discuss on-list
>>and at the
>> end of the week I?ll see if we have any conclusions to summarize.
>> >
>> > Cheers,
>> > Chris.
>> >
>> >
>> > From: Colin Dixon [mailto:colin at colindixon.com]
>> > Sent: Monday, September 28, 2015 10:59 AM
>> > To: Luke, Chris
>> > Cc: Neela Jacques; discuss at lists.opendaylight.org;
>> tsc at lists.opendaylight.org; Todd Benzies; Philip Robb
>> > Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Discuss] First pass at
>> Graduation Review Tempalte
>> >
>> > The really succinct, statement is we're trying to to come to an
>>agreement
>> about what the TSC should bear in mind and ask for as collateral when we
>> start holding graduation reviews to move projects to mature. Note that
>> graduation reviews and mature are technical terms defined in the project
>> lifecycle document here:
>> > https://www.opendaylight.org/project-lifecycle-releases
>> > This thread should serve as good, if lengthy, background on what that
>> question including differing opinions on what can be (and should be) in
>>scope
>> for the review under our current governing documents as well as what we
>> might like to see if we were willing to change our governing documents.
>>Any
>> input from the Advisory Group on either or both of those would be
>> interesting and much appreciated.
>> >
>> > Cheers,
>> > --Colin
>> >
>> 
>>

>> _______________________________________________

>> https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/advisory-group

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Long term support is indeed an important factor.  Long term commitment could
also be gauged by if a project would continue to be a place for innovations
from the community.

Alex

OpenDaylight Advisors,

Given that the October 15th Advisory Group meeting will conflict with SDN &
OpenFlow World Congress in Dusseldorf, and specifically the User Panel
during the OpenDaylight Mini-Summit, I'd like to propose that we push the
meeting to the following week at the same time.

October 22nd at 8:00am PT.

Please let me know if there are any objections by EOD Friday (10/2).

Regards,

Todd

OpenDaylight Advisors,

Given that the October 15th Advisory Group meeting will conflict with SDN & OpenFlow World Congress in Dusseldorf, and specifically the User Panel during the OpenDaylight Mini-Summit, I'd like to propose that we push the meeting to the following week at the same time.

October 22nd at 8:00am PT.

Please let me know if there are any objections by EOD Friday (10/2).

Regards,

Todd

> imediatamente por esta mesma via e proceda a sua destrui??o

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Okay everyone, here's my summarized version of the thread (which I've shared with Colin already to see if it's a useful format and will post back to the TSC thread shortly):


The Advisory Group feels that mature and stable are different things. In general, mature is seen as a higher standard than stable. A checklist of items that broadly define stable and mature could include:

Stable
* Complete documentation exists that is suitable for experts which explains how to configure and use the key project features.
* The project has no known major issues; users of it have the expectation that the software works as advertised.
* There is a QA process to catch and avoid major issues making it into a release. This QA process includes a set of identified environments (hardware, software, O/S, etc).
* There is some minimum interval between subsequent stable releases.

* Once released, there is a commitment to repair any new major issues within some advertised time frame.
* Once released, there is a commitment to attempt to repair minor issues before the next release.

Mature
* The project has been included, as a stable release, in at least two major releases of the parent project.
* The project has multiple users; to be considered mature, several end-users must be actively using the project and ideally several are using it in production. To be mature, the expectation is that the user base of that project has some quantifiable experience of using it.
* Potentially the community-at-large should have some say on whether a project graduates to mature.
* Complete documentation exists for non-experts which explains how to configure, use and maintain all the project features.
* A security guide exists that identifies all known areas that need attention with suggestions on how to secure them.
* A security process exists to handle emergent CVEs.
* The project has no known major issues and only very few minor issues.
* The QA process includes steps that attempt to catch and avoid both major and minor issues.

* Software releases are bound to their version numbers; minor release = increment minor version component, major release = increment major version component.
** Fixes for issues are included in minor releases.
** Minor enhancements may be included in minor releases if there is identifiable benefit.
** All other enhancements require a new major release.
** Major releases have some degree of minimum interval.

* Once released, there is a commitment to repair any new major issues within some advertised time frame.
* Once released, there is a commitment to attempt to repair minor issues before the next release, noting the expectation that few minor issues are acceptable in a new release.
* There is some indication that the project will continue to be supported for the foreseeable future; and that the community will manage a graceful exit of the project if that becomes necessary.

Chris.


________________________________________
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> on behalf of Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com>
Sent: Tuesday, September 29, 2015 7:45 PM
To: 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T'; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

Long term support is indeed an important factor.  Long term commitment could
also be gauged by if a project would continue to be a place for innovations
from the community.

Alex

-----Original Message-----

[mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of CHIOSI,
MARGARET T
Sent: Tuesday, September 29, 2015 6:19 AM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

Another Comment within AT&T:

Best regards

> ** Major releases have some degree of minimum interval.
>
> * Once released, there is a commitment to repair any new major issues within some advertised time frame.
> * Once released, there is a commitment to attempt to repair minor issues before the next release, noting the expectation that few minor issues are acceptable in a new release.
> * There is some indication that the project will continue to be supported for the foreseeable future; and that the community will manage a graceful exit of the project if that becomes necessary.
>
> Chris.

> Another Comment within AT&T:
>  From my perspective - I think the reason I care about the status of a
> project is that I can then base business features on it.
>
> An incubation project may have a critical feature for me but if its
> incubation then it can go away in a future release (like plugin2OC).
> As a service provider using ODL, I need to know when I can depend on a
> project and when I need to make special arrangements
>
> A mature project should be something a user of ODL can depend on being in
> each and every ongoing release and that the community is supporting as
> component.  Mature projects could go away but only with careful attention by
> the community to a migration plan to something else that fills the need.
>
> With that viewpoint, the criteria of graduation to me should be dependent on
> the existing community agreeing that the function is stable, documented and
> the community large enough to support ongoing integration with the rest of
> the code base.  The community can best judge that but I would be looking for
> committers from two or more companies as a sign of that health and how well
> they are meeting the various milestones where they are supporting the
> product integration points.
>
> As a customer I may have my favorite projects but it's really more about the
> community committing to the long term support of that project.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review
message_text:
Thanks Luke for this summary 
In addition to the Stability and Maturity we need also to consider the notion of 'Carrier Grade' SDN controller including Performance, Resiliency, Security and Scalability. 
I have summarized SDN controller benchmark  terminology proposed in the attached 2 IRTF Drafts. 
BTW a new project is proposed within OPNFV on the  SDN performance testing
https://wiki.opnfv.org/project_proposals/cperf

.Performance  
-Network Topology Discovery Time  
-Asynchronous Message Processing Time   
-Asynchronous Message Processing Rate  
-Reactive Path Provisioning Time    
-Proactive Path Provisioning Time   
-Reactive Path Provisioning Rate    
-Proactive Path Provisioning Rate     
-Network Topology Change Detection Time   

.Scalability  
-Control Sessions Capacity 
-Network Discovery Size   
-Forwarding Table Capacity  

.Security   
-Exception Handling   
-Denial of Service Handling   

.Reliability 
-Controller Failover Time   
-Network Re-Provisioning Time   

Regards
Jamil

-----Message d'origine-----
De?: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] De la part de Luke, Chris
Envoy??: mercredi 7 octobre 2015 16:47
??: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Objet?: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

Okay everyone, here's my summarized version of the thread (which I've shared with Colin already to see if it's a useful format and will post back to the TSC thread shortly):


The Advisory Group feels that mature and stable are different things. In general, mature is seen as a higher standard than stable. A checklist of items that broadly define stable and mature could include:

Stable
* Complete documentation exists that is suitable for experts which explains how to configure and use the key project features.
* The project has no known major issues; users of it have the expectation that the software works as advertised.
* There is a QA process to catch and avoid major issues making it into a release. This QA process includes a set of identified environments (hardware, software, O/S, etc).
* There is some minimum interval between subsequent stable releases.

* Once released, there is a commitment to repair any new major issues within some advertised time frame.
* Once released, there is a commitment to attempt to repair minor issues before the next release.

Mature
* The project has been included, as a stable release, in at least two major releases of the parent project.
* The project has multiple users; to be considered mature, several end-users must be actively using the project and ideally several are using it in production. To be mature, the expectation is that the user base of that project has some quantifiable experience of using it.
* Potentially the community-at-large should have some say on whether a project graduates to mature.
* Complete documentation exists for non-experts which explains how to configure, use and maintain all the project features.
* A security guide exists that identifies all known areas that need attention with suggestions on how to secure them.
* A security process exists to handle emergent CVEs.
* The project has no known major issues and only very few minor issues.
* The QA process includes steps that attempt to catch and avoid both major and minor issues.

* Software releases are bound to their version numbers; minor release = increment minor version component, major release = increment major version component.
** Fixes for issues are included in minor releases.
** Minor enhancements may be included in minor releases if there is identifiable benefit.
** All other enhancements require a new major release.
** Major releases have some degree of minimum interval.

* Once released, there is a commitment to repair any new major issues within some advertised time frame.
* Once released, there is a commitment to attempt to repair minor issues before the next release, noting the expectation that few minor issues are acceptable in a new release.
* There is some indication that the project will continue to be supported for the foreseeable future; and that the community will manage a graceful exit of the project if that becomes necessary.

Chris.


________________________________________
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> on behalf of Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com>
Sent: Tuesday, September 29, 2015 7:45 PM
To: 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T'; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC request for comment: Graduation Review

Long term support is indeed an important factor.  Long term commitment could also be gauged by if a project would continue to be a place for innovations from the community.

Alex

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core
message_text:
The TSC has had a brief discussion after our comments last week and they are seeking some clarity between "core" and "mature", since we added the concept of "stable" in our response.

The thread is here: https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-October/003983.html

The summary is (paraphrasing both Colin and Ed):

                Given that we currently have two lifecycle states, "mature" and "core", what do we want "mature" to mean and what do we want "core" to mean?
Do we envisage a third pre-requisite state called "stable"?

Chris.
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/private/advisory-group/attachments/20151013/8d006a9f/attachment.html>

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core
message_text:
I think core means it is mandatory to the platform vs optional. That is different from stable.
Stable is a criteria for maturity - so maybe we just merge to one term and list all the characteristics - stable and mature definitions combine and pick one as the category/stage.
Then Core features progress to different development stages which eventually get to stable/mature.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core
message_text:
Yes, busy in Dusselfdorf with WIFI hunt..

 

"mature", "stable" are quality state. Whether we have one or two depends on
what we can really accomplish when "enforce" each of the state.  I prefer to
have just one state here from use end.

 

I think "core" belongs to functionality categorization.  It should be
clearly separated from quality state.  I'm interested to know how would we
determine and mark "core".  Keep in mind one "core" to someone may not be
"core" to other.

 

Alex

Chris

subject: [advisory-group] SDN/NFV World Congress
message_text:
I also feel that the hallway conversations, dinner meetings appear to be
more useful


One thought is that if ODL could do more ?marketing?  on how ODL helps with
the actual operators solutions (like Neela showed on Friday in his keynote),
or just some specific technology solutions, that would attract more traffic.
Maybe we just get used to that ODL could do anything
but others may not know
it, and many are typically seeking for something that tends to be specific.

 

Alex

dinner meetings were useful. 

 

Chris

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/private/advisory-group/attachments/20151019/cb94c80c/attachment-0001.html>

subject: [advisory-group] SDN/NFV World Congress
message_text:
That seems to play in to the stuff we've already been talking about around showing how to do specific things.

We seem to be saying we want a more technical venue, which is good (an operationally focused one, perhaps). But with the number of conferences there are currently my leadership is pushing back on travel quite hard; they're looking for some consolidation. Maybe there's room for a neutral conference to spring up, or for the various projects to come together, have joint technical meetings (with some dev and also some ops focus) and limit these conferences to 2 or 3 per year.

The marketing events can happen as often as they want - but we need to transition into much more of a "doing" industry.

Chris.


From: Alex_Zhang [mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com]
Sent: Monday, October 19, 2015 2:31 PM
To: 'Chris Donley'; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ'; 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T'; Luke, Chris; 'advisory-group'
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] SDN/NFV World Congress

I also feel that the hallway conversations, dinner meetings appear to be more useful...
One thought is that if ODL could do more "marketing"  on how ODL helps with the actual operators solutions (like Neela showed on Friday in his keynote), or just some specific technology solutions, that would attract more traffic. Maybe we just get used to that ODL could do anything...but others may not know it, and many are typically seeking for something that tends to be specific.

Alex

From: Chris Donley [mailto:C.Donley at cablelabs.com]
Sent: Monday, October 19, 2015 8:18 AM
To: PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>>; CHIOSI, MARGARET T <mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>>; Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com<mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com>>; 'advisory-group' <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] SDN/NFV World Congress

There were about 8 people in the audience for the ODL summit, 25 for MEF, and 100 +/- for OPNFV.  Too many concurrent sessions, and as Pedro mentioned, mostly high-level. That said, the hallway conversations and dinner meetings were useful.

Chris

subject: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call
message_text:
All,

Colin and I have been discussing the upcoming Boron release. The TSC would like to seek our input on the release, and in particular what's "most missing" from the current plans so I have invited Colin, at the next call, to present us with the plans such as they may currently be and then we can provide feedback, either/both in the remainder of the call or on this list.

For some background material, here's some details Colin shared with me.

Release topics were on the last TSC agenda: https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/TSC:Main#Agenda

Mostly, these items are not project-specific, but more about how we can fix some issues we've had in past releases, including:

* doing a release faster than 6 months?
* allow for compatibility between releases, e.g., "apps" in the Boron release should be able to run on Beryllium
* provide support for programmatic upgrades, e.g., no or minimal human effort to upgrade from Beryllium to Boron
* support for continuous release for individual projects

Naturally, the TSC has already heard about the importance of documentation and compatibility in future releases, so we don't need to focus on those too much.

Cheers,
Chris.

De: <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>> en nombre de "Luke, Chris" <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>
Fecha: martes, 20 de octubre de 2015, 16:21
Para: 'advisory-group' <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Asunto: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call

All,

Colin and I have been discussing the upcoming Boron release. The TSC would like to seek our input on the release, and in particular what?s ?most missing? from the current plans so I have invited Colin, at the next call, to present us with the plans such as they may currently be and then we can provide feedback, either/both in the remainder of the call or on this list.

For some background material, here?s some details Colin shared with me.

Release topics were on the last TSC agenda: https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/TSC:Main#Agenda

Mostly, these items are not project-specific, but more about how we can fix some issues we've had in past releases, including:

* doing a release faster than 6 months?

IMvHO that would give an impression of lack of stability and may deter a couple of users in the ?corporate spectrum?.

* allow for compatibility between releases, e.g., "apps" in the Boron release should be able to run on Beryllium

Backwards compatibility would be a more than nice to have feature. The other way round may create confusion.

* provide support for programmatic upgrades, e.g., no or minimal human effort to upgrade from Beryllium to Boron

1++ This is an absolute MUST. I would really pay attention to the cases where it is not possible to have a zero-effort upgrade and make sure that the platform provides clear information on what steps to follow to fix incompatibilities. That is not typically the case in a stack trace :-)

* support for continuous release for individual projects

Naturally, the TSC has already heard about the importance of documentation and compatibility in future releases, so we don?t need to focus on those too much.

Cheers,
Chris.

In addition, here is some food for thought for the core team:

There is something that is bugging me. Imagine I have two applications running independently on top of the SAL. These two applications, at a given point in time, send commands towards one and the same network element and these commands happen to be contradictory: like activate and shut down an interface or forward and drop a packet, etc. How should ODL handle this situations to produce a predictable and reproduce-able behaviour?

Best, /PA

---

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Advisors,

We have another query from the TSC; please see section 4 of the page Colin links below.

The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle devices that don?t conform to ODL?s interpretation of how NETCONF works. At the moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices that have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the XML a device returns doesn?t parse according to a YANG model defined for it.

Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF; this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a RESTCONF client towards a device when trying to configure it.

Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.

Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal with this issue?

Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning; there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to correct broken implementations. To steal Colin?s comment though: We shouldn?t unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.

Cheers,
Chris.

https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-meeting/2015/md_sal_interest_call/opendaylight-meeting-md_sal_interest_call.2015-10-20-16.04.html
The bulk of the call was spend discussing when and how it makes sense to mount and allow access to a NETCONF device if it does not conform to the NETCONF spec or at least OpenDaylight's interpretation of it.

--Colin

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core
message_text:
So summarizing, and adding my comments:


-          Core is only a functional state; it labels items critical to the system, upon which other key features depend. Care must be taken to not make 'core' a subjective label.

-          Mature and stable are quality labels; even though we can discern more than one such state, end-users really only care about a label that gives them confidence that the system will work as expected. This end-user expectation may vary and that is where the difference between stable and mature comes in. (stable may be good enough for the lab; mature required for production, for example)

-          There is a loose relationship between functional states and quality states; though arguably a core project needs to be stable/mature in order for dependent projects to also be stable/mature.

Is this a fair summary?

Cheers,
Chris.

To: 'Luke, Chris'; 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T'; 'advisory-group'
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core

Yes, busy in Dusselfdorf with WIFI hunt....

"mature", "stable" are quality state. Whether we have one or two depends on what we can really accomplish when "enforce" each of the state.  I prefer to have just one state here from use end.

I think "core" belongs to functionality categorization.  It should be clearly separated from quality state.  I'm interested to know how would we determine and mark "core".  Keep in mind one "core" to someone may not be "core" to other.

Alex

From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mailto:mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 11:52
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; advisory-group <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Mature vs. Core

I think core means it is mandatory to the platform vs optional. That is different from stable.
Stable is a criteria for maturity - so maybe we just merge to one term and list all the characteristics - stable and mature definitions combine and pick one as the category/stage.
Then Core features progress to different development stages which eventually get to stable/mature.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
Sent: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 10:23 AM
To: advisory-group
Subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core

The TSC has had a brief discussion after our comments last week and they are seeking some clarity between "core" and "mature", since we added the concept of "stable" in our response.

The thread is here: https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-October/003983.html

The summary is (paraphrasing both Colin and Ed):

                Given that we currently have two lifecycle states, "mature" and "core", what do we want "mature" to mean and what do we want "core" to mean?
Do we envisage a third pre-requisite state called "stable"?

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Hi Chris -
Trying to dissect the issue -
Is the issue actually NETCONF ?  IE, the transport protocol itself isn't working properly with some device implementations? Or is it that the device is not compliant with its own advertised YANG schema definition in terms of the returned XML following a NETCONF call (eg GET-CONFIG).
Sounded like the latter?
At TR we're likely to be heavy users of the netconf southbound - If NETCONF is ok but but the advertised YANG is outside of the expected schema spec in some way I'd like options to deal with it upstream of the controller
rather than it failing at the controller.  Being able to switch the controller into a 'loose' vs 'strict' mode of operation would be nice, on a per-model basis. That way we can test and potentially troubleshoot issues in loose mode and feedback to vendors if their device is misbehaving with our upstream application, or even trap and deal with exception within the upstream app (depends on the schema violation - some may not be that critical to the app in question).

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Luke, Chris [Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: 22 October 2015 16:46
To: 'advisory-group'
Subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Advisors,

We have another query from the TSC; please see section 4 of the page Colin links below.

The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle devices that don?t conform to ODL?s interpretation of how NETCONF works. At the moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices that have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the XML a device returns doesn?t parse according to a YANG model defined for it.

Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF; this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a RESTCONF client towards a device when trying to configure it.

Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.

Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal with this issue?

Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning; there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to correct broken implementations. To steal Colin?s comment though: We shouldn?t unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
I didn?t see a clear distinction in the notes between the two issues: NETCONF protocol issues and XML-schema-conformance issues, but I am seeing hints of both.

Either way, assuming the violations are not structurally ambiguous, I feel that being able to be tolerant of such issues is important; but we should have the option of being pedantic. To dissuade vendors from insisting we always operate in the relaxed mode, perhaps call the option ?this-vendors-implementation-is-horribly-broken?. :)

I?m not keen on pass-through though. I think ODL?s northbound should always be well-behaved. If the data cannot be parsed with a liberally tolerant parser, it?s bad data.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
>From Brian Freeman:
We need a looser version that allows us to work with devices that support netconf but don't have yang models for instance.

It may need to be a different interface - one where the app is responsible for crafting the payload but ODL  puts the xml return into a XML tree as a blob and the app has to xpath into the tree or something like that (hand waving).

NetConf-Lite which would be a separate mount type that would allow us to work with vendor equipment that isn't fully netconf + yang  compatible.
Even Cisco has netconf interfaces without the corresponding YANG models. We know this from the vRR interface.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 9:59 AM
To: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

I didn't see a clear distinction in the notes between the two issues: NETCONF protocol issues and XML-schema-conformance issues, but I am seeing hints of both.

Either way, assuming the violations are not structurally ambiguous, I feel that being able to be tolerant of such issues is important; but we should have the option of being pedantic. To dissuade vendors from insisting we always operate in the relaxed mode, perhaps call the option "this-vendors-implementation-is-horribly-broken". :)

I'm not keen on pass-through though. I think ODL's northbound should always be well-behaved. If the data cannot be parsed with a liberally tolerant parser, it's bad data.

Chris.

From: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com> [mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 06:14
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Hi Chris -
Trying to dissect the issue -
Is the issue actually NETCONF ?  IE, the transport protocol itself isn't working properly with some device implementations? Or is it that the device is not compliant with its own advertised YANG schema definition in terms of the returned XML following a NETCONF call (eg GET-CONFIG).
Sounded like the latter?
At TR we're likely to be heavy users of the netconf southbound - If NETCONF is ok but but the advertised YANG is outside of the expected schema spec in some way I'd like options to deal with it upstream of the controller
rather than it failing at the controller.  Being able to switch the controller into a 'loose' vs 'strict' mode of operation would be nice, on a per-model basis. That way we can test and potentially troubleshoot issues in loose mode and feedback to vendors if their device is misbehaving with our upstream application, or even trap and deal with exception within the upstream app (depends on the schema violation - some may not be that critical to the app in question).

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Luke, Chris [Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: 22 October 2015 16:46
To: 'advisory-group'
Subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
Advisors,

We have another query from the TSC; please see section 4 of the page Colin links below.

The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle devices that don't conform to ODL's interpretation of how NETCONF works. At the moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices that have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the XML a device returns doesn't parse according to a YANG model defined for it.

Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF; this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a RESTCONF client towards a device when trying to configure it.

Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin calls this a "sloppy mount"). There was some disagreement on whether specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.

Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal with this issue?

Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for known bad (or "in development") devices, though it needs a health warning; there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to correct broken implementations. To steal Colin's comment though: We shouldn't unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it?s unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target - but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3.... Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623

subject: [advisory-group] SDN/NFV World Congress
message_text:
Hi,

Last year, ODL was the only open source controller in town. Now,
especially with OPNFV and ONOS, there is a lot more dissipation of
attention.

I think that one room covering OPNFV, ONOS, ODL would be a better draw
next year - two high-impact ODL presentations would be better than a
full day of poorly attended ones.

Thanks,
Dave.

subject: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call
message_text:
For what it's worth, dealing with conflicting commands being sent to
devices is something we're aware of and thinking about. We've been making a
lot of progress on the topic in a specific domain around OpenFlow and
multiple apps controlling vSwitches when there is a combination
applications attempting to provide network virtualization and service
chaining.

The ideas we've been developing and some of the code we've started writing
could be generalized, but it's not a panacea. We'd probably need to know
what protocols you were interested in for this. Cross-protocol things are
possible, but much more complex.

I'll add this to the list of things I've heard people asking for.

--Colin

On Tue, Oct 20, 2015 at 10:39 AM, PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ <
pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com> wrote:

> Hi,
>
> Answers inline?

> /PA
> De: <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> en nombre de "Luke,
> Chris" <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>
> Fecha: martes, 20 de octubre de 2015, 16:21
> Para: 'advisory-group' <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
> Asunto: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call
>
> All,
>
>
>
> Colin and I have been discussing the upcoming Boron release. The TSC would
> like to seek our input on the release, and in particular what?s ?most
> missing? from the current plans so I have invited Colin, at the next call,
> to present us with the plans such as they may currently be and then we can
> provide feedback, either/both in the remainder of the call or on this list.
>
>
>
> For some background material, here?s some details Colin shared with me.
>
>
>
> Release topics were on the last TSC agenda:
> https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/TSC:Main#Agenda
>
>
>
> Mostly, these items are not project-specific, but more about how we can
> fix some issues we've had in past releases, including:
>
>
>
> * doing a release faster than 6 months?
>
>
> IMvHO that would give an impression of lack of stability and may deter a
> couple of users in the ?corporate spectrum?.
>
> * allow for compatibility between releases, e.g., "apps" in the Boron
> release should be able to run on Beryllium
>
>
> Backwards compatibility would be a more than nice to have feature. The
> other way round may create confusion.
>
> * provide support for programmatic upgrades, e.g., no or minimal human
> effort to upgrade from Beryllium to Boron
>
>
> 1++ This is an absolute MUST. I would really pay attention to the cases
> where it is not possible to have a zero-effort upgrade and make sure that
> the platform provides clear information on what steps to follow to fix
> incompatibilities. That is not typically the case in a stack trace :-)
>
> * support for continuous release for individual projects
>
>
>
> Naturally, the TSC has already heard about the importance of documentation
> and compatibility in future releases, so we don?t need to focus on those
> too much.
>
>
>
> Cheers,
>
> Chris.
>
>
> In addition, here is some food for thought for the core team:
>
> There is something that is bugging me. Imagine I have two applications
> running independently on top of the SAL. These two applications, at a given
> point in time, send commands towards one and the same network element and
> these commands happen to be contradictory: like activate and shut down an
> interface or forward and drop a packet, etc. How should ODL handle this
> situations to produce a predictable and reproduce-able behaviour?
>
> Best, /PA
>

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core
message_text:
+1

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Thursday, October 22, 2015 12:00 PM
To: Williamson, Beau; Alex_Zhang; CHIOSI, MARGARET T; 'advisory-group'
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core

So summarizing, and adding my comments:


-          Core is only a functional state; it labels items critical to the system, upon which other key features depend. Care must be taken to not make 'core' a subjective label.

-          Mature and stable are quality labels; even though we can discern more than one such state, end-users really only care about a label that gives them confidence that the system will work as expected. This end-user expectation may vary and that is where the difference between stable and mature comes in. (stable may be good enough for the lab; mature required for production, for example)

-          There is a loose relationship between functional states and quality states; though arguably a core project needs to be stable/mature in order for dependent projects to also be stable/mature.

Is this a fair summary?

Cheers,
Chris.

Yes, busy in Dusselfdorf with WIFI hunt....

"mature", "stable" are quality state. Whether we have one or two depends on what we can really accomplish when "enforce" each of the state.  I prefer to have just one state here from use end.

I think "core" belongs to functionality categorization.  It should be clearly separated from quality state.  I'm interested to know how would we determine and mark "core".  Keep in mind one "core" to someone may not be "core" to other.

Alex

Subject: RE: TSC query: Mature vs. Core

I think core means it is mandatory to the platform vs optional. That is different from stable.
Stable is a criteria for maturity - so maybe we just merge to one term and list all the characteristics - stable and mature definitions combine and pick one as the category/stage.
Then Core features progress to different development stages which eventually get to stable/mature.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris

Subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core

The TSC has had a brief discussion after our comments last week and they are seeking some clarity between "core" and "mature", since we added the concept of "stable" in our response.

The thread is here: https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-October/003983.html

The summary is (paraphrasing both Colin and Ed):

                Given that we currently have two lifecycle states, "mature" and "core", what do we want "mature" to mean and what do we want "core" to mean?
Do we envisage a third pre-requisite state called "stable"?

Chris.
