+1

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Thursday, October 22, 2015 12:00 PM
To: Williamson, Beau; Alex_Zhang; CHIOSI, MARGARET T; 'advisory-group'
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] TSC query: Mature vs. Core

So summarizing, and adding my comments:


-          Core is only a functional state; it labels items critical to the system, upon which other key features depend. Care must be taken to not make ?core? a subjective label.

-          Mature and stable are quality labels; even though we can discern more than one such state, end-users really only care about a label that gives them confidence that the system will work as expected. This end-user expectation may vary and that is where the difference between stable and mature comes in. (stable may be good enough for the lab; mature required for production, for example)

-          There is a loose relationship between functional states and quality states; though arguably a core project needs to be stable/mature in order for dependent projects to also be stable/mature.

Is this a fair summary?

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
Hi Colin,

Thanks for the reality check. We have been also doing some research on that and this is our current take too: could be something you might want to do in a specific domain (and OF is a good candidate, while netconf might no because it?s more difficult to extract meta-information about the clash there) while going cross technology/domain/protocol is extremely complex.

Best, /PA
De: Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com<mailto:colin at colindixon.com>>
Fecha: viernes, 23 de octubre de 2015, 21:30
Para: paag <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>>
CC: "Luke, Chris" <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>, advisory-group <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Asunto: Re: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call

For what it's worth, dealing with conflicting commands being sent to devices is something we're aware of and thinking about. We've been making a lot of progress on the topic in a specific domain around OpenFlow and multiple apps controlling vSwitches when there is a combination applications attempting to provide network virtualization and service chaining.

The ideas we've been developing and some of the code we've started writing could be generalized, but it's not a panacea. We'd probably need to know what protocols you were interested in for this. Cross-protocol things are possible, but much more complex.

I'll add this to the list of things I've heard people asking for.

--Colin

On Tue, Oct 20, 2015 at 10:39 AM, PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>> wrote:

Hope not to introduce too much noise,
/PA
De: <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>> en nombre de "Luke, Chris" <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>
Fecha: martes, 20 de octubre de 2015, 16:21
Para: 'advisory-group' <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Asunto: [advisory-group] Agenda for Thursdays AG call

All,

Colin and I have been discussing the upcoming Boron release. The TSC would like to seek our input on the release, and in particular what?s ?most missing? from the current plans so I have invited Colin, at the next call, to present us with the plans such as they may currently be and then we can provide feedback, either/both in the remainder of the call or on this list.

For some background material, here?s some details Colin shared with me.

Release topics were on the last TSC agenda: https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/TSC:Main#Agenda

Mostly, these items are not project-specific, but more about how we can fix some issues we've had in past releases, including:

* doing a release faster than 6 months?

IMvHO that would give an impression of lack of stability and may deter a couple of users in the ?corporate spectrum?.

* allow for compatibility between releases, e.g., "apps" in the Boron release should be able to run on Beryllium

Backwards compatibility would be a more than nice to have feature. The other way round may create confusion.

* provide support for programmatic upgrades, e.g., no or minimal human effort to upgrade from Beryllium to Boron

1++ This is an absolute MUST. I would really pay attention to the cases where it is not possible to have a zero-effort upgrade and make sure that the platform provides clear information on what steps to follow to fix incompatibilities. That is not typically the case in a stack trace :-)

* support for continuous release for individual projects

Naturally, the TSC has already heard about the importance of documentation and compatibility in future releases, so we don?t need to focus on those too much.

Cheers,
Chris.

In addition, here is some food for thought for the core team:

There is something that is bugging me. Imagine I have two applications running independently on top of the SAL. These two applications, at a given point in time, send commands towards one and the same network element and these commands happen to be contradictory: like activate and shut down an interface or forward and drop a packet, etc. How should ODL handle this situations to produce a predictable and reproduce-able behaviour?

Best, /PA

---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

Network Innovation & Virtualisation

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
If I understand things correctly, commercial products like Tail-F have developed NED's (Network Element Drivers) that are non-NETCONF/YANG based and instead use CLI to interface to devices that are not (yet) NETCONF/YANG compliant or where the customer is still running an old OS version that is in the same boat.

Have we considered some projects to do the same?  I think the goal is to be able to have ODL cover all devices in the network despite their lack of NETCONF/YANG support.  I know we are in this boat which is why Tail-F looks so attractive to TMO.

Beau Williamson
CCIE #1346 R/S Emeritus
Principle Member of Technical Staff
Corporate Engineering
metroPCS/T-Mobile
Internal: 314982
Office:   469.330.4982
Mobile:   972.679.4334

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 11:12 AM
To: mc3124 at att.com; Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: 23 October 2015 15:19
To: Luke, Chris; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target - but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3.... Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:11 AM
To: CHIOSI, MARGARET T; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it's unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.


From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mailto:mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:07
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
More correctly, for legacy devices the NED defines a YANG model to describe the CLI; the remainder of the NED provides a mechanism to talk to that device. This hits issues when there are inconsistencies between versions of the CLI, for example.

Chris.

To: mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: 23 October 2015 15:19
To: Luke, Chris; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target - but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3.... Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:11 AM
To: CHIOSI, MARGARET T; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it's unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.


From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mailto:mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:07
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Yep, handling CLI is really hard  - the NEDs do it fairly well but not perfectly in all cases out-of-the-box.  The most complexity occurs where services are changed in a subtle way and the ordering of the CLI commands is important - eg changing the RD of a vrf on a Cisco device.  Short story is that the complexity of the CLI NEDs is the thorn in Tail-F's side, they'd rather not be managing them. Tough project for anyone to take on in ODL.
Other thing TailF does well is transactions, network-wide.  That to me would be really cool to have in ODL.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: Luke, Chris [Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: 26 October 2015 14:28
To: Williamson, Beau; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); mc3124 at att.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

More correctly, for legacy devices the NED defines a YANG model to describe the CLI; the remainder of the NED provides a mechanism to talk to that device. This hits issues when there are inconsistencies between versions of the CLI, for example.

Chris.

From: Williamson, Beau [mailto:Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 10:26 AM
To: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com; mc3124 at att.com; Luke, Chris; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

If I understand things correctly, commercial products like Tail-F have developed NED's (Network Element Drivers) that are non-NETCONF/YANG based and instead use CLI to interface to devices that are not (yet) NETCONF/YANG compliant or where the customer is still running an old OS version that is in the same boat.

Have we considered some projects to do the same?  I think the goal is to be able to have ODL cover all devices in the network despite their lack of NETCONF/YANG support.  I know we are in this boat which is why Tail-F looks so attractive to TMO.

Beau Williamson

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Yes, I've been meaning to mention this.  Network-wide transactions seems to be begging for an ODL project.

Also, I know that CLI stuff is really a PITA but I keep hoping that since this is an open source community that someone might contribute some CLI NED's for some common boxes.  Example, unless you upgrade to the more recent versions of SRX in you ALU routers, you are stuck with CLI-based NEDs.  Given ALU's already complex Service provisioning model (my opinion), this makes lack of NETCONF/YANG a PITA.

Beau Williamson

message_text:
Hi,

I figured it'd perhaps be polite to introduce myself before posting to this group. I am Johan Gustawsson, SDN&NFV Network Architect at TeliaSonera Group. I think Todd will upload a bio to the AG page shortly.
Anyhow, I am really excited to be a part of this group and hope to contribute with our experiences and ongoing work involving ODL.

I also think the needed polishing of CLI NEDs to make poorly written operating systems work in every situation and version is a different (and never-ending) story.
Although I like what Tail-F does apart from the caveats already mentioned in this thread - Network-wide transactions in ODL is something we'd welcome and be happy to contribute to.

Best Regards,
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Johan Gustawsson, CCIE SP #48292

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
We basically have been telling vendors for future releases (SW/HW) that they must migrate to Netconf and provide YANG models for their equipment.
At least it forces the vendors to have to go through our grilling exceptions process of why they can't get to netconf.
We then use Tail-F for the CLI ones as an ODL intelligent adapter.

Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Yep, handling CLI is really hard  - the NEDs do it fairly well but not perfectly in all cases out-of-the-box.  The most complexity occurs where services are changed in a subtle way and the ordering of the CLI commands is important - eg changing the RD of a vrf on a Cisco device.  Short story is that the complexity of the CLI NEDs is the thorn in Tail-F's side, they'd rather not be managing them. Tough project for anyone to take on in ODL.
Other thing TailF does well is transactions, network-wide.  That to me would be really cool to have in ODL.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: Luke, Chris [Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: 26 October 2015 14:28
To: Williamson, Beau; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
More correctly, for legacy devices the NED defines a YANG model to describe the CLI; the remainder of the NED provides a mechanism to talk to that device. This hits issues when there are inconsistencies between versions of the CLI, for example.

Chris.

From: Williamson, Beau [mailto:Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 10:26 AM
To: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Luke, Chris; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

If I understand things correctly, commercial products like Tail-F have developed NED's (Network Element Drivers) that are non-NETCONF/YANG based and instead use CLI to interface to devices that are not (yet) NETCONF/YANG compliant or where the customer is still running an old OS version that is in the same boat.

Have we considered some projects to do the same?  I think the goal is to be able to have ODL cover all devices in the network despite their lack of NETCONF/YANG support.  I know we are in this boat which is why Tail-F looks so attractive to TMO.

Beau Williamson
CCIE #1346 R/S Emeritus
Principle Member of Technical Staff
Corporate Engineering
metroPCS/T-Mobile
Internal: 314982
Office:   469.330.4982
Mobile:   972.679.4334

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 11:12 AM
To: mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623
________________________________
From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: 23 October 2015 15:19
To: Luke, Chris; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target - but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3.... Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:11 AM
To: CHIOSI, MARGARET T; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it's unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.

We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Apologies for the delay in summarizing this, but here's what I got from this:

* Distinguish between NETCONF protocol issues and YANG schema conformance in the payload.
* Loose mode for both is strongly desirable.
* Especially to support devices that may not yet have a model, or it's known to be incomplete.
* For schema conformance loose mode, consider making it a per-model tweak.
* Loose mode should only apply when violations are not structurally ambiguous. Data that cannot be deserialized by a reasonably tolerant parser should always be rejected.
* ODL northbound should always be well behaved; passthrough must be carefully considered, possibly with a separate endpoint (to make its use explicit in apps)

Anything else?

Chris.

We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

> I didn?t see a clear distinction in the notes between the two issues:
> NETCONF protocol issues and XML-schema-conformance issues, but I am seeing
> hints of both.
>
>
>
> Either way, assuming the violations are not structurally ambiguous, I feel
> that being able to be tolerant of such issues is important; but we should
> have the option of being pedantic. To dissuade vendors from insisting we

> ?this-vendors-implementation-is-horribly-broken?. :)
>

> always be well-behaved. If the data cannot be parsed with a liberally

> mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com

> *To:* Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>;
> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> *Subject:* RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
>
>
>
> Hi Chris -
>
> Trying to dissect the issue -
>
> Is the issue actually NETCONF ?  IE, the transport protocol itself isn't
> working properly with some device implementations? Or is it that the device
> is not compliant with its own advertised YANG schema definition in terms of
> the returned XML following a NETCONF call (eg GET-CONFIG).
>
> Sounded like the latter?
> At TR we're likely to be heavy users of the netconf southbound - If
> NETCONF is ok but but the advertised YANG is outside of the expected schema
> spec in some way I'd like options to deal with it upstream of the controller
>
> rather than it failing at the controller.  Being able to switch the
> controller into a 'loose' vs 'strict' mode of operation would be nice, on a
> per-model basis. That way we can test and potentially troubleshoot issues
> in loose mode and feedback to vendors if their device is misbehaving with
> our upstream application, or even trap and deal with exception within the
> upstream app (depends on the schema violation - some may not be that
> critical to the app in question).
>
>
>
> *Jon Beasley*
> Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
>
> *Thomson Reuters*
>
> Phone: 0207 542 6674
>
> Mobile 07920 230623
> ------------------------------
>
> *From:* advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [
> advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Luke, Chris [
> Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
> *Sent:* 22 October 2015 16:46
> *To:* 'advisory-group'
> *Subject:* [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
>
> Advisors,
>
>
>
> We have another query from the TSC; please see section 4 of the page Colin
> links below.
>
>
>
> The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle devices
> that don?t conform to ODL?s interpretation of how NETCONF works. At the
> moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices that
> have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the XML a
> device returns doesn?t parse according to a YANG model defined for it.
>
>
>
> Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and
> (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF;
> this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if
> RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a RESTCONF
> client towards a device when trying to configure it.
>
>
>
> Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin
> calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether
> specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the
> violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.
>
>
>
> Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal with
> this issue?
>
>
>
> Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for
> known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning;
> there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to correct
> broken implementations. To steal Colin?s comment though: We shouldn?t
> unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.
>
>
>
> Cheers,
>
> Chris.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

Le 5 nov. 2015 ? 20:47, Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com<mailto:colin at colindixon.com>> a ?crit :

This is a great summary, one question inline.

--Colin

On Thu, Nov 5, 2015 at 1:25 PM, Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>> wrote:
Apologies for the delay in summarizing this, but here?s what I got from this:

* Distinguish between NETCONF protocol issues and YANG schema conformance in the payload.
* Loose mode for both is strongly desirable.
* Especially to support devices that may not yet have a model, or it's known to be incomplete.
* For schema conformance loose mode, consider making it a per-model tweak.
* Loose mode should only apply when violations are not structurally ambiguous. Data that cannot be deserialized by a reasonably tolerant parser should always be rejected.

I'm curious if this means that you'd like to see an entire query rejected because a mandatory integer field contained "fred" or if you'd like to be able to get the rest of the data.

* ODL northbound should always be well behaved; passthrough must be carefully considered, possibly with a separate endpoint (to make its use explicit in apps)

Anything else?

Chris.

inline responses, sigh.

There are solutions to that... :-P

the yang ? if loose, then yes, ignore type issues; whereas that line was I
think talking more about unbalanced nesting and whatnot (structurally bad
XML).
>
>
>
> Do I need to make the summary clearer on this? Does it make sense?

That makes sense. I think it might behoove us to be clear as I think the
underlying question was when and if it's OK for the NETCONF plugin to drop
information on the floor because of violations (real or perceived) of the
NETCONF protocol or provided YANG schemas. The current prevailing opinion
of the most involved engineers angles toward being more strict. Along those
lines, if our users have a different opinion, it would be food to make that
clear.

transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG
will happen over time.

client towards a device when trying to configure it.

calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether
specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the
violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.

>>

with this issue?

known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning;
there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to correct

unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.

>>

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Updated summary:

* Distinguish between NETCONF protocol issues and YANG schema conformance in the payload.
* Loose mode for both is strongly desirable.
* Especially to support devices that may not yet have a model, or it's known to be incomplete.
* For schema conformance loose mode, consider making it a per-model tweak.
* Loose mode should only apply when violations are not structurally ambiguous. Data that cannot be deserialized by a reasonably tolerant parser should always be rejected. This means bad XML (syntactically broken - unbalanced nesting, missing >'s and so on) should probably not be accepted, but semantic issues (not passing yang schema checks, like elements not passing type tests or whole data structures not being defined in the schema at all) should be tolerable. Likewise NETCONF transport issues that are not ambiguous should be tolerable too.
* ODL northbound should always be well behaved; passthrough must be carefully considered, possibly with a separate endpoint (to make its use explicit in apps)
* Expect end users to come up with esoteric conditions down the road; when stuff is in production things need to work, even if it's sometimes kludgy. Especially during the next few years with much legacy equipment deployed the need for tolerance in protocols is that bit greater.

Any tweaks, anyone? :)

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
1. un-parseable payload should be rejected but we need to have loose enforcement of the parsing rules. This lets us deal with valid xml that doesn?t have the niceties of a specific namespace for every tag vs inferred namespace, etc.
2. pushing data is easier since we will have a payload from the vendor of the xml that is to be pushed in edit-config
3. pulling data (get-config) is harder because ODL needs to know what to do with data that does not have a matching yang model.
	a. I would think something like anyxml could be used to let the application do the mapping.
	b. It would be nicer for the service provider/application to provide a mapping file from the xml xpath A to yang datapath B but maybe that ends up being just as much work as having the vendor provide a yang model.
	c. I would be happy with the netconf-lite adaptor providing a pointer to "this is the result of get-config" . the application could parse it using your standard XML tools and we can do the mapping in our application.
	d. netconf-lite assumes that application does the xml input and xml parsing as step 1.
	e. options on top of netconf-lite would provide xml parsing to a generic set of leafs into md-sal of a get-config (but not sure how hard/easy that is)


-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris
Sent: Friday, November 06, 2015 8:13 AM
To: Colin Dixon
Cc: advisory-group
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Updated summary:

* Distinguish between NETCONF protocol issues and YANG schema conformance in the payload.
* Loose mode for both is strongly desirable.
* Especially to support devices that may not yet have a model, or it's known to be incomplete.
* For schema conformance loose mode, consider making it a per-model tweak.
* Loose mode should only apply when violations are not structurally ambiguous. Data that cannot be deserialized by a reasonably tolerant parser should always be rejected. This means bad XML (syntactically broken - unbalanced nesting, missing >'s and so on) should probably not be accepted, but semantic issues (not passing yang schema checks, like elements not passing type tests or whole data structures not being defined in the schema at all) should be tolerable. Likewise NETCONF transport issues that are not ambiguous should be tolerable too.
* ODL northbound should always be well behaved; passthrough must be carefully considered, possibly with a separate endpoint (to make its use explicit in apps)
* Expect end users to come up with esoteric conditions down the road; when stuff is in production things need to work, even if it's sometimes kludgy. Especially during the next few years with much legacy equipment deployed the need for tolerance in protocols is that bit greater.

Any tweaks, anyone? :)

Chris.

> >> The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle
> devices that don?t conform to ODL?s interpretation of how NETCONF works.
> At the moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices
> that have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the
> XML a device returns doesn?t parse according to a YANG model defined for it.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and
> (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF;
> this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if
> RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a
> RESTCONF client towards a device when trying to configure it.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin
> calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether
> specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the
> violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal
> with this issue?
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for
> known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning;
> there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to
> correct broken implementations. To steal Colin?s comment though: We
> shouldn?t unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> Cheers,
> >>

Asunto: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

We basically have been telling vendors for future releases (SW/HW) that they must migrate to Netconf and provide YANG models for their equipment.
At least it forces the vendors to have to go through our grilling exceptions process of why they can?t get to netconf.
We then use Tail-F for the CLI ones as an ODL intelligent adapter.

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Yes, I've been meaning to mention this.  Network-wide transactions seems to be begging for an ODL project.

Also, I know that CLI stuff is really a PITA but I keep hoping that since this is an open source community that someone might contribute some CLI NED's for some common boxes.  Example, unless you upgrade to the more recent versions of SRX in you ALU routers, you are stuck with CLI-based NEDs.  Given ALU's already complex Service provisioning model (my opinion), this makes lack of NETCONF/YANG a PITA.

From:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com> [mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 9:40 AM
To: Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; Williamson, Beau; mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Yep, handling CLI is really hard  - the NEDs do it fairly well but not perfectly in all cases out-of-the-box.  The most complexity occurs where services are changed in a subtle way and the ordering of the CLI commands is important - eg changing the RD of a vrf on a Cisco device.  Short story is that the complexity of the CLI NEDs is the thorn in Tail-F's side, they'd rather not be managing them. Tough project for anyone to take on in ODL.
Other thing TailF does well is transactions, network-wide.  That to me would be really cool to have in ODL.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters

To: Williamson, Beau; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
More correctly, for legacy devices the NED defines a YANG model to describe the CLI; the remainder of the NED provides a mechanism to talk to that device. This hits issues when there are inconsistencies between versions of the CLI, for example.

Chris.

From: Williamson, Beau [mailto:Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 10:26 AM
To: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Luke, Chris; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

If I understand things correctly, commercial products like Tail-F have developed NED's (Network Element Drivers) that are non-NETCONF/YANG based and instead use CLI to interface to devices that are not (yet) NETCONF/YANG compliant or where the customer is still running an old OS version that is in the same boat.

Have we considered some projects to do the same?  I think the goal is to be able to have ODL cover all devices in the network despite their lack of NETCONF/YANG support.  I know we are in this boat which is why Tail-F looks so attractive to TMO.

Beau Williamson
CCIE #1346 R/S Emeritus

Corporate Engineering
metroPCS/T-Mobile

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters

Mobile 07920 230623

Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target ? but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3?. Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:11 AM
To: CHIOSI, MARGARET T; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it?s unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mc3124 at att.com]
Sent: 06 November 2015 17:46
To: Luke, Chris; Colin Dixon
Cc: advisory-group
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

1. un-parseable payload should be rejected but we need to have loose enforcement of the parsing rules. This lets us deal with valid xml that doesn?t have the niceties of a specific namespace for every tag vs inferred namespace, etc.

2. pushing data is easier since we will have a payload from the vendor of the xml that is to be pushed in edit-config

3. pulling data (get-config) is harder because ODL needs to know what to do with data that does not have a matching yang model.

        a. I would think something like anyxml could be used to let the application do the mapping.

        b. It would be nicer for the service provider/application to provide a mapping file from the xml xpath A to yang datapath B but maybe that ends up being just as much work as having the vendor provide a yang model.

        c. I would be happy with the netconf-lite adaptor providing a pointer to "this is the result of get-config" . the application could parse it using your standard XML tools and we can do the mapping in our application.

        d. netconf-lite assumes that application does the xml input and xml parsing as step 1.

        e. options on top of netconf-lite would provide xml parsing to a generic set of leafs into md-sal of a get-config (but not sure how hard/easy that is)





-----Original Message-----

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris

Sent: Friday, November 06, 2015 8:13 AM

To: Colin Dixon

Cc: advisory-group

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF



Updated summary:



* Distinguish between NETCONF protocol issues and YANG schema conformance in the payload.

* Loose mode for both is strongly desirable.

* Especially to support devices that may not yet have a model, or it's known to be incomplete.

* For schema conformance loose mode, consider making it a per-model tweak.

* Loose mode should only apply when violations are not structurally ambiguous. Data that cannot be deserialized by a reasonably tolerant parser should always be rejected. This means bad XML (syntactically broken - unbalanced nesting, missing >'s and so on) should probably not be accepted, but semantic issues (not passing yang schema checks, like elements not passing type tests or whole data structures not being defined in the schema at all) should be tolerable. Likewise NETCONF transport issues that are not ambiguous should be tolerable too.

* ODL northbound should always be well behaved; passthrough must be carefully considered, possibly with a separate endpoint (to make its use explicit in apps)

* Expect end users to come up with esoteric conditions down the road; when stuff is in production things need to work, even if it's sometimes kludgy. Especially during the next few years with much legacy equipment deployed the need for tolerance in protocols is that bit greater.



Any tweaks, anyone? :)



Chris.

> >> Trying to dissect the issue -

> >> Is the issue actually NETCONF ?  IE, the transport protocol itself isn't

> is not compliant with its own advertised YANG schema definition in terms of

> controller

> into a 'loose' vs 'strict' mode of operation would be nice, on a per-model

> basis. That way we can test and potentially troubleshoot issues in loose

> mode and feedback to vendors if their device is misbehaving with our

> upstream application, or even trap and deal with exception within the

> upstream app (depends on the schema violation - some may not be that

> >> Advisors,

> >>

> >>

> >> We have another query from the TSC; please see section 4 of the page

> Colin links below.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> The summary is that there was a discussion regarding how to handle

> devices that don?t conform to ODL?s interpretation of how NETCONF works.

> At the moment it requires strict conformance and refuses to mount devices

> that have any sort of protocol flaw and presumably throws a tantrum if the

> XML a device returns doesn?t parse according to a YANG model defined for it.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> Pass-through is suggested; that protocol errors are ignored and

> (optionally?) any errant XML payload is simply passed through to RESTCONF;

> this has several issues, including when the caller asks for JSON, and if

> RESTCONF should be expected to accept similarly flawed XML from a

> RESTCONF client towards a device when trying to configure it.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> Another approach might be to be relaxed about various violations (Colin

> calls this a ?sloppy mount?). There was some disagreement on whether

> specific violations should be tracked; presumably either by logging the

> violation, or making them available to RESTCONF callers.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> Anyway, what do we think? Do we have any specific suggestions to deal

> with this issue?

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> Personally I think we definitely need to be able to relax the rules for

> known bad (or ?in development?) devices, though it needs a health warning;

> there has to be some feedback loop to encourage NETCONF vendors to

> correct broken implementations. To steal Colin?s comment though: We

> shouldn?t unnecessarily punish end users for their vendors poor behavior.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >> Cheers,

> >>

> >> Chris.

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >>

> >>

subject: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
message_text:
Below is the link where you can find the source, the plugin (YangUpdate) as well as documentation on how to install the dependencies as well as the plugin.

https://github.com/att/yang-design-studio

To only install the plugin, please follow the instructions (in the /Docs folder) in sequence as indicated by the file names.
Let me know if you run into any issues.

Regards,

Kevin

Asunto: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

We basically have been telling vendors for future releases (SW/HW) that they must migrate to Netconf and provide YANG models for their equipment.
At least it forces the vendors to have to go through our grilling exceptions process of why they can?t get to netconf.
We then use Tail-F for the CLI ones as an ODL intelligent adapter.

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Yes, I've been meaning to mention this.  Network-wide transactions seems to be begging for an ODL project.

Also, I know that CLI stuff is really a PITA but I keep hoping that since this is an open source community that someone might contribute some CLI NED's for some common boxes.  Example, unless you upgrade to the more recent versions of SRX in you ALU routers, you are stuck with CLI-based NEDs.  Given ALU's already complex Service provisioning model (my opinion), this makes lack of NETCONF/YANG a PITA.

From:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com> [mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 9:40 AM
To: Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; Williamson, Beau; mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Yep, handling CLI is really hard  - the NEDs do it fairly well but not perfectly in all cases out-of-the-box.  The most complexity occurs where services are changed in a subtle way and the ordering of the CLI commands is important - eg changing the RD of a vrf on a Cisco device.  Short story is that the complexity of the CLI NEDs is the thorn in Tail-F's side, they'd rather not be managing them. Tough project for anyone to take on in ODL.
Other thing TailF does well is transactions, network-wide.  That to me would be really cool to have in ODL.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623

From: Luke, Chris [Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>]
Sent: 26 October 2015 14:28
To: Williamson, Beau; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
More correctly, for legacy devices the NED defines a YANG model to describe the CLI; the remainder of the NED provides a mechanism to talk to that device. This hits issues when there are inconsistencies between versions of the CLI, for example.

Chris.

From: Williamson, Beau [mailto:Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com]
Sent: Monday, October 26, 2015 10:26 AM
To: jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Luke, Chris; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

If I understand things correctly, commercial products like Tail-F have developed NED's (Network Element Drivers) that are non-NETCONF/YANG based and instead use CLI to interface to devices that are not (yet) NETCONF/YANG compliant or where the customer is still running an old OS version that is in the same boat.

Have we considered some projects to do the same?  I think the goal is to be able to have ODL cover all devices in the network despite their lack of NETCONF/YANG support.  I know we are in this boat which is why Tail-F looks so attractive to TMO.

Beau Williamson

Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 11:12 AM
To: mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>; Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

Same here I suspect. We'll have a whole bunch of n/w elements which may possibly support Netconf but not the YANG models. We're not going to rip and replace a signficant portion of our network estate to make it work with a controller which demands device YANG schemas, but at the same time we may want to perform service activation consistently through the controller, across a set of devices some of which have a vendor defined YANG schema and others which may only support squirting CLI commands over netconf (ala early Cisco netconf implementations in the ASR9K product range).  The transition of our n/w estate to a set of devices which fully support YANG will happen over time.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623

From: CHIOSI, MARGARET T [mc3124 at att.com<mailto:mc3124 at att.com>]
Sent: 23 October 2015 15:19
To: Luke, Chris; Beasley, Jonathan (Financial&Risk); advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF
We will be at phases. App (VNF) may not give total control to controller. I agree on target ? but question
is do we get to target where controller has all state in 1 step, 2, 3?. Which is why you allow the looser control.
We have this debate internally all the time w/r to getting to target architecture/implementation.

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, October 23, 2015 10:11 AM
To: CHIOSI, MARGARET T; jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: TSC query: Handling of non-conformant NETCONF

In that example, is the controller adding any value? Or is it a glorified connection pooler? The risk is that it forces what I would consider a layer violation: a bunch of state being managed in an app that should be in the controller. But perhaps it?s unavoidable in some cases. Pesky vendors.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Folks: AT&T is finding a lot of bugs in the adapters (e.g. BGP Flowspec) which are pretty fundamental we think.
We have discovered that ODL as a community doesn't necessarily test some of these adapters against real equipment.
Just curious if anyone else has hit the adapter maturity issues and if we as a group should raise this as a higher priority
to the community.
thanks.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Yes we at Caltech have had a similar experience,
including items such as the error counters not
being properly passed on.

I raised this general issue a while ago.
Testing, interaction with vendors and resolution
of issues, and establishment of known
working configurations (switch models and
firmware release, parameter settings etc.)
are important for wide community adoption.
Especially if an ODL  release is to be declared
"production ready"

Harvey


On 11/10/2015 7:09 AM, CHIOSI, MARGARET T wrote:
> Folks: AT&T is finding a lot of bugs in the adapters (e.g. BGP Flowspec) which are pretty fundamental we think.
> We have discovered that ODL as a community doesn't necessarily test some of these adapters against real equipment.
> Just curious if anyone else has hit the adapter maturity issues and if we as a group should raise this as a higher priority
> to the community.
> thanks.

> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/advisory-group

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
I think it will be powerful to say this whole group thinks that interop testing is critical for ODL to gain traction quickly.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Agreed, and we've had sort of the same experiences. However, not with things I would consider to be very fundamental. 

If the priority is to be raised, maybe we have to take part in defining what that means in practice and what we expect (on a lower level than just saying 'we expect it to work')? 
At the other end, are we as end-users doing enough to feed the information back and creating awareness about the specific misbehaviours/bugs? 

Your suggestion for a common statement from this group about the importance of this could be a great next step. 

BR,
Johan Gustawsson

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
This begs the question of does the ODL Development Team have a lab of the key equipment that they need to test against to confirm the adapters are production ready?  I would guess that they do not as some of this equipment (e.g. a Cisco router that runs IOS-XR) could be pretty expensive.

>>community adoption.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
Chris,

Maybe we are not in the position of defining specific interop testing for specific devices. However I would guess that we can voice our concern that there are basic features that don?t work against devices provided by the sponsors of the project. Am I completely unrealistic if I think that they are the first to want their devices working with ODL?

BR,/PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

Technology Exploration -
Network Innovation & Virtualisation
email: pedroa d0t aranda At telefonica d0t com
Telef?nica, Investigaci?n y Desarrollo
C/ Zurbar?n,12
28010 Madrid, Spain

Fragen sind nicht da, um beantwortet zu werden.
Fragen sind da, um gestellt zu werden.
Georg Kreisler

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
That?s totally reasonable.

I think this needs two things.

- As suggested, a statement of our concerns.
- Some sort of appendix that lists some of the areas of particular concern or things we know that need to be tested on real hardware. This could be attached to the statement, or a wiki page that we all pile into or something.

Is this a way forward? I?d like a volunteer to collate these, please.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
I would think it is the responsibility of the project to call out the hardware they want to test and show the results. Making it to the release would be up some governance to decide if test scope is reasonable and results acceptable?For example? if one project decided to test against sponsor's device?fine make it work ?tested?first on their part? this could go to the release with such caveat ?only tested on specific hardware?? or maybe not under vendor ?neutrality?
I'm not sure we ?e.g. AG) would be in a position to govern or mediate what test that can be run?I'm afraid the scope itself could vary and tend to be subjective among ourselves?

Alex

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Luke, Chris

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

That?s totally reasonable.

I think this needs two things.

- As suggested, a statement of our concerns.
- Some sort of appendix that lists some of the areas of particular concern or things we know that need to be tested on real hardware. This could be attached to the statement, or a wiki page that we all pile into or something.

Is this a way forward? I?d like a volunteer to collate these, please.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
I do think we have a role in this though. I'm not suggesting we govern anything, merely provide specific direction - because that is our remit.

If any among us can provide some test resources too, even better.

But right now I would rather us give a message of "needs improvement, here's some specifics" rather than "it's broken, fix it." We do ourselves no favors with the latter. The more we as a community give the better the result we get, yada yada.

Chris.

> they want to test and show the results. Making it to the release would be up

> ?For example? if one project decided to test against sponsor's device?
> fine make it work ?tested?first on their part? this could go to the release

> under vendor ?neutrality?
> I'm not sure we ?e.g. AG) would be in a position to govern or mediate what
> test that can be run?I'm afraid the scope itself could vary and tend to be
> subjective among ourselves?

> Alex

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Folks: sorry I am slowly reading my email. At the OPNFV summit all week and have been pretty busy - we actually got around 750 participants
attending with many carriers who have attended now thinking of joining! So I've been inundated with back-back meetings..

Did someone agree to pull together the list of adapters- equipment to test against(I think that is what Chris asked for)? If not
I am willing. So just send me your list and I will pull AT&T's list together.


-----Original Message-----
From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com] 
Sent: Thursday, November 12, 2015 7:17 AM
To: Alex_Zhang; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ'; 'Williamson, Beau'; CHIOSI, MARGARET T; 'Harvey Newman'; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

I do think we have a role in this though. I'm not suggesting we govern anything, merely provide specific direction - because that is our remit.

If any among us can provide some test resources too, even better.

But right now I would rather us give a message of "needs improvement, here's some specifics" rather than "it's broken, fix it." We do ourselves no favors with the latter. The more we as a community give the better the result we get, yada yada.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
OPNFV is planning a plugfest event to get the vendors together and test
interoperability.  Is that something ODL should consider, as well?

Chris

On 11/12/15, 4:16 AM, "advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on
behalf of Luke, Chris" <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on
behalf of Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:

>I do think we have a role in this though. I'm not suggesting we govern
>anything, merely provide specific direction - because that is our remit.
>
>If any among us can provide some test resources too, even better.
>
>But right now I would rather us give a message of "needs improvement,
>here's some specifics" rather than "it's broken, fix it." We do ourselves
>no favors with the latter. The more we as a community give the better the
>result we get, yada yada.
>
>Chris.
>

>>acceptable

>>be
>> subjective among ourselves?
>>

Alex

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
This is more of a process of testing to make sure as each ODL release occurs that ODL folks test the adapters. More than a plug fest.

-----Original Message-----
From: Alex_Zhang [mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com] 
Sent: Thursday, November 12, 2015 5:30 PM
To: 'Chris Donley' <C.Donley at cablelabs.com>; 'Luke, Chris' <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ' <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; 'Williamson, Beau' <Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com>; CHIOSI, MARGARET T <mc3124 at att.com>; 'Harvey Newman' <newman at hep.caltech.edu>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

If OPNFV can pull a list together, then it would be a good starting point...:-)

Alex

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Donley [mailto:C.Donley at cablelabs.com] 
Sent: Thursday, November 12, 2015 7:09 AM
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com>; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ' <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; 'Williamson, Beau' <Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com>; 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T' <mc3124 at att.com>; 'Harvey Newman' <newman at hep.caltech.edu>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

OPNFV is planning a plugfest event to get the vendors together and test interoperability.  Is that something ODL should consider, as well?

Chris

On 11/12/15, 4:16 AM, "advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on behalf of Luke, Chris" <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on behalf of Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:

>I do think we have a role in this though. I'm not suggesting we govern 
>anything, merely provide specific direction - because that is our remit.
>
>If any among us can provide some test resources too, even better.
>
>But right now I would rather us give a message of "needs improvement, 
>here's some specifics" rather than "it's broken, fix it." We do 
>ourselves no favors with the latter. The more we as a community give 
>the better the result we get, yada yada.
>
>Chris.
>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: Alex_Zhang [mailto:alexzhang at chinamobile.com]
>> Sent: Thursday, November 12, 2015 01:54
>> To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA 
>> GUTIERREZ' <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; 'Williamson, Beau'

>> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
>> Subject: RE: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network 
>> devices
>> 
>> I would think it is the responsibility of the project to call out the 
>>hardware  they want to test and show the results. Making it to the 
>>release would be up  some governance to decide if test scope is 
>>reasonable and results acceptable
>> ?For example? if one project decided to test against sponsor's 
>>device?
>> fine make it work ?tested?first on their part? this could go to the 
>>release  with such caveat ?only tested on specific hardware?? or maybe 
>>not  under vendor ?neutrality?
>> I'm not sure we ?e.g. AG) would be in a position to govern or mediate 
>>what  test that can be run?I'm afraid the scope itself could vary and 
>>tend to be  subjective among ourselves?
>> 
>> Alex
>>

>> Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network 
>> devices
>> 
>> That?s totally reasonable.
>> 
>> I think this needs two things.
>> 
>> - As suggested, a statement of our concerns.
>> - Some sort of appendix that lists some of the areas of particular 
>>concern or  things we know that need to be tested on real hardware. 
>>This could be  attached to the statement, or a wiki page that we all 
>>pile into or something.
>> 
>> Is this a way forward? I?d like a volunteer to collate these, please.
>> 
>> Chris.
>>

>> 
>>

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Folks: attached is a spreadsheet - please list the adapters and network elements you think the adapters need to test against.

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of CHIOSI, MARGARET T

To: Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com>; 'Chris Donley' <C.Donley at cablelabs.com>; 'Luke, Chris' <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ' <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; 'Williamson, Beau' <Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com>; 'Harvey Newman' <newman at hep.caltech.edu>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

*** Security Advisory: This Message Originated Outside of AT&T ***.
Reference http://cso.att.com/EmailSecurity/IDSP.html for more information.

This is more of a process of testing to make sure as each ODL release occurs that ODL folks test the adapters. More than a plug fest.

From: Chris Donley [mailto:C.Donley at cablelabs.com] 
Sent: Thursday, November 12, 2015 7:09 AM
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>; Alex_Zhang <alexzhang at chinamobile.com>; 'PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ' <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; 'Williamson, Beau' <Beau.Williamson at T-Mobile.com>; 'CHIOSI, MARGARET T' <mc3124 at att.com>; 'Harvey Newman' <newman at hep.caltech.edu>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

OPNFV is planning a plugfest event to get the vendors together and test interoperability.  Is that something ODL should consider, as well?

Chris

On 11/12/15, 4:16 AM, "advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on behalf of Luke, Chris" <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org on behalf of Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com> wrote:

>I do think we have a role in this though. I'm not suggesting we govern 
>anything, merely provide specific direction - because that is our remit.
>
>If any among us can provide some test resources too, even better.
>
>But right now I would rather us give a message of "needs improvement, 
>here's some specifics" rather than "it's broken, fix it." We do 
>ourselves no favors with the latter. The more we as a community give 
>the better the result we get, yada yada.
>
>Chris.
>

>> 
>> I would think it is the responsibility of the project to call out the 
>>hardware  they want to test and show the results. Making it to the 
>>release would be up  some governance to decide if test scope is 
>>reasonable and results acceptable
>> ?For example? if one project decided to test against sponsor's 
>>device?
>> fine make it work ?tested?first on their part? this could go to the 
>>release  with such caveat ?only tested on specific hardware?? or maybe 
>>not  under vendor ?neutrality?
>> I'm not sure we ?e.g. AG) would be in a position to govern or mediate 
>>what  test that can be run?I'm afraid the scope itself could vary and 
>>tend to be  subjective among ourselves?
>> 
>> Alex
>>

>> - As suggested, a statement of our concerns.
>> - Some sort of appendix that lists some of the areas of particular 
>>concern or  things we know that need to be tested on real hardware. 
>>This could be  attached to the statement, or a wiki page that we all 
>>pile into or something.
>> 
>> Is this a way forward? I?d like a volunteer to collate these, please.

>> Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Folks: since no one gave me input - here is AT&T's

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Harvey Newman
Sent: Tuesday, November 10, 2015 10:18 AM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices


Yes we at Caltech have had a similar experience,
including items such as the error counters not
being properly passed on.

I raised this general issue a while ago.
Testing, interaction with vendors and resolution
of issues, and establishment of known
working configurations (switch models and
firmware release, parameter settings etc.)
are important for wide community adoption.
Especially if an ODL  release is to be declared
"production ready"

Harvey


On 11/10/2015 7:09 AM, CHIOSI, MARGARET T wrote:
> Folks: AT&T is finding a lot of bugs in the adapters (e.g. BGP Flowspec) which are pretty fundamental we think.
> We have discovered that ODL as a community doesn't necessarily test some of these adapters against real equipment.
> Just curious if anyone else has hit the adapter maturity issues and if we as a group should raise this as a higher priority
> to the community.
> thanks.
> _______________________________________________
> advisory-group mailing list
> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/advisory-group

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Hi all,
I appended to Margaret's list attached with TR's entries in blue.
Margaret - I noticed your list contained some vendor-only entries, some device model specifics, and some s/w specifics. I've stuck with the vendor/device-model only for my list which means there's overlap (eg the ASR 9K in my with IOS-XR in yours). 


Jon Beasley

Thomson Reuters

subject: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices
message_text:
Margaret,

Sorry for not responding before now.  I would add ALU SRX 7750 routers to all of the categories.  We use a lot of those and I'd like to make sure those interoperate with ODL.  

Having said that, we are not yet up to an SRX release that supports NETCONF but I have been lead to believe that one of the newer versions (that we haven't tested in the lab yet) "will" support it.  Therefore, I'd like to see that on the list.

Beau Williamson
CCIE #1346 R/S Emeritus
Principle Member of Technical Staff
Corporate Engineering
metroPCS/T-Mobile
Internal: 314982
Office:?? 469.330.4982
Mobile:?? 972.679.4334

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of CHIOSI, MARGARET T
Sent: Wednesday, December 02, 2015 4:15 PM
To: Harvey Newman; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices

Folks: since no one gave me input - here is AT&T's

-----Original Message-----
From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Harvey Newman
Sent: Tuesday, November 10, 2015 10:18 AM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Interop testing with real network devices


Yes we at Caltech have had a similar experience, including items such as the error counters not being properly passed on.

I raised this general issue a while ago.
Testing, interaction with vendors and resolution of issues, and establishment of known working configurations (switch models and firmware release, parameter settings etc.) are important for wide community adoption.
Especially if an ODL  release is to be declared "production ready"

Harvey


On 11/10/2015 7:09 AM, CHIOSI, MARGARET T wrote:
> Folks: AT&T is finding a lot of bugs in the adapters (e.g. BGP Flowspec) which are pretty fundamental we think.
> We have discovered that ODL as a community doesn't necessarily test some of these adapters against real equipment.
> Just curious if anyone else has hit the adapter maturity issues and if 
> we as a group should raise this as a higher priority to the community.
> thanks.
> _______________________________________________
> advisory-group mailing list
> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/advisory-group

subject: [advisory-group] Use case demo collections.
message_text:
Hello ODL folks,

During the recent ODL Hackfest, community people discussed about to compile a set of use case demos, the target audience is end users.

I solicited some PTLs to provide video demos for their projects based on Beryllium release,  with Beryllium entering code freeze milestone, it probably is a good time for all projects to think about this.

This is the template I would like to get start: https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/User_cases
The format is not final, we can discuss more in details. I would like PTLs to think about one or more use cases, provide a description of what problem you are to resolve, a brief steps how to setup in ODL, preferable a demo video for users to follow step by step. The goal is to enable user to download and run the ODL SDN controller.

I list some projects that agreed to provide demo videos, please feel free to add your project to the page,  I would also like to collect use cases from community users, please fill the following form with a use case you would like to see, or how to use ODL to achieve what you would like to do, we will circulate those in the community and see if we can provide a solution for your use case.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1k_kurc_R6M-0E_7Nj7WCFkmYsHlUURLyme9jWzFaBCg

Thanks,
George
