subject:
[advisory-group] Fwd: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Board]
 [OPENDAYLIGHT BYLAW WAIVER - TSC COMPOSITION] Discussion.
message_text:
Dear Advisory Group,

As the mail below highlights, the TSC is in the process of discussing and
likely approving significant changes to who will sit on the TSC.

The major change is that we will likely be ending platinum designates
(appointed members from the platinum companies) as the major constituents
of the TSC. This is something that was intended since the beginning of
OpenDaylight; the platinum designates were only ever intended to be a
bootstrapping mechanism until the technical members of the community were
numerous enough and could be identified to make up the TSC. There appears
to be a strong belief that we have hit that point.

However, the original plan for the makeup of the TSC expected that there
would be core projects at this point and the PTLs of the core projects
would be the TSC members from the technical community. We do not yet have
core projects, so the current discussion is looking at having TSC members
come from a combination of committers-at-large (any committer could be
elected) and PTLs of projects (possibly with a preference to mature
projects).

Beyond this, there are discussions about whether PTLs should be drawn from
all projects with no categorization or if we should split projects into
different constituencies,  e.g., kernel, protocol,  and apps.

Lastly, there is discussion about capping the number of TSC members that
could come from any one company.

If you have thoughts on any of this and would like to chime in,  feel free
to do so here or on the TSC list.  The archives of discussion so far can be
found here:
https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-December/thread.html
https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-November/thread.html

Search for "waiver" and you should find the long discussion.

Cheers,
--Colin
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Colin Dixon" <colin at colindixon.com>
Date: Dec 8, 2015 5:27 PM
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Board] [OPENDAYLIGHT BYLAW
WAIVER - TSC COMPOSITION] Discussion.
To: "Neela Jacques" <njacques at linuxfoundation.org>
Cc: <board at lists.opendaylight.org>, "Christopher Price" <
christopher.price at ericsson.com>, "Edward Warnicke" <hagbard at gmail.com>,
"Daniel Farrell" <dfarrell at redhat.com>, <tsc at lists.opendaylight.org>

I'd be more than happy to bring the advisory group into the discussion or
> at least make them aware of what's going on.
>
> --Colin
> On Dec 7, 2015 10:43 PM, "Neela Jacques" <njacques at linuxfoundation.org>
> wrote:
>
>> I like the way all this is progressing but I do want to make an important
>> point re caps for you all to consider.
>>
>> I am asked about the concern regarding the ability for one company to get
>> "control" over and over again. Like it or not many business executives at
>> existing or prospective members will NOT make the gamble to invest millions
>> of dollars of resources if they feel a single company has or can get
>> "control" of the project. Even absent any nefarious behavior by any
>> individual tsc members, a situation where one company gets a large % of tsc
>> or board members will lead to a significant reduction in project
>> participation, adoption and contribution. I hear this from both end users
>> and vendors. We are a platform, not an App and as a result a key
>> determinant of our success is not just how good we are but also people's
>> beliefs that we will succeed, that we are the deaf to standard and that
>> others will also build on us, support us and deploy us. That trust is hard
>> to earn and easy to lose.
>>
>>  While 99% of what you consider should be the effective running of the
>> project I do ask that you keep in mind the realities that the folks that
>> have to make the decision whether or not to invest resources.
>>
>> -Neela
>>
>> P.S. Colin, since caps seems to be a hot button issue, could I suggest
>> you check with our end user advisory group to get their feedback on how
>> these changes (and any others you feel are pertinent) might be perceived
>> and effect our perception among their decision makers.
>>
>> Sent from my mobile device. Please excuse brevity and typos.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> On Mon, Dec 7, 2015 at 3:17 AM -0800, "Edward Warnicke" <
>> hagbard at gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>
>>>
>>> On Thu, Dec 3, 2015 at 3:29 PM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com>
>>> wrote:
>>>
>>>> Hello all,
>>>>
>>>> Per [my TSC #action][0], let's see if we can drive this to a vote. :)
>>>>
>>>> Establishing a more formal consensus on a few key [decision points][1]
>>>> should help reduce the solution space and provide constrains on
>>>> proposals that can achieve consensus.
>>>>
>>>> It would be particularly helpful if TSC members could vote (informally
>>>> as
>>>> a poll, not as a binding decision of the TSC) on these questions, so we
>>>> can accurately gauge consensus. As always, feedback is encouraged from
>>>> all.
>>>>
>>>> ## Platinum Designates
>>>>
>>>> Under the assumption that we come up with a good replacement system,
>>>> should we eliminate Platinum Designate seats from the TSC?
>>>>
>>>
>>> +1 once we have a concrete plan, -1 until we do... I think this question
>>> puts the cart before the horse... in the presence of a good plan, a whole
>>> hearted +1 million, in the presence of a poor plan, strong -1... without a
>>> plan, this is unanswerable.
>>>
>>>
>>>>
>>>> ## Company Caps
>>>>
>>>> Do we want to have per-company caps on TSC seats?
>>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> I think this question is essentially meaningless without a clear
>>> mechanism that addresses the negative concerns about adverse impacts on the
>>> technical community and the re-introduction (in a worse form) of the issue
>>> we are seeking to address with the waiver.  Which is to say, I think this
>>> question isn't properly answerable without more details and a careful
>>> walkthrough of the *tradeoffs* of those details.
>>>
>>>
>>>>
>>>> ## Represented Groups
>>>>
>>>> We need to decided which groups will make up the TSC.
>>>>
>>>> This is an involved question, and I think each proposal will have to
>>>> address
>>>> it in its on way, but we can at least start pruning the set of proposals
>>>> that can get consensus.
>>>>
>>>> Do we want only Committer-at-Large seats, or do we also want to allocate
>>>> seats to PTLs from some TBD Represented Groups?
>>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Depends on which groups.  I think there are good and bad choices of
>>> groups.  Given good choices and mechanisms, I strongly support this, but I
>>> can't say without a concerete proposal, and I think this is vague enough
>>> that it simply can't be sanely answered as phrased.
>>>
>>>
>>>>
>>>> ## Timeline
>>>>
>>>> The Board just requires a plan to move away from needing the the
>>>> Platinum
>>>> Designates company cap waver, not an immediate implementation. We could
>>>> formalize a plan, ask the Board for a waver for this year and implement
>>>> the plan next year. We could also push through and implement it now.
>>>>
>>>> Do we want to implement this now or in a year?
>>>>
>>>
>>> Depends *completely* on the concrete plan.  I think this question is
>>> meaningless at this level of detail.
>>>
>>> I would strongly suggest that we look at a better breakdown of these
>>> questions, one that actually captures in a more detailed fashion the
>>> detailed choice points and the raised tradeoffs.  For example, I believe we
>>> have a fairly small number of actual proposals for groupings, and a pretty
>>> clear articulation of folks for why they think which options are
>>> preferable.  *That* could be answerable, but I think many of the quesitons
>>> as phrased are pre-committing to unknown and possibly objectionable
>>> solutions.
>>>
>>>
>>>>
>>>> ---------
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> [0]:
>>>> https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-meeting/2015/tsc/opendaylight-meeting-tsc.2015-12-03-18.00.log.html#l-147
>>>> [1]:
>>>> https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-meeting/2015/tsc/opendaylight-meeting-tsc.2015-12-03-18.00.log.html#l-144
>>>>
>>>> Daniel Farrell
>>>> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
>>>> https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/user:dfarrell07
>>>>
>>>> ----- Original Message -----
>>>> > On Tue, Dec 1, 2015 at 12:10 PM, Phil Robb <probb at linuxfoundation.org
>>>> >
>>>> > wrote:
>>>> >
>>>> > > Hi Ed.  Thanks for your quick feedback.  My comments inline as
>>>> well....
>>>> > >
>>>> > > On Tue, Dec 1, 2015 at 11:45 AM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com
>>>> >
>>>> > > wrote:
>>>> > >
>>>> > >> Comments inline...
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >> On Tue, Dec 1, 2015 at 11:22 AM, Phil Robb <
>>>> probb at linuxfoundation.org>
>>>> > >> wrote:
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>> <snip />
>>>> > >>> So with the above context, and taking all of the outstanding
>>>> comments on
>>>> > >>> this thread thus far, I suggest the following "framework" for the
>>>> > >>> election.
>>>> > >>> 1) We have 5 constituencies: Kernel, Apps, Protocols, Support,
>>>> CALs
>>>> > >>> 2) Each constituency gets 3 TSC seats (15 TSC seats total)
>>>> > >>> 3) Core/Mature projects have priority to sit on the TSC
>>>> > >>>     i - If there are more than 3 Core/Mature projects in a
>>>> constituency,
>>>> > >>> an election will be held to see which of the Core/Mature project
>>>> PTLs
>>>> > >>> will
>>>> > >>> sit on the TSC:
>>>> > >>>         * Candidates: PTLs of the Core/Mature projects within the
>>>> > >>> constituency
>>>> > >>>         * Voters: All PTLs in the constituency (core, mature, and
>>>> > >>> incubation)
>>>> > >>>     ii - If there are exactly 3 Core/Mature projects in a
>>>> constituency,
>>>> > >>> the 3 PTLs from those projects are the constituency's
>>>> representatives on
>>>> > >>> the TSC
>>>> > >>>     iii - If there are fewer than 3 Core/Mature projects in the
>>>> > >>> constituency, the PTLs from the Core/Mature projects get TSC
>>>> seats, and
>>>> > >>> an
>>>> > >>> election is held to fill the remaining seats with Incubation
>>>> project PTLs
>>>> > >>>         * Candidates:  PTLs from Incubation Projects within the
>>>> > >>> constituency
>>>> > >>>         * Voters: All PTLs within the constituency (core, mature,
>>>> > >>> incubation)
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >> I am a bit concerned about guaranteeing seats to Mature projects
>>>> in this
>>>> > >> manner... I'd feel more comfortable if we considered something
>>>> like:
>>>> > >> "All PTLs in a non-CAL constituency eligible to run until 6 (2*3)
>>>> > >> projects in a constituency have become Mature, all PTLs in a
>>>> non-CAL
>>>> > >> constituency vote in that constituencies election".  It moves
>>>> towards the
>>>> > >> same goal, but does not guarantee seats in the same way.
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >
>>>> > > [PJR] - Yep, I see and appreciate this concern.  While I think that
>>>> we
>>>> > > should continue to find and stress incentives for projects to become
>>>> > > mature, this incentive may be a bit "too privileged".   I'm not
>>>> sure that 6
>>>> > > is the magic number though, particularly for constituencies that
>>>> are going
>>>> > > to be smaller (kernel and support come to mind).  Maybe a
>>>> combination of
>>>> > > size-of-constituency, and hard number... ie "All PTLs in a non-CAL
>>>> > > constituency eligible to run until either 50% of the constituency
>>>> or 6
>>>> > > (2*3) project are core/mature"... as an example.
>>>> > >
>>>> >
>>>> > [eaw] - Take 6 as an example here, not a strong push :)  The basic
>>>> idea is
>>>> > some n*(number of seats)... but even that is just an example to talk
>>>> about.
>>>> >
>>>> > >
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>> 4) CAL Election
>>>> > >>>     * Candidates: All Committers within ODL
>>>> > >>>     * Voters: All Committers within ODL
>>>> > >>> 4) The assignments/elections for TSC representatives are done in
>>>> series:
>>>> > >>> Kernel, then Apps, then Protocols, then Support, then CALs.  Each
>>>> > >>> election
>>>> > >>> need only be staggered by a day or two.
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >> This actually makes a huge amount of sense to me.
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>> 5) No more than 4 individuals from the same company can sit on
>>>> the TSC.
>>>> > >>> If/When the cap of 4 is reached, all remaining
>>>> candidates/appointees are
>>>> > >>> disqualified and are removed from consideration (hence the series
>>>> of
>>>> > >>> appointments/elections above).  If the cap is reached where
>>>> multiple PTLs
>>>> > >>> from the same company would be appointed to the TSC (as is the
>>>> case in
>>>> > >>> 3.ii
>>>> > >>> above), then the PTL(s) of project(s) that have been mature/core
>>>> the
>>>> > >>> longest get preference.
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >> I am really really uncomfortable with mixing corporate
>>>> > >> politics/affiliation with technical governance in this way.  I
>>>> can't
>>>> > >> imagine a stronger slap in the face to someone working their heart
>>>> out in
>>>> > >> the community than being excluded purely due to corporate
>>>> affiliation.
>>>> > >> Additionally, it opens us up to *exactly* the same sort of bizarre
>>>> > >> distortions the waiver is trying to move away from (only in spades,
>>>> > >> because
>>>> > >> this has the potential to be even *more* distorting than the
>>>> situation the
>>>> > >> waiver is designed to deal with).  I don't think trying to do away
>>>> with
>>>> > >> the
>>>> > >> distortion of the waiver by introducing a more complex distortion
>>>> is a
>>>> > >> good
>>>> > >> idea.
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >
>>>> > > [PJR] I can go either way on the caps.  I find good arguments in
>>>> both
>>>> > > directions.  This was an attempt at a compromise.  Having 4 people
>>>> from the
>>>> > > same company on a TSC of 15 is a lot.  I think many would agree
>>>> that we
>>>> > > need have some kind of cap... for example at least put a cap at 7
>>>> otherwise
>>>> > > a company affiliation could control all TSC votes, and that would
>>>> also
>>>> > > indicate a general unhealthy non-diverse leadership issue.  In
>>>> general
>>>> > > however (and as usual), I defer to the majority consensus on this
>>>> one.
>>>> > >
>>>> > > Phil.
>>>> > >
>>>> > >
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >> Ed
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>> ---
>>>> > >>> [0] https://www.opendaylight.org/tsc-charter
>>>> > >>> [1] https://www.opendaylight.org/tsc-policy
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>> Thanks,
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>> Phil.
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>> On Mon, Nov 30, 2015 at 12:52 PM, Daniel Farrell <
>>>> dfarrell at redhat.com>
>>>> > >>> wrote:
>>>> > >>>
>>>> > >>>> > First of all, ODL TSC is open to public, and everyone can
>>>> voice his
>>>> > >>>> opinion
>>>> > >>>> > to TSC.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> By "voice" I mean vote, not just attend/contribute.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> > My question is do we really need to divide projects into
>>>> categories
>>>> > >>>> to make
>>>> > >>>> > sure each category has a representative? Can we just rely on
>>>> > >>>> committers to
>>>> > >>>> > elect a group of TSC.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> +1, this seems to be the key question atm.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> I'm not strongly convicted one way or the other. I seem to tend
>>>> to favor
>>>> > >>>> designing the system such that we have diversity guarantees, but
>>>> if
>>>> > >>>> there's
>>>> > >>>> consensus that they are unnecessary I'd defer to the community.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> > incentive for projects to move to mature
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> +1, understood. If we do this, we're back in the world of
>>>> multi-STV
>>>> > >>>> elections,
>>>> > >>>> which is fine and simple imho, but essentially a version of the
>>>> system
>>>> > >>>> I've
>>>> > >>>> been describing with 2 Represented Groups (CALs and Mature).
>>>> That's
>>>> > >>>> actually
>>>> > >>>> nice, since we could have a path to add additional Represented
>>>> Groups
>>>> > >>>> later
>>>> > >>>> if we decide it's necessary.
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> Daniel Farrell
>>>> > >>>> Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
>>>> > >>>> https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/user:dfarrell07
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> > >>>> ----- Original Message -----
>>>> > >>>> > First of all, ODL TSC is open to public, and everyone can
>>>> voice his
>>>> > >>>> opinion
>>>> > >>>> > to TSC.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > My question is do we really need to divide projects into
>>>> categories
>>>> > >>>> to make
>>>> > >>>> > sure each category has a representative? Can we just rely on
>>>> > >>>> committers to
>>>> > >>>> > elect a group of TSC.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Mature project is a little different, projects need to have
>>>> history of
>>>> > >>>> > tracking record, complete documentations and prompt responses
>>>> for
>>>> > >>>> support,
>>>> > >>>> > we would like to promote projects to move to this direction,
>>>> thus,
>>>> > >>>> create a
>>>> > >>>> > special bucket for mature projects PTLs to be TSC is an
>>>> incentive for
>>>> > >>>> > projects to move to mature. However, I won't be surprised that
>>>> most
>>>> > >>>> mature
>>>> > >>>> > project PTLs will be elected even without this rule.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > -----Original Message-----
>>>> > >>>> > From: Daniel Farrell [mailto:dfarrell at redhat.com]
>>>> > >>>> > Sent: Wednesday, November 25, 2015 1:21 PM
>>>> > >>>> > To: George Zhao
>>>> > >>>> > Cc: Edward Warnicke; Robert Varga; Christopher Price; board;
>>>> > >>>> > tsc at lists.opendaylight.org
>>>> > >>>> > Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] [OpenDaylight Board]
>>>> [OPENDAYLIGHT
>>>> > >>>> BYLAW
>>>> > >>>> > WAIVER - TSC COMPOSITION] Discussion.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > > but it will add a lot of words to explain the CAL rules.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > I don't think it's as complex as this thread makes it out to
>>>> be. ;)
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > If I understand it correctly, your proposal is a version of
>>>> what
>>>> > >>>> > I called [Option 1][0] with adjusted seat counts to get to 15.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > [0]:
>>>> > >>>>
>>>> https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/tsc/2015-November/004226.html
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Here's what I think you're proposing, put in the Represented
>>>> Groups
>>>> > >>>> > voting framework that imho makes these easier to reason about.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > # Option 3
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Focus on maturity of project for representation.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > * Committers-at-Large
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 9
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: Committers to ODL projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: Committers to ODL projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Mature Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 6
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Mature projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Mature projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Core Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 0 (>0 later, no Core projects will exist this
>>>> election)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Core projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Core projects
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Total seats: 15
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > > do we really need to divide projects into those categories to
>>>> > >>>> > > make sure they have representatives in TSC?
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > > What if we only identify mature/graduate projects
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > If we decide we don't want to partition seats to guarantee
>>>> voices,
>>>> > >>>> > why do we keep the Mature Represented Group? I see better
>>>> arguments
>>>> > >>>> > for guaranteeing Core's voice (very select, critical voice),
>>>> but
>>>> > >>>> > not for Mature vs Kernel/App/Proto/Common.
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > I definitely see merit in allocating more seats to the CAL
>>>> pool,
>>>> > >>>> > for the community to fill as they wish. However, it's not much
>>>> > >>>> > extra work to add diversity guarantees, and imho that's a
>>>> better
>>>> > >>>> > structure. If we're going to have diversity guarantees at all,
>>>> > >>>> > why choose Mature over groups that frequently have different
>>>> > >>>> > expertise/interests at the TSC, like Kernel/App/Proto/Common?
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Here's a proposal that's a bit of a mix of Option 0 and Option
>>>> 1:
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > # Option 4
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > * Committers-at-Large
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 9
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: Committers to ODL projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: Committers to ODL projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Mature Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 2 (1 later, once we have core projects)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Mature projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Mature projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Core Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 0 (1 or more later, once we have core projects)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Core projects
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Core projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Kernel Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 1
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Kernel-type projects (exact def TBD)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Kernel projects
>>>> > >>>> > * Protocol Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 1
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of Protocol-type projects (exact def TBD)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Protocol projects
>>>> > >>>> > * App Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 1
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of App-type projects (exact def TBD)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of App projects
>>>> > >>>> > * "Support" (better name?) Project PTLs
>>>> > >>>> >   * Seats: 1
>>>> > >>>> >   * Candidates: PTLs of "Support"-type projects (exact def TBD)
>>>> > >>>> >   * Voters: PTLs of Support projects
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Total seats: 15
>>>> > >>>> >
>>>> > >>>> > Daniel Farrell
>>>> > >>>> > Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
>>>> > >>>> > https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/user:dfarrell07
>>>> > >>>> >

>>>> divide
>>>> > >>>> projects
>>>> > >>>> > > into those categories to make sure they have representatives
>>>> in
>>>> > >>>> TSC? I am
>>>> > >>>> > > not object to it, but it will add a lot of words to explain
>>>> the CAL
>>>> > >>>> rules.
>>>> > >>>> > >
>>>> > >>>> > >
>>>> > >>>> > >
>>>> > >>>> > > The question is what format of TSC will do best for ODL, in
>>>> my mind,
>>>> > >>>> > > today?s
>>>> > >>>> > > TSC works pretty well except for the bylaw issue that we
>>>> have to
>>>> > >>>> work
>>>> > >>>> > > around. We don?t need to over complicate CAL election.
>>>> > >>>> > >
>>>> > >>>> > >

>>>> > >>>> > > I agree with Chris that ?mature? is a state of project and
>>>> can be
>>>> > >>>> measured
>>>> > >>>> > > more subjectively. What if we only identify mature/graduate

>>>> > >>>> now, we

>>>> > >>>> > > Abhijit correctly, project that is qualified as core can be

>>>> > >>>> > > and TSC can give a list of projects that is considered as

>>>> > >>>> > >
>>>> > >>>> > >

>>>> > >>>> > > BR,

subject: [advisory-group] ODL Advisory Group Agenda for Dec 17th.
message_text:
Thank you Margaret, and thank you George.

These were great slides.  Are all you POCs going to move to field trial and then production? I know AT&T?s w/r to controller and virtualization are moving in that direction.

-        We do try to move POC to field trial. But the progress is uncertain because we need more VNFs besides vBNG to support service chaining, most current VNFs are poor at performance. BTW, we already have several field trials for vBRAS in some metro networks. But those are vendor?s proprietary controller instead of OLD. Prushing vendors to move those controllers to ODL is another choice for us.

Also are you planning on contributing applications (like policy engine) back into ODL?

-        Yes. Actually, we are seeking a new policy engine from ODL project to replace our policy module. GBP and NEMO are under evaluation, how to simplify abstraction concepts to end user in above two projects is headache problem for us.

I am noticing a lot of participation in ODL and OPNFV by the Chinese companies.

Maybe ODL/LF should invest in a company to translate the documents into Chinese.

-        As far as I know, some Chinese tech websites start translation work as mentioned by George. But language is not the biggest obstacle, use cases on how to apply ODL in different solutions are more important in current phrase.



BR,



Liang Ou

subject: [advisory-group] Boron Planning
message_text:
Almost two months ago, we had an advisory group meeting about Boron
planning and requirements. As part of that I agreed to try to send out a
mail asking for more input from the AG on Boron, but failed to do so until
now.

Here are my quick notes with full notes below.

Critical Priority:
* Easier upgrades/migration between versions. This includes the ability to
do skip upgrades (Helium => Beryllium) rather than having to go through
each incremental release (Helium => Lithium => Beryllium).

High Priority:
* Documentation
* Compatibility information (mostly w.r.t. hardware)

Other ideas (from the AG):
* More focus on TSDR, collection of logs, alarms, analytics, etc.
* Change control, e.g., Microsoft's statesman
* Dealing with conflicting commands going to devices
* Not really a development idea, but dealing with what should go in ODL vs.
being solved elsewhere
    * especially in the context of VNFM vs. controller vs. NFVO
    * Margaret argues that if the controller controls it?the controller
should also do it's lifecycle management

--Colin

More raw notes:

Still more topics/ideas:
* Should we have shorter release cycles (less than every 6 months)
* Should we think about offering different support timelines? SLAs for
support?

Notes on how often to upgrade:
* upgrade every other seems more common than on every release
* it depends on how easy it is to upgrade
    * every six months seems crazy for operators if it's a critical
component
* comcast just moved off of Essex for openstack (released early 2012)
* AT&T says six month cadence is about right
    * If you're forced to upgrade A => B => C vs. A => C that changes some
of how
* Beau says that LTSes seem less relevant, people upgrade when they need
new features not on a cadence
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/advisory-group/attachments/20151221/74b77762/attachment.html>

subject: [advisory-group] Boron Planning
message_text:
Colin:

1.       Preliminary adaptors appear to last for a cycle or two and then appear to go into oblivion / disuse.

a.       There is only one pillar in IoT and not clear there is enough breadth of users to push it where it needs to go.

b.      Clearly contrail was an example of it but that might be a poor example since only one vendor was really supporting this.

2.       A useful adaptor is in the right niche but when you go to use it you find that it lacks completeness / features ? BGP is an example of this. It?s getting there but it?s still missing Add-Path. This is not due to lack of effort ? but more lack of real users using it to give feedback.

a.       Maybe part of it is -  How is each PTL gathering input from Users on their features ? or help from the user community on their component in terms of feature planning ?

b.      Netconf needs more thorough flushing out

High Priority:

Other ideas (from the AG):

* Change control, e.g., Microsoft's statesman

* Not really a development idea, but dealing with what should go in ODL vs. being solved elsewhere
    * especially in the context of VNFM vs. controller vs. NFVO
    * Margaret argues that if the controller controls it?the controller should also do it's lifecycle management

--Colin

More raw notes:
Still more topics/ideas:

subject: [advisory-group] Boron Planning
message_text:
This is really good feedback.

When it comes to fleshing out current plugins, I think different PTLs are
approach things differently. That being said, my suggestion is to send
e-mails to the relevant lists either referring to a new feature or a
documented bug/issue. Some (really most) projects track new features as
bugs with the severity set to "enhancement".

After the e-mail,
1.) make sure the bugfix and/or new feature actually appears on the release
plan for the project
2.) make sure to actually try it out during the development cycle to make
sure it's doing what you expected

For projects with waning interest, the right approach is obviously going to
depend on the project and situation. It never hurts to let people know that
you're actually using it and explaining how so that the developers know
what they're doing matters. That being said, it might not be enough if
there are business concerns that shift attention.one way or another. You
can mitigate that by trying to make sure more than one vendor is
significantly involved in things, but I know that's not always easy.

Specific to Boron, it sounds like there's a few asks here:

a.) Try to connect users into the per-project feature request and
development during the release cycle. This is a great idea, but at the very
least will take time and cycles from users to engage and make sure things
actually happen. Also,

b.) You'd like to see Add-Path support in the BPG project.

c.) You'd like to see some NETCONF changes. Are these more or less the same
ones that we had the previous thread about?

--Colin

Dear all
Let me first to wish you a happy new year,
Yes P4 is an interesting technology with an objective to go beyond Openflow with a complete programmable network protocol 'the 4th P in P4 is for any protocol.
who is able to present us P4 ? Or maybe we can ask one of P4 leader to give us a overview on P4. Anyway in case we think it's an important technology, who is interested to initiate such project within ODL?

Cordialement
Jamil

From:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] On Behalf Of Colin Dixon
Sent: Monday, December 21, 2015 2:24 PM
To: advisory-group <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Subject: [advisory-group] Boron Planning

Almost two months ago, we had an advisory group meeting about Boron planning and requirements. As part of that I agreed to try to send out a mail asking for more input from the AG on Boron, but failed to do so until now.
Here are my quick notes with full notes below.

Critical Priority:
* Easier upgrades/migration between versions. This includes the ability to do skip upgrades (Helium => Beryllium) rather than having to go through each incremental release (Helium => Lithium => Beryllium).
High Priority:
* Documentation
* Compatibility information (mostly w.r.t. hardware)
Other ideas (from the AG):
* More focus on TSDR, collection of logs, alarms, analytics, etc.
* Change control, e.g., Microsoft's statesman
* Dealing with conflicting commands going to devices
* Not really a development idea, but dealing with what should go in ODL vs. being solved elsewhere
    * especially in the context of VNFM vs. controller vs. NFVO
    * Margaret argues that if the controller controls it?the controller should also do it's lifecycle management

--Colin

More raw notes:
Still more topics/ideas:
* Should we have shorter release cycles (less than every 6 months)
* Should we think about offering different support timelines? SLAs for support?

Notes on how often to upgrade:
* upgrade every other seems more common than on every release
* it depends on how easy it is to upgrade
    * every six months seems crazy for operators if it's a critical component
* comcast just moved off of Essex for openstack (released early 2012)
* AT&T says six month cadence is about right
    * If you're forced to upgrade A => B => C vs. A => C that changes some of how
* Beau says that LTSes seem less relevant, people upgrade when they need new features not on a cadence

Sounds good. Is anyone else working with P4? I might have something from Comcast too by then.

I guess from Colin's questions he (and perhaps other developers) would like to see more information on how we would use P4, and what the interaction model between a controller and a P4 switch might look like. Do we want a controller to worry about loading P4 program blobs? Or just interacting with the P4 program already on a switch?

Chris.

? : PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ; CHAWKI Jamil IMT/OLN; CHIOSI, MARGARET T
Cc : advisory-group
Objet : Re: [advisory-group] Boron Planning

Sounds good. Is anyone else working with P4? I might have something from Comcast too by then.

I guess from Colin's questions he (and perhaps other developers) would like to see more information on how we would use P4, and what the interaction model between a controller and a P4 switch might look like. Do we want a controller to worry about loading P4 program blobs? Or just interacting with the P4 program already on a switch?

Chris.

From:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] On Behalf Of Colin Dixon
Sent: Monday, December 21, 2015 2:24 PM
To: advisory-group <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Subject: [advisory-group] Boron Planning

Almost two months ago, we had an advisory group meeting about Boron planning and requirements. As part of that I agreed to try to send out a mail asking for more input from the AG on Boron, but failed to do so until now.
Here are my quick notes with full notes below.

Critical Priority:
* Easier upgrades/migration between versions. This includes the ability to do skip upgrades (Helium => Beryllium) rather than having to go through each incremental release (Helium => Lithium => Beryllium).
High Priority:
* Documentation
* Compatibility information (mostly w.r.t. hardware)
Other ideas (from the AG):
* More focus on TSDR, collection of logs, alarms, analytics, etc.
* Change control, e.g., Microsoft's statesman
* Dealing with conflicting commands going to devices
* Not really a development idea, but dealing with what should go in ODL vs. being solved elsewhere
    * especially in the context of VNFM vs. controller vs. NFVO
    * Margaret argues that if the controller controls it?the controller should also do it's lifecycle management

--Colin

More raw notes:
Still more topics/ideas:
* Should we have shorter release cycles (less than every 6 months)
* Should we think about offering different support timelines? SLAs for support?

Notes on how often to upgrade:
* upgrade every other seems more common than on every release
* it depends on how easy it is to upgrade
    * every six months seems crazy for operators if it's a critical component
* comcast just moved off of Essex for openstack (released early 2012)
* AT&T says six month cadence is about right
    * If you're forced to upgrade A => B => C vs. A => C that changes some of how
* Beau says that LTSes seem less relevant, people upgrade when they need new features not on a cadence

https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/advisory-group

subject: [advisory-group] Please Take & Share 2016 ODL User Survey
message_text:
ODL Advisors:

Today we are issuing the second *OpenDaylight User Survey* to collect data
on where, why and how people are using ODL. We?ll use data from both
surveys to show deployment and adoption trends, and have added several new
questions to increase our understanding of demographics and usage.

We are asking our advisors to please take the survey, circulate internally,
and share with others.

Blog:
https://www.opendaylight.org/news/blogs/2016/01/participate-2016-odl-user-survey

Survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/5Y29Q6N

Click to Tweet: http://ctt.ec/3Gp0m


Our previous survey findings were very well received by reporters and the
industry at large, so we anticipate similar levels of interest as we
continue to show trends.

Full results will be shared privately with AG and ODL members prior to a
results summary being published, which will happen in tandem with the
Beryllium launch.


Let us know if you have questions. Thank you!


-- 
Melissa Logan
Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight
mlogan at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: mklogan
503-317-8498

Using Open SDN to Share Big Data from Large Hadron Collider
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSLaEha85Dw

subject: [advisory-group] Welcoming Carlos Matos, Fidelty
message_text:
OpenDaylight Advisory Group,

Please join me in welcoming Carlos Matos as the newest OpenDaylight Advisor.

Carlos has been with Fidelity Investments for 15 years in multiple areas
including Operations, Engineering, and Architecture. Currently as Director
of Global Network Architecture, in addition of being the Architect for the
External infrastructure (Internet and Extranet), he leads the emerging
technologies, (NSV/NFV) Network Service/Function Virtualization, and (SDN)
Software Define Networking Programs.



Carlos has been the Network Architect for the Click-to-Compute private
cloud project from its inception, overseeing the entire design, automation
of network Services, and creation of Network self-service offerings for
LBaaS, FWaaS, etc. He was also part of the group who designed the Next
generation data center, next generation firewall, NG monitoring projects
among many others.



While taking  a leave from Fidelity to later return,  he worked as a Chief
Architect as part of the Divx Professional Services group,  consulting,
designing, and deploying  video over IP and Content Delivery Networks for
Fortune 100 Companies.

Prior to Fidelity Carlos worked for The Venezuelan Revenue Service,  and
Verizon Wireless as Chief Internal Auditor among other positions.



He has a bachelor degree in Business, and Management of Information Systems
from the University JMV, Venezuela, and an MS in telecommunications and
Data Networks from the University of Colorado at Boulder.


-- 
*Todd Benzies*
Senior Program Manager
The Linux Foundation
+1 (415) 412-0310 (m)
tbenzies at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: tbenzies

subject: [advisory-group] Please Take & Share 2016 ODL User Survey
message_text:
Thanks to everyone who has taken the survey so far.

The additional data we're collecting has been useful - US and Japan are
leading so far in deployments. Demographics show telcos comprise almost
half of our user base, followed by IT, then academic/research.

If you haven't yet, please take a few moments and respond - we would
greatly appreciate your input.

Survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/5Y29Q6N

Click to Tweet: http://ctt.ec/3Gp0m


Complete results will be shared with you in the coming weeks.


Melissa

subject: [advisory-group] Welcoming Tetsuya Nakamura, CableLabs
message_text:
OpenDaylight Advisory Group,

Please join me in welcoming Tetsuya Nakamura as the newest OpenDaylight
Advisor.

Tetsuya Nakamura serves as Principal Architect, Strategy and Innovation
Group at CableLabs. Tetsuya is leading CableLabs? open source research
efforts on NFV and SDN, and the Board member of OPNFV. Before joining
CableLabs, Tetsuya worked at NTT for about 17 years. While at NTT DOCOMO,
Tetsuya was in charge of NFV investigation for mobile networks, and
actively involved in the ETSI NFV ISG as ISG Vice Chair, Vice Chair of
Technical Steering Committee, and Chair of Software Architecture WG. Also,
Tetsuya was a founder of OPNFV and the initial Board member for NTT DOCOMO.
Tetsuya received B.S degree in Physics from Kyoto University and M.E degree
in Engineering from The University of Tokyo.

-- 
*Todd Benzies*
Senior Program Manager
The Linux Foundation
+1 (415) 412-0310 (m)
tbenzies at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: tbenzies

Sent: Wednesday, February 03, 2016 22:15
To: advisory-group <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: [advisory-group] Welcoming Tetsuya Nakamura, CableLabs

OpenDaylight Advisory Group,

Please join me in welcoming Tetsuya Nakamura as the newest OpenDaylight Advisor.

Tetsuya Nakamura serves as Principal Architect, Strategy and Innovation Group at CableLabs. Tetsuya is leading CableLabs? open source research efforts on NFV and SDN, and the Board member of OPNFV. Before joining CableLabs, Tetsuya worked at NTT for about 17 years. While at NTT DOCOMO, Tetsuya was in charge of NFV investigation for mobile networks, and actively involved in the ETSI NFV ISG as ISG Vice Chair, Vice Chair of Technical Steering Committee, and Chair of Software Architecture WG. Also, Tetsuya was a founder of OPNFV and the initial Board member for NTT DOCOMO. Tetsuya received B.S degree in Physics from Kyoto University and M.E degree in Engineering from The University of Tokyo.

--
Todd Benzies
Senior Program Manager
The Linux Foundation

subject: [advisory-group] Quote for ODL Beryllium press release
message_text:
Hello ODL AG,

We'd like to include input and perspective from the AG into some of our
launch materials for Beyllium. If you'd be willing to draft a short quote
in support of the launch --from either your individual or company
perspective --we'd be more than happy to include in the press release
(current draft is attached for reference).

If you're interested, please pass along a quote with your name and title
attached by Thursday afternoon, Feb. 17.

Let us know if there are questions, and thank you in advance!

Jill


-- 
*Jill Lovato*
PR Manager
The Linux Foundation
jlovato at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: jill.lovato1
Phone: +1.503.703.8268

subject: [advisory-group] Tomorrow's Call - Postponed
message_text:
OpenDaylight Advisory Group,

Given several last-minute scheduling conflicts and travel schedule
conflicts, tomorrow's Advisory Group call will be cancelled.  The regular
cadence will resume on Thursday 3/17.

That said, if Advisors are available, we can schedule an ad hoc call on
Thursday 3/3 (to replace the call being cancelled tomorrow).  Please send
me a private note indicating whether or not you would be available for 3/3
at 8:00am PT.

Regards,

Todd

-- 
*Todd Benzies*
Senior Program Manager
The Linux Foundation
+1 (415) 412-0310 (m)
tbenzies at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: tbenzies

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/advisory-group/attachments/20160217/a95bda79/attachment.html>

subject: [advisory-group] Next ODL board meeting
message_text:
Advisors,

I've been asked to give a readout on AG activities at the next in-person ODL board meeting which is on March 2nd.

I will of course give a summary of our 2015 activities. Are there any other topics the AG would like me to bring up? Are there more areas we could be involved with?

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
Chris, I suggest we add statistics to measure community participation, individuals, companies in different areas or ways as an area to improve. I have officers in att who have access to the ODL links which influence some of their decisions and opinions. so the right stats and accuracies are becoming important. 
There is movement afoot in OPNFV, LF, and Openstack to work together on this. ODL should join this

Margaret Chiosi

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
I've not been following this. Do you (or anyone) have examples of how participation is measured and presented?

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
Openstack uses stacklytics:
http://stackalytics.com/

Opnfv uses Bitergia
http://projects.bitergia.com/opnfv/browser/

ODL used to have Spectrometer, spectrometer is forked from stacklytics and customized for ODL, it stopped working about half a year ago, spectrometer is current an ODL project, Tom Nadeau is the PTL for that project. 

Bitergia approached ODL a couple of days ago at Linux collaboration summit to see if ODL would like use them for statistics.

George

-----Original Message-----

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
There was an effort inside ODL to port stackalytics. It was called
spectrometer and Dave Tucker wrote it. When he left Red Hat for Socketplane
and then Docker, we had difficulty maintaining it and eventually it was
out-of-date and broken enough that it was taken down.

There's a new effort to bring it back up here:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/Spectrometer

If you'd like to help out, please do so. I agree having visibility into
this again would be huge.

--Colin

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
Bitergia had the features I would be looking for on companies, health of the community, key contributers.
Seemed to paint a lot faster than openhub.org but maybe its doing a lot less.

Too bad it seems like it?s a paid for service.

Surprised Openstack is listed on the users/references page.

Brian

message_text:
it is opensource. the discussion is to have them set it up and then we can run and maintain. the problem as a bunch of volunteers it isn't trivial to maintain. as I said Openstack folks may also be looking at them. so we want to join forces

Margaret Chiosi

subject: [advisory-group] statistics on ODL
message_text:
Colin: we all are having issues on maintaining stats. Which is why there is a discussion going on between Openstack, OPNFV and Bitergia. So the question is can we pull our resources together to do this once for all of us.
Talk with Neela since he has talked with Bitergia.

Opnfv uses Bitergia

ODL used to have Spectrometer, spectrometer is forked from stacklytics and customized for ODL, it stopped working about half a year ago, spectrometer is current an ODL project, Tom Nadeau is the PTL for that project.

Bitergia approached ODL a couple of days ago at Linux collaboration summit to see if ODL would like use them for statistics.

George

subject:
[advisory-group] Fwd: I need help answering questions from Comcast
	on the MD-SAL
message_text:
Hello Advisory Group Members:

Thanks to Sameer Patel and Jason Schnitzer for presenting their work at
Comcast with ODL and the PCMM plugin originally created by Cable Labs.

During the presentation, we walked through the observations/questions that
this team had while developing their Demos/PoCs that is attached as a word
document to this email.

I forwarded these materials yesterday to a couple of the lead developers
within OpenDaylight and the MD-SAL project.  Their responses are below.
For follow up, I suggest that Sameer and Jason start a thread on either the
controller-dev at lists.opendaylight.org or the
mdsal-dev at lists.opendaylight.org email list referencing their original
observations and the responses provided thus far by Colin and Robert.  From
there a more specific dialog can take place for each of the topics.

Best,

Phil.

Forwarded conversation
Subject: I need help answering questions from Comcast on the MD-SAL
------------------------

From: *Phil Robb* <probb at linuxfoundation.org>
Date: Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 11:05 AM
To: Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com>, Robert Varga <nite at hq.sk>


Hey Robert and Colin:

Comcast is presenting at the ODL Advisory Group tomorrow morning.  Along
with the slides they are presenting, I also receive a word document (both
attached) with observations/questions they are asking with regard to ODL
MD-SAL features/capabilities... particularly in the context of how they see
the MD-SAL being used by the PCMM plugin developed by CableLabs.

It would be great to have answers and suggested-paths-forward for these
guys during the call tomorrow morning.  Would you be able to provide me
with answers to the questions/observations in the attached word doc. and
even better, be able to attend the Advisory Group meeting tomorrow morning
(PDT time)?

Meeting Logistics are:
Unless otherwise noted regular meetings are held at 8:00am Pacific Time,
11:00am Eastern Time, on the third Thursday of each month.
WebEx:
https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/meetings/join?uuid=M0KKZ7N2BFGOV5DMTGNLU0I048-9VIB
Phone: +1-415-655-0001 (Access code: 190 042 215)
IRC: chat.freenode.net #opendaylight-users

AG Wiki Page:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Advisory_Group:Main

Thanks very much for your help on this.

Phil.

<snip>
-- 
Phil Robb
Sr. Director Of Technical Operations
OpenDaylight Project
(O) 970-229-5949
(M) 970-420-4292
Skype: Phil.Robb

----------
From: *Colin Dixon* <colin at colindixon.com>
Date: Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 12:40 PM
To: Phil Robb <probb at linuxfoundation.org>
Cc: Robert Varga <nite at hq.sk>


1.) In order to get transactional behavior from the northbound you need to
either (a) write to the config data store and then poll the operational
data store until it looks the way you'd expect, which is what it sounds
like they're doing or (b) implement an RPC and call that to accomplish your
transaction, which might better suit their needs.

2.) I think you can do an update. Usually this is by doing a PUT to a lower
point in the data tree to only change what you need. This can also be
accomplished using the Java data store API of merge to leave other parts
untouched, which is a bit more powerful. I'm pretty sure we also added
support for HTTP PATCH, which should allow similar things.

3.) We support this via Notifications. The are exposed NB from OpenDaylight
over WebSockets.

4.) It is true that right now our data store replication is not pipelined,
which means that the throughput for transactions is 1/latency to another
instance. This is something we are aware of and could be fixed. In the
short-run, if you batch more "operations" into each transaction, this
should help mitigate the negative impact of the limit.

5.) Our logging definitely leaves something to be desired at times. We have
logging best practices [0], but they aren't always followed and likely
aren't complete. Improving this is an ongoing effort in which we'd love
help.

--Colin

[0] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/Logging_Best_Practices


----------
From: *Phil Robb* <probb at linuxfoundation.org>
Date: Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 8:13 PM
To: Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com>
Cc: Robert Varga <nite at hq.sk>


Thanks very much for your insights Colin.

Phil

----------
From: *Robert Varga* <nite at hq.sk>
Date: Thu, Apr 21, 2016 at 2:27 AM
To: Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com>, Phil Robb <probb at linuxfoundation.org
>


On 04/20/2016 08:40 PM, Colin Dixon wrote:
> 1.) In order to get transactional behavior from the northbound you need
> to either (a) write to the config data store and then poll the
> operational data store until it looks the way you'd expect, which is
> what it sounds like they're doing or (b) implement an RPC and call that
> to accomplish your transaction, which might better suit their needs.

Agreed, PCEP already does this: the RPC call does not return until the
network element acks it.

NETCONF operations, being a pass-through data store access, always
operate synchronously.

> 2.) I think you can do an update. Usually this is by doing a PUT to a
> lower point in the data tree to only change what you need. This can also
> be accomplished using the Java data store API of merge to leave other
> parts untouched, which is a bit more powerful. I'm pretty sure we also
> added support for HTTP PATCH, which should allow similar things.

Yup, MERGE is the operation they want, and RESTCONF PATCH allows them to
do that -- committed in Boron and Beryllium SR2.

> 3.) We support this via Notifications. The are exposed NB from
> OpenDaylight over WebSockets.

Also, data store operations are driven via "notifications" -- depends on
what exactly is they want to listen for.

> 4.) It is true that right now our data store replication is not
> pipelined, which means that the throughput for transactions is 1/latency
> to another instance. This is something we are aware of and could be
> fixed. In the short-run, if you batch more "operations" into each
> transaction, this should help mitigate the negative impact of the limit.

This a multi-faceted question:
- memory efficiency suffers when replicated, but PCMM probably does not
care. Tracked as a requirement from BGP, post-Boron (BUG-5718 is a
prerequisite)
- transaction pipelining *will* be fixed in Boron, BUG-5419
- switching masters is pretty much a "restart apps" thing (at least
judging by the code, not sure what the operational experience is),
BUG-5280, will be fixed in Boron
- adding a node should not have a large-scale impact

For testing -- Vratko is currently designing the test suite, IIRC.

> 5.) Our logging definitely leaves something to be desired at times. We
> have logging best practices [0], but they aren't always followed and
> likely aren't complete. Improving this is an ongoing effort in which

subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
OK, my pet topic!!! ?

One of the possible selling points in an HA setup would be EASE of configuration. Currently there are several ways of hiding HA setups in routers. They depend protocols below (i.e. HSRP,etc. ). However, they tend to be cumbersome because you need to have multiple, synchronised copies of RIB residing in all possible speakers, so that any of them can take over in case of failure of the active one. This is not AFI but protocol specific?

If we are able to provide a clean solution that is easy to understand, I know a couple of people who would be quite happy.

Then I would also like us to understand the implications of using BMP data in our apps. It is extremely tempting, but I?m sure we will face (positive) feedback loops with more than just probable oscillation danger. I think we may be in a good position to discuss guidelines to avoid nasty things like this. Any incident might be quite devastating for our

Best, /PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

Technology Exploration -
Network Innovation & Virtualisation

subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_text:
I?ve entered some feedback/wish list into the BGPCEP project mailing list that covers things we would like to see wrt clustering for BGP-LS and PCEP.

Copied below.
---

A few notes on BGP HA clustering.


1.       BGP-LS/ BGP

a.       Today we design around the clustering capability in Li/Be by having separate sessions to each node in the cluster.

                                                               i.      For a 3 node cluster we have the route reflector establish a session to each ODL node.

                                                             ii.      Per advice from the community we setup BGP for a non-replicating shard so that the data is not replicated on each node.

                                                           iii.      Our application checks the status of connectivity and looks for the first available ODL node that has a connected state with the route reflector

b.      We would like to be able to have at least the session data shared across the 3 sessions.

                                                               i.      We would like to have the data in the LOCRIB available in a single shard so that we could interact with the shard leader even if there were sessions from each ODL node to the route reflectors

                                                             ii.      We would really like to have the BGP southbound session move with the shard leader so that we did not have to consume 3 BGP sessions from each route reflector that we interact with.

2.       PCEP

a.       Today we point the routers at one node in the ODL cluster with a  primary/second site strategy because we are limited by the number of PCEP end points we want to setup in the routers.

b.      We would like to have a mechanism where the PCEP sessions from the routers come up into a floating IP that would move with the shard leader.

c.       The floating IP could be on a primary/second adaptor or some other mechanism that could handle single node failure and still get the data to md-sal so that the application and send update-lsp commands even if there was 1 node down in the cluster.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 2:29 AM
To: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

+1.

As mentioned during the AG call maybe we can at the very least:

?         Provide an overview of the related challenges/problems

?         Devise best practices and recommendations on how to mitigate the problems that doesn?t have those clean solutions you?re referring to..

BR,
Johan

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ
Sent: den 20 maj 2016 8:11
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

OK, my pet topic!!! ?

One of the possible selling points in an HA setup would be EASE of configuration. Currently there are several ways of hiding HA setups in routers. They depend protocols below (i.e. HSRP,etc. ). However, they tend to be cumbersome because you need to have multiple, synchronised copies of RIB residing in all possible speakers, so that any of them can take over in case of failure of the active one. This is not AFI but protocol specific?

If we are able to provide a clean solution that is easy to understand, I know a couple of people who would be quite happy.

Then I would also like us to understand the implications of using BMP data in our apps. It is extremely tempting, but I?m sure we will face (positive) feedback loops with more than just probable oscillation danger. I think we may be in a good position to discuss guidelines to avoid nasty things like this. Any incident might be quite devastating for our

Best, /PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_text:
Did you get any feedback on the feasibility of the suggestions?

I guess in the PCEP case you?re talking about something like keepalived moving the active IP between nodes. I don?t see ODL doing that, but then we?ll need a way to make sure what keepalived thinks is true is in face true. Also, can?t we have PCE initiated PCEP sessions? Or am I imagining that?

Chris.

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of FREEMAN, BRIAN D
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 09:54
To: johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com; pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP


I?ve entered some feedback/wish list into the BGPCEP project mailing list that covers things we would like to see wrt clustering for BGP-LS and PCEP.

Copied below.
---

A few notes on BGP HA clustering.


1.       BGP-LS/ BGP

a.       Today we design around the clustering capability in Li/Be by having separate sessions to each node in the cluster.

                                                                  i.      For a 3 node cluster we have the route reflector establish a session to each ODL node.

                                                                 ii.      Per advice from the community we setup BGP for a non-replicating shard so that the data is not replicated on each node.

                                                               iii.      Our application checks the status of connectivity and looks for the first available ODL node that has a connected state with the route reflector

b.      We would like to be able to have at least the session data shared across the 3 sessions.

                                                                  i.      We would like to have the data in the LOCRIB available in a single shard so that we could interact with the shard leader even if there were sessions from each ODL node to the route reflectors

                                                                 ii.      We would really like to have the BGP southbound session move with the shard leader so that we did not have to consume 3 BGP sessions from each route reflector that we interact with.

2.       PCEP

a.       Today we point the routers at one node in the ODL cluster with a  primary/second site strategy because we are limited by the number of PCEP end points we want to setup in the routers.

b.      We would like to have a mechanism where the PCEP sessions from the routers come up into a floating IP that would move with the shard leader.

c.       The floating IP could be on a primary/second adaptor or some other mechanism that could handle single node failure and still get the data to md-sal so that the application and send update-lsp commands even if there was 1 node down in the cluster.

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
AG members:

ODL has created a Trademark Working Group (TWG) to discuss if/how to modify
our trademark policy to include "badges" that can be used by
vendors/providers. The purpose is twofold:

1) A signal to end users that "badged" products meet certain technical
requirements they may be seeking.

2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform,
and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users.

OpenStack's badge system models most closely what we've been discussing, if
that is familiar to you. There is consensus that the TWG would like an "ODL
powered" designation now, and an "ODL compatible" designation down the road
as the ecosystem grows. We are also discussing pros/cons of an "ODL
distribution" designation. See the attached doc for details.

Our key questions for you are:

1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why
not? What would be most meaningful?

2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL
powered" badge to market your own solutions?

Feel free to reply directly to me or to the group. We appreciate your
input. Holler with questions. Thanks!

-- 
Melissa Logan
Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight
mlogan at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: mklogan
503-317-8498

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
I would think ?powered? and a ?distro? should be the same. There should be a core set of project that must be supported. As an user I want to know I get a minimum amount of interoperability, flexibility, and fungibility across distros. You don?t want to keep vendors from adding proprietary code, components, or modifying projects but there should be some amount of code that is always unmodified. It would make life much easier for many compatible apps as well.

Best,

Vesko

Cybersecurity Product Management

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Melissa Logan
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 12:32 AM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
Subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

AG members:

ODL has created a Trademark Working Group (TWG) to discuss if/how to modify our trademark policy to include "badges" that can be used by vendors/providers. The purpose is twofold:

1) A signal to end users that "badged" products meet certain technical requirements they may be seeking.

2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users.

OpenStack's badge system models most closely what we've been discussing, if that is familiar to you. There is consensus that the TWG would like an "ODL powered" designation now, and an "ODL compatible" designation down the road as the ecosystem grows. We are also discussing pros/cons of an "ODL distribution" designation. See the attached doc for details.

Our key questions for you are:

1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

Feel free to reply directly to me or to the group. We appreciate your input. Holler with questions. Thanks!

--
Melissa Logan
Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight
mlogan at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:mlogan at linuxfoundation.org>
Skype: mklogan
503-317-8498

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Hello Melissa
I think these kind of label are important for a service provider

1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?
>Yes mainly ODL compatible, my preference is to change it to ?ODL certified?, this will facilitate the selection of ODL products

2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
Hey Melissa:

> Our key questions for you are:

> 1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

?ODL Powered? and ?ODL distribution? may be too close and create confusion?

> 2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

That has implications that go well beyond my attributions, but I could at least try to poke responsible people?

subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_text:
Any details you can share on what you intend to do with it? Or shortcomings you currently see?

Chris.

Fecha: viernes, 20 de mayo de 2016, 21:20
Para: "FREEMAN, BRIAN D" <bf1936 at att.com<mailto:bf1936 at att.com>>, "johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>" <johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>>, paag <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>>, "advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>" <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>

I guess in the PCEP case you?re talking about something like keepalived moving the active IP between nodes. I don?t see ODL doing that, but then we?ll need a way to make sure what keepalived thinks is true is in face true. Also, can?t we have PCE initiated PCEP sessions? Or am I imagining that?

Chris.

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of FREEMAN, BRIAN D
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 09:54
To: johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>; pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP


I?ve entered some feedback/wish list into the BGPCEP project mailing list that covers things we would like to see wrt clustering for BGP-LS and PCEP.

Copied below.
---

A few notes on BGP HA clustering.


1.       BGP-LS/ BGP

a.       Today we design around the clustering capability in Li/Be by having separate sessions to each node in the cluster.

                                                                              i.      For a 3 node cluster we have the route reflector establish a session to each ODL node.

                                                                            ii.      Per advice from the community we setup BGP for a non-replicating shard so that the data is not replicated on each node.

                                                                           iii.      Our application checks the status of connectivity and looks for the first available ODL node that has a connected state with the route reflector

b.      We would like to be able to have at least the session data shared across the 3 sessions.

                                                                              i.      We would like to have the data in the LOCRIB available in a single shard so that we could interact with the shard leader even if there were sessions from each ODL node to the route reflectors

                                                                            ii.      We would really like to have the BGP southbound session move with the shard leader so that we did not have to consume 3 BGP sessions from each route reflector that we interact with.

2.       PCEP

a.       Today we point the routers at one node in the ODL cluster with a  primary/second site strategy because we are limited by the number of PCEP end points we want to setup in the routers.

b.      We would like to have a mechanism where the PCEP sessions from the routers come up into a floating IP that would move with the shard leader.

c.       The floating IP could be on a primary/second adaptor or some other mechanism that could handle single node failure and still get the data to md-sal so that the application and send update-lsp commands even if there was 1 node down in the cluster.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 2:29 AM
To: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

+1.

As mentioned during the AG call maybe we can at the very least:

?         Provide an overview of the related challenges/problems

?         Devise best practices and recommendations on how to mitigate the problems that doesn?t have those clean solutions you?re referring to..

BR,
Johan

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ
Sent: den 20 maj 2016 8:11
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

OK, my pet topic!!! ?

One of the possible selling points in an HA setup would be EASE of configuration. Currently there are several ways of hiding HA setups in routers. They depend protocols below (i.e. HSRP,etc. ). However, they tend to be cumbersome because you need to have multiple, synchronised copies of RIB residing in all possible speakers, so that any of them can take over in case of failure of the active one. This is not AFI but protocol specific?

If we are able to provide a clean solution that is easy to understand, I know a couple of people who would be quite happy.

Then I would also like us to understand the implications of using BMP data in our apps. It is extremely tempting, but I?m sure we will face (positive) feedback loops with more than just probable oscillation danger. I think we may be in a good position to discuss guidelines to avoid nasty things like this. Any incident might be quite devastating for our

Best, /PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

As promised: BGP, let?s talk about it!

In particular, we?ve had a couple of members mention issues with BGP sessions in an HA environment now. Can we discuss how we?d like to see this issue addressed?

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_text:
I don?t know if Pedro has run into this but we are using  PCEP to update tunnels but when we want to create tunnels the options that we want to set aren?t available in the PCEP standard so we have to use the CLI/Netconf to create the tunnel and then PCEP to update bandwidth and tunnel path.
We might have a weird case because we have existing tunnels that we delegate to the controller and its only on a split/merge to create new longer latency paths for more capacity around an outage that we need to create/delete tunnels.

We also fallback to distributed if the controller is down ?

Brian

Para: "FREEMAN, BRIAN D" <bf1936 at att.com<mailto:bf1936 at att.com>>, "johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>" <johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>>, paag <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>>, "advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>" <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Asunto: RE: [advisory-group] BGP

Did you get any feedback on the feasibility of the suggestions?

I guess in the PCEP case you?re talking about something like keepalived moving the active IP between nodes. I don?t see ODL doing that, but then we?ll need a way to make sure what keepalived thinks is true is in face true. Also, can?t we have PCE initiated PCEP sessions? Or am I imagining that?

Chris.

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of FREEMAN, BRIAN D
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 09:54
To: johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>; pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP


I?ve entered some feedback/wish list into the BGPCEP project mailing list that covers things we would like to see wrt clustering for BGP-LS and PCEP.

Copied below.
---

A few notes on BGP HA clustering.


1.       BGP-LS/ BGP

a.       Today we design around the clustering capability in Li/Be by having separate sessions to each node in the cluster.

                                                                              i.      For a 3 node cluster we have the route reflector establish a session to each ODL node.

                                                                            ii.      Per advice from the community we setup BGP for a non-replicating shard so that the data is not replicated on each node.

                                                                           iii.      Our application checks the status of connectivity and looks for the first available ODL node that has a connected state with the route reflector

b.      We would like to be able to have at least the session data shared across the 3 sessions.

                                                                              i.      We would like to have the data in the LOCRIB available in a single shard so that we could interact with the shard leader even if there were sessions from each ODL node to the route reflectors

                                                                            ii.      We would really like to have the BGP southbound session move with the shard leader so that we did not have to consume 3 BGP sessions from each route reflector that we interact with.

2.       PCEP

a.       Today we point the routers at one node in the ODL cluster with a  primary/second site strategy because we are limited by the number of PCEP end points we want to setup in the routers.

b.      We would like to have a mechanism where the PCEP sessions from the routers come up into a floating IP that would move with the shard leader.

c.       The floating IP could be on a primary/second adaptor or some other mechanism that could handle single node failure and still get the data to md-sal so that the application and send update-lsp commands even if there was 1 node down in the cluster.


From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>
Sent: Friday, May 20, 2016 2:29 AM
To: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

+1.

As mentioned during the AG call maybe we can at the very least:

?         Provide an overview of the related challenges/problems

?         Devise best practices and recommendations on how to mitigate the problems that doesn?t have those clean solutions you?re referring to..

BR,
Johan

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ
Sent: den 20 maj 2016 8:11
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] BGP

OK, my pet topic!!! ?

One of the possible selling points in an HA setup would be EASE of configuration. Currently there are several ways of hiding HA setups in routers. They depend protocols below (i.e. HSRP,etc. ). However, they tend to be cumbersome because you need to have multiple, synchronised copies of RIB residing in all possible speakers, so that any of them can take over in case of failure of the active one. This is not AFI but protocol specific?

If we are able to provide a clean solution that is easy to understand, I know a couple of people who would be quite happy.

Then I would also like us to understand the implications of using BMP data in our apps. It is extremely tempting, but I?m sure we will face (positive) feedback loops with more than just probable oscillation danger. I think we may be in a good position to discuss guidelines to avoid nasty things like this. Any incident might be quite devastating for our

Best, /PA
---
Dr. Pedro A. Aranda Guti?rrez

Network Innovation & Virtualisation

Asunto: [advisory-group] BGP

As promised: BGP, let?s talk about it!

In particular, we?ve had a couple of members mention issues with BGP sessions in an HA environment now. Can we discuss how we?d like to see this issue addressed?

Cheers,
Chris.
