subject: [advisory-group] BGP
message_text:
Somehow its reassuring to know we aren?t alone ?

From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 9:04 AM
To: FREEMAN, BRIAN D; PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ; johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] BGP

I think that?s a fairly well known limitation of PCEP. You can create certain types of tunnel but it?s not enough of the service to be useful.

Chris.


From: FREEMAN, BRIAN D [mailto:bf1936 at att.com]
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 08:57
To: Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com>>; PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ <pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com<mailto:pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com>>; johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com<mailto:johan.gustawsson at teliasonera.com>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: RE: [advisory-group] BGP

I don?t know if Pedro has run into this but we are using  PCEP to update tunnels but when we want to create tunnels the options that we want to set aren?t available in the PCEP standard so we have to use the CLI/Netconf to create the tunnel and then PCEP to update bandwidth and tunnel path.
We might have a weird case because we have existing tunnels that we delegate to the controller and its only on a split/merge to create new longer latency paths for more capacity around an outage that we need to create/delete tunnels.

We also fallback to distributed if the controller is down ?

Brian


From: Luke, Chris [mailto:Chris_Luke at cable.comcast.com]
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 8:07 AM

Subject: RE: [advisory-group] BGP

Any details you can share on what you intend to do with it? Or shortcomings you currently see?

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
I think these badges are reasonably defined except a minor comment about ?OLD distribution? where we could use an adj for a consistent look-and-feel.

I have one question regarding ?ODL Powered?. Do we want to make it optional? The flexibility here would be more encouraging (the use ODL as base).  The other alternative is to make it mandatory for ODL members. How would other AG folks think about it?

 

Alex

 

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 3:32 AM
To: Melissa Logan <mlogan at linuxfoundation.org>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: Neela Jacques <njacques at linuxfoundation.org>; Pankaj Chawla <pchawla at linuxfoundation.org>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

 

Hey Melissa:

 

> Our key questions for you are:

 

> 1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

 

?ODL Powered? and ?ODL distribution? may be too close and create confusion?

 

> 2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

 

That has implications that go well beyond my attributions, but I could at least try to poke responsible people?

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
A.      My brand folks are probably not a fan of mandatory.

B.      A Badge program makes a lot of sense and we?ve seen value from the Openstack badge program that reinforces some type of program as being useful.

C.


> 1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

Not sure we need 3 designations but for adaptors and applications it would be good to have a program that suppliers could use to be ?certified?

> 2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

I cant say. We have used logo?s when it makes sense in technical presentations but overall I think our PR folks are conservative on those things.

Alex

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Greetings,

Here is what I think:


1)     Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful? I believe that these designations are very important since we expect to have some level of verification, validation as stated by many of us here. We need the assurance level of openness and standardizations, and compliance.

2)     2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users. Indeed why not.









From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Melissa Logan
Sent: Thursday, June 02, 2016 5:32 PM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
Subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

AG members:

ODL has created a Trademark Working Group (TWG) to discuss if/how to modify our trademark policy to include "badges" that can be used by vendors/providers. The purpose is twofold:

1) A signal to end users that "badged" products meet certain technical requirements they may be seeking.

2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users.

OpenStack's badge system models most closely what we've been discussing, if that is familiar to you. There is consensus that the TWG would like an "ODL powered" designation now, and an "ODL compatible" designation down the road as the ecosystem grows. We are also discussing pros/cons of an "ODL distribution" designation. See the attached doc for details.

Our key questions for you are:

1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

Feel free to reply directly to me or to the group. We appreciate your input. Holler with questions. Thanks!

--
Melissa Logan
Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight
mlogan at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:mlogan at linuxfoundation.org>
Skype: mklogan
503-317-8498

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Thank you for the input so far.

The "ODL certified" descriptor is great and as a term is well
recognized/understood.

Badges would be elective not mandatory unless folks feel strongly
otherwise. We did discuss that to get badge(s) one should be a member. That
is a common requirement for these programs. Or we could offer a discounted
rate for members versus non members (also common).

Regarding having both "powered" and "distro", most are suggesting just
powered.

Jamil, in your last note what you describe is a distro whereas the
"powered" designation is simpler by design to include just MD-SAL and
Controller as the core components. This provides basic interoperability
while allowing vendors to develop on top/around as Vesko stated.

Other thoughts/comments welcome, we appreciate it.

Melissa

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Not sure about ? ODL certified?,  certified is a ?strong? and serious word, typically involves a certification program. Is it  ready to go that far (heavy) ?  I think  ?ODL compatible? sounds more relaxed, perhaps a bit room for anyone who is interested, more towards community-style, so to speak.

 

Alex

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Hi,
It would certainly be useful for me as an end user to see the ODL Certified badge against vendor apps. The most value would be in a formal certification program. The key thing is to avoid any ambiguity as to what the certification really means in terms of what has been tested.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Thank you, Jon and Alex.

Thinking of the TWG is that we would pursue "powered" now, and
"compatible/certified" further down the road, perhaps 18 months or more as
the ecosystem grows.

Does this group see compatible and certified as two distinct programs or
could they be one that encompasses apps, hardware etc? Would love thoughts
here. (The latter was where we were leaning.)

De: <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> en nombre de Melissa Logan <mlogan at linuxfoundation.org>
Fecha: martes, 7 de junio de 2016, 7:01
Para: "jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com" <jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>
CC: Neela Jacques <njacques at linuxfoundation.org>, Pankaj Chawla <pchawla at linuxfoundation.org>, "advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org" <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Asunto: Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

Thank you, Jon and Alex.

Thinking of the TWG is that we would pursue "powered" now, and "compatible/certified" further down the road, perhaps 18 months or more as the ecosystem grows.

Does this group see compatible and certified as two distinct programs or could they be one that encompasses apps, hardware etc? Would love thoughts here. (The latter was where we were leaning.)


On Mon, Jun 6, 2016 at 2:28 AM, <jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com<mailto:jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>> wrote:
Hi,
It would certainly be useful for me as an end user to see the ODL Certified badge against vendor apps. The most value would be in a formal certification program. The key thing is to avoid any ambiguity as to what the certification really means in terms of what has been tested.

Jon Beasley
Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
Thomson Reuters
Phone: 0207 542 6674
Mobile 07920 230623

Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

Not sure about ? ODL certified?,  certified is a ?strong? and serious word, typically involves a certification program. Is it  ready to go that far (heavy) ?  I think  ?ODL compatible? sounds more relaxed, perhaps a bit room for anyone who is interested, more towards community-style, so to speak.

Alex

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] On Behalf Of Melissa Logan
Sent: Friday, June 03, 2016 10:06 AM
To: CHAWKI Jamil IMT/OLN <jamil.chawki at orange.com<mailto:jamil.chawki at orange.com>>
Cc: Neela Jacques <njacques at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:njacques at linuxfoundation.org>>; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>; Pankaj Chawla <pchawla at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:pchawla at linuxfoundation.org>>
Subject: Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

Thank you for the input so far.

The "ODL certified" descriptor is great and as a term is well recognized/understood.

Badges would be elective not mandatory unless folks feel strongly otherwise. We did discuss that to get badge(s) one should be a member. That is a common requirement for these programs. Or we could offer a discounted rate for members versus non members (also common).

Regarding having both "powered" and "distro", most are suggesting just powered.

Jamil, in your last note what you describe is a distro whereas the "powered" designation is simpler by design to include just MD-SAL and Controller as the core components. This provides basic interoperability while allowing vendors to develop on top/around as Vesko stated.

Other thoughts/comments welcome, we appreciate it.

Melissa


On Fri, Jun 3, 2016 at 8:27 AM, <jamil.chawki at orange.com<mailto:jamil.chawki at orange.com>> wrote:
Additionnel inputs
We need to be sure that for ODL powered  all ODL functionalities and interfaces  are provided by the vendor and not a selected ODL functionalities/features.
for ODL compatible we need also to give a precision on the protocol/interface compatibility
De : advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] De la part de Khaddam, Mazen (CCI-Atlanta)
Envoy? : vendredi 3 juin 2016 17:14
? : Melissa Logan; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Cc : Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
Objet : Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

Greetings,

Here is what I think:


1)      Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful? I believe that these designations are very important since we expect to have some level of verification, validation as stated by many of us here. We need the assurance level of openness and standardizations, and compliance.

2)      2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users. Indeed why not.









From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Melissa Logan
Sent: Thursday, June 02, 2016 5:32 PM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>
Cc: Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
Subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges

AG members:

ODL has created a Trademark Working Group (TWG) to discuss if/how to modify our trademark policy to include "badges" that can be used by vendors/providers. The purpose is twofold:

1) A signal to end users that "badged" products meet certain technical requirements they may be seeking.

2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end users.

OpenStack's badge system models most closely what we've been discussing, if that is familiar to you. There is consensus that the TWG would like an "ODL powered" designation now, and an "ODL compatible" designation down the road as the ecosystem grows. We are also discussing pros/cons of an "ODL distribution" designation. See the attached doc for details.

Our key questions for you are:

1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why not? What would be most meaningful?

2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL powered" badge to market your own solutions?

Feel free to reply directly to me or to the group. We appreciate your input. Holler with questions. Thanks!

--
Melissa Logan
Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight
mlogan at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:mlogan at linuxfoundation.org>
Skype: mklogan
503-317-8498<tel:503-317-8498>

subject: [advisory-group]  You’re Invited! OpenDaylight Community Dinner at OPNFV Summit 2016
message_text:
Dear OpenDaylight Advisory Group Member,

ODL is hosting dinner and drinks as part of the ODL European Mini Summit
<https://www.opendaylight.org/events/2016-06-21-000000/opendaylight-european-mini-summit>
and the OPNFV Summit <http://events.linuxfoundation.org/events/opnfv-summit>
and we want you to join us! This is a great place to network with key
members of the ODL community and to learn more about the project in 2016.

The dinner will be held on Tuesday, June 21 from 7:00pm - 9:30pm
(immediately following the OPNFV Summit Welcome Reception) at Hugos
Restaurant <http://www.hugos-restaurant.de/en/> East Room, Budapester
Stra?e 2 10787 Berlin (located on the 14th-floor of the Intercontinental
Berlin
<http://www.ihg.com/intercontinental/hotels/gb/en/berlin/berha/hoteldetail?cm_mmc=GoogleMaps-_-IC-_-DEU-_-BERHA>
).

Space is limited so RSVP as soon as possible here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1AHgVQ9ev2XuvF062hI7uLJuRlKPeawQ1SgWlV0RL6zk/viewform>
or by emailing abenson at linuxfoundation.org. The RSVP deadline is Monday,
June 13.

The OpenDaylight Events Team will confirm receipt of your RSVP. If you have
questions, please let us know.

Best Regards,

The OpenDaylight Events Team

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
Thanks to all for sharing your input. We have summarized your feedback for
TWG and will be recommending to the board that we proceed with the ODL
Powered badge now, with the goal of launching at ODL Summit.

If you have further questions or input, please let us know.

Melissa

> Thank you, Jon and Alex.
>
>
>
> Thinking of the TWG is that we would pursue "powered" now, and
> "compatible/certified" further down the road, perhaps 18 months or more as
> the ecosystem grows.
>
>
>
> Does this group see compatible and certified as two distinct programs or
> could they be one that encompasses apps, hardware etc? Would love thoughts
> here. (The latter was where we were leaning.)
>
>
>
>
>
> On Mon, Jun 6, 2016 at 2:28 AM, <jonathan.beasley at thomsonreuters.com>
> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> It would certainly be useful for me as an end user to see the ODL
> Certified badge against vendor apps. The most value would be in a formal
> certification program. The key thing is to avoid any ambiguity as to what
> the certification really means in terms of what has been tested.
>
>
>
> *Jon Beasley*
> Principal Architect,  Technical Services and Connectivity
>
> *Thomson Reuters*
>
> Phone: 0207 542 6674
>
> Mobile 07920 230623
> ------------------------------
>
> *From:* advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [
> advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Alex_Zhang [
> alexzhang at chinamobile.com]
> *Sent:* 03 June 2016 20:03
> *To:* 'Melissa Logan'; 'CHAWKI Jamil IMT/OLN'
> *Cc:* 'Neela Jacques'; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org; 'Pankaj
> Chawla'
>
>
> *Subject:* Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark
> Policy/Badges
>
>
>
> Not sure about ? ODL certified?,  certified is a ?strong? and serious
> word, typically involves a certification program. Is it  ready to go that
> far (heavy) ?  I think  ?ODL compatible? sounds more relaxed, perhaps a bit
> room for anyone who is interested, more towards community-style, so to
> speak.
>
>
>
> Alex
>
>
>
> *From:* advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:
> advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] *On Behalf Of *Melissa
> Logan
> *Sent:* Friday, June 03, 2016 10:06 AM
> *To:* CHAWKI Jamil IMT/OLN <jamil.chawki at orange.com>
> *Cc:* Neela Jacques <njacques at linuxfoundation.org>;
> advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org; Pankaj Chawla <
> pchawla at linuxfoundation.org>
> *Subject:* Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark
> Policy/Badges
>
>
>
> Thank you for the input so far.
>
>
>
> The "ODL certified" descriptor is great and as a term is well
> recognized/understood.
>
>
>
> Badges would be elective not mandatory unless folks feel strongly
> otherwise. We did discuss that to get badge(s) one should be a member. That
> is a common requirement for these programs. Or we could offer a discounted
> rate for members versus non members (also common).
>
>
>
> Regarding having both "powered" and "distro", most are suggesting just
> powered.
>
>
>
> Jamil, in your last note what you describe is a distro whereas the
> "powered" designation is simpler by design to include just MD-SAL and
> Controller as the core components. This provides basic interoperability
> while allowing vendors to develop on top/around as Vesko stated.
>
>
>
> Other thoughts/comments welcome, we appreciate it.
>
>
>
> Melissa
>
>
>
>
>
> On Fri, Jun 3, 2016 at 8:27 AM, <jamil.chawki at orange.com> wrote:
>
> Additionnel inputs
>
> We need to be sure that for ODL powered  all ODL functionalities and
> interfaces  are provided by the vendor and not a selected ODL
> functionalities/features.
>
> for ODL compatible we need also to give a precision on the
> protocol/interface compatibility
>
> *De :* advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:
> advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] *De la part de* Khaddam,
> Mazen (CCI-Atlanta)
> *Envoy? :* vendredi 3 juin 2016 17:14
> *? :* Melissa Logan; advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> *Cc :* Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
> *Objet :* Re: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark
> Policy/Badges
>
>
>
> Greetings,
>
>
>
> Here is what I think:
>
>
>
> 1)      Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why
> not? What would be most meaningful? I believe that these designations are
> very important since we expect to have some level of verification,
> validation as stated by many of us here. We need the assurance level of
> openness and standardizations, and compliance.
>
> 2)      2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL
> platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end
> users. Indeed why not.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> *From:* advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [
> mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org
> <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] *On Behalf Of *Melissa
> Logan
> *Sent:* Thursday, June 02, 2016 5:32 PM
> *To:* advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
> *Cc:* Neela Jacques; Pankaj Chawla
> *Subject:* [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark
> Policy/Badges
>
>
>
> AG members:
>
>
>
> ODL has created a Trademark Working Group (TWG) to discuss if/how to
> modify our trademark policy to include "badges" that can be used by
> vendors/providers. The purpose is twofold:
>
>
>
> 1) A signal to end users that "badged" products meet certain technical
> requirements they may be seeking.
>
>
>
> 2) Allow vendors/providers to display their commitment to the ODL
> platform, and raise their industry profile by marketing their badges to end
> users.
>
>
>
> OpenStack's badge system models most closely what we've been discussing,
> if that is familiar to you. There is consensus that the TWG would like an
> "ODL powered" designation now, and an "ODL compatible" designation down the
> road as the ecosystem grows. We are also discussing pros/cons of an "ODL
> distribution" designation. See the attached doc for details.
>
>
>
> Our key questions for you are:
>
>
>
> 1) Are these three designations meaningful to you as an end user; why/why
> not? What would be most meaningful?
>
>
>
> 2) If you are a service provider, would you consider using the "ODL
> powered" badge to market your own solutions?
>
>
>
> Feel free to reply directly to me or to the group. We appreciate your
> input. Holler with questions. Thanks!
>
>
>
> --
>
> Melissa Logan
>
> Head of Marketing, OpenDaylight

> 503-317-8498

subject: [advisory-group] Your input please - ODL Trademark Policy/Badges
message_text:
I'm not sure any of the categories mentioned apply to research teams,
to proven tools that are available but unrelated to products.

Regards

Harvey


On 6/14/2016 6:56 PM, Melissa Logan wrote:
> Thanks to all for sharing your input. We have summarized your feedback 
> for TWG and will be recommending to the board that we proceed with the 
> ODL Powered badge now, with the goal of launching at ODL Summit.
>
> If you have further questions or input, please let us know.
>
> Melissa
>

subject: [advisory-group] Today's OpenDaylight Advisory Group Call
message_text:
Hello Advisory Group Members:

This is a reminder that we have an Advisory Group meeting coming up at the
top of the hour.  Our topics for today are:

- Review of the OpenDaylight-Beryllium Perform Report and plans for the
future.
- Discussion on Edge Computing and the potential value of advocating
CORD-like initiatives encompassing OpenDaylight.

The logistics for the call are below:

OpenDaylight Advisory Group
The 3rd Thursday of every month, from Thu, May 19, 2016 to no end date,
9:00 am | 1 hr

Denver (Mountain Daylight Time, GMT-06:00)
Host: Phil Robb

When it's time, start the meeting from here:
https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/meetings/join?uuid=MCYBAQNO8PMMQ1RD917HIUQRK1-9VIB

Access Information
Where: WebEx Online
Meeting number: 191 365 382
Meeting password: This meeting does not require a password.
Host key: 250348 (Use this key in the meeting if you have made someone else
the host and then want to reclaim the host role.)

Audio Connection
+1-855-797-9485 Call-in toll-free number (US/Canada)
+1-415-655-0002 Call-in toll number (US/Canada)
Access code: 191 365 382
Talk with everyone soon.

Best,

Phil.
-- 
Phil Robb

OpenDaylight Project

subject:
[advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to CORD
	activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
Hello ODL Advisory Group members:

At the last Advisory Group meeting I took the action item to kick off a
discussion thread on the idea of creating an Edge Computing effort similar
to what the ONOS project has done with CORD.

We briefly talked about this at the last Advisory Group meeting and I would
like to solicit further thoughts from you on this topic if possible.
Please feel free to respond with any comments you may have.  For me, the
leading questions I would like your thoughts on include:

- What "flavors" of CORD are most interesting to you?  I believe that
someone on the past AG call noted that M-CORD was interesting and it had
significant similarity to the Mobile Edge Computing  effort (
http://www.etsi.org/technologies-clusters/technologies/mobile-edge-computing).
What is everyone's thought on that?  Are there others and what priority
order should we consider?

- Where are the most likely homes for such and effort and what are the
pros/cons of each?  OPNFV is a logical contender.  Are there others?

- Are there other Open Source groups beyond OPNFV that we should target?

- Any other questions you may have.

Please let me know your thoughts on this when you get the chance.

Best,

Phil.
-- 
Phil Robb
Sr. Director Of Technical Operations
OpenDaylight Project
(O) 970-229-5949
(M) 970-420-4292
Skype: Phil.Robb

subject:
[advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to
	CORD	activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
Hi Phil & folks,

 

Due to key conflicts and travels, missed some recent meetings.  I have some quick thoughts to share here doe discussion?

*       We can call it SDEN ? software defined edge networking/node. 

*       ODL is the network controller for SDEN, to state the obvious ?:)

*       ODL to develop APP (as Service/APP controller) for the SDEN use cases

*       ODL to interface with Open-O perhaps other applicable Open Source Orchestration for Telco SDEN service use cases

 

Use cases wise, I suspect Residential CO would see early and more deployments opportunities.  I believe it is also easier to get (ODL community) started. Second would come to the Analytic SDEN, again it is relatively playing into ODL current strength. IoT SDEN is also a good one for ODL, I suspect some developers would already jump in?

 

Regards,

 

Alex

 

 

From: advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Phil Robb
Sent: Friday, July 01, 2016 1:20 PM
To: advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: [advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to CORD activities) using OpenDaylight

 

Hello ODL Advisory Group members:

 

At the last Advisory Group meeting I took the action item to kick off a discussion thread on the idea of creating an Edge Computing effort similar to what the ONOS project has done with CORD.

 

 

We briefly talked about this at the last Advisory Group meeting and I would like to solicit further thoughts from you on this topic if possible.  Please feel free to respond with any comments you may have.  For me, the leading questions I would like your thoughts on include:

 

- What "flavors" of CORD are most interesting to you?  I believe that someone on the past AG call noted that M-CORD was interesting and it had significant similarity to the Mobile Edge Computing  effort (http://www.etsi.org/technologies-clusters/technologies/mobile-edge-computing).  What is everyone's thought on that?  Are there others and what priority order should we consider?

 

- Where are the most likely homes for such and effort and what are the pros/cons of each?  OPNFV is a logical contender.  Are there others?

 

- Are there other Open Source groups beyond OPNFV that we should target?

 

- Any other questions you may have.

 

Please let me know your thoughts on this when you get the chance.

 

Best,

 

Phil.

-- 

Phil Robb

Sr. Director Of Technical Operations

OpenDaylight Project

(O) 970-229-5949

(M) 970-420-4292

subject:
[advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar
	to	CORD	activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
Hello
Interesting discussion , agree with Alex for SDEN.
In m-cord the ONOS SDN controller and XoS orchestrator are use to control the virtualization function for core and access (vEPC, vBBU ) and mobile edge computing servers.
Mobile edge computing can be considered as cloud openstack solution to deliver compute , storage/cache... to improve mobile services like better latency.
In m-cord , as ONOS the main interface si OF, we don't have a control for the Radio part RRH.
In Opendaylight as its a multi interface controller  we a have now a new radio projects called OCP to implement control and management plan for ORI interface between BBU and RRH.
I think this OCP project is very important and we can position ODL as a controller for 5G CRAN radio access. ODL can also manage the mobile edge computing based on openstack.
I have seen that Foxconn is behind this project and I am interested to have more information about the rational.
Phill, Neela, it's possible to have a presentation on OCP project during our next advisory meeting?
I have ask internally , in Orange , our position on OCP.
Regards
Jamil

message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
Hi folks,

One of the things we should try to investigate as soon as possible is the API between X-OS and ONOS. If we are able to implement it in ODL, ?we? can be a drop-replacement in the M-CORD architecture. Once that is done, ?we? can see how to profit from the plethora of southbound interfaces ?we? support and move M-CORD towards ?our? turf.

Could we profit from the experience in the ONF ATRIUM project?

Best, /PA

PS: but don?t call the API ?Intent? , pls ;-)

---

subject:
[advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to
	CORD	activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
Hi Phil
I'm afraid I missed your session on CORD, however, in answer to your questions:

>>What "flavors" of CORD are most interesting to you

For us its E-CORD and A-CORD. We're looking at E-CORD architecture in particular to solve some of our WAN networking business challenges (cost and agility challenges primarily - ie, the usual).

subject:
[advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to CORD
 activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
I concur with Dr. Guti?rrez.

We are doing some research and experimentation with the M-CORD concept for use at T-Mobile.  So far this has been using the published CORD infrastructure based on ONOS, XOS.  However, ONOS and XOS are currently not the Controller/Orchestrator of choice so we are hoping to see if another Controller/Orchestrator pair can be substituted or, at the very least, be controlled via API from our current choice.

I think it would be very helpful to the acceptance of OpenDaylight if we could develop a similar CORD example that can be used.

Beau Williamson
CCIE #1346 R/S Emeritus
Principal Member of Technical Staff
Corporate Engineering
metroPCS/T-Mobile

Mobile:   972.679.4334

De: <advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>> en nombre de Phil Robb <probb at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:probb at linuxfoundation.org>>
Fecha: viernes, 1 de julio de 2016, 22:20
Para: "advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>" <advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:advisory-group at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Asunto: [advisory-group] Edge Computing Use Cases (similar to CORD activities) using OpenDaylight

Hello ODL Advisory Group members:

At the last Advisory Group meeting I took the action item to kick off a discussion thread on the idea of creating an Edge Computing effort similar to what the ONOS project has done with CORD.

We briefly talked about this at the last Advisory Group meeting and I would like to solicit further thoughts from you on this topic if possible.  Please feel free to respond with any comments you may have.  For me, the leading questions I would like your thoughts on include:

- What "flavors" of CORD are most interesting to you?  I believe that someone on the past AG call noted that M-CORD was interesting and it had significant similarity to the Mobile Edge Computing  effort (http://www.etsi.org/technologies-clusters/technologies/mobile-edge-computing).  What is everyone's thought on that?  Are there others and what priority order should we consider?

- Where are the most likely homes for such and effort and what are the pros/cons of each?  OPNFV is a logical contender.  Are there others?

- Are there other Open Source groups beyond OPNFV that we should target?

- Any other questions you may have.

Please let me know your thoughts on this when you get the chance.

Best,

Phil.
--
Phil Robb
Sr. Director Of Technical Operations
OpenDaylight Project
(O) 970-229-5949
(M) 970-420-4292
Skype: Phil.Robb

subject:

	CORD	activities) using OpenDaylight
message_text:
Hi,

I think much have been said already, but I agree that M-CORD like functionality should be the highest priority. That being said,  E- and R- is of interest as well.

As for Mobile Edge Computing, isn?t that since some time ago based out of the Open Edge Computing (OEC)? Same people, wider scope?
OPNFV definitely seems like a perfect fit, and here?s the presentation on OEC from the recent Summit in Berlin: https://wiki.opnfv.org/display/EVNT/Berlin+Design+Summit+Schedule?preview=%2F6824840%2F6824831%2F2016-06-21+Open+Edge+Computing+-+published+final.pdf

To me, this looks like a good opportunity for ODL and I will check thoughts on this internally as well.

/J

Sorry to ask but does anyone know what is the SDN controller exact role(s) in the reference architectures provided by Edge Computing initiatives like FOG/MEC/OEC?

Also depending on the role, controller will have to support different set of APIs, so are these or other Edge Computing initiatives already working in standardizing these APIs?

BR/Luis

subject: [advisory-group] Today's OpenDaylight Advisory Group Meeting
message_text:
Hello OpenDaylight Advisory Group Members:

This is a quick reminder that we have our monthly meeting coming up at the
top of the hour.

For this month's meeting we have the following topics:

   - Close on CORD/Edge-Computing discussion from ongoing email thread
   - Discuss impending changes to ODL's YANG Models and RESTCONF interface
   and it's impact on end users. How best can the ODL community communicate
   and execute on changes that impact end users?
   - Call for future topics & AG member presentations

If there are any other topics that you would like to add to today's agenda,
please let me know.

Best,

Phil.
-- 
Phil Robb
Sr. Director Of Technical Operations
OpenDaylight Project

(M) 970-420-4292

subject: [advisory-group] Today's OpenDaylight Advisory Group Meeting
message_text:
I am also pretty active in the fd.io community, though mostly a bit lower in the stack than honeycomb. :)

Short version is that Honeycomb is an ODL module that makes use of the auto-generated Java bindings to the binary API of VPP. It aims to produce semantically meaningful abstractions for the dataplane mechanisms; not exposing too much of the internal workings but enough to retain the flexibility it offers. The intention is that you could strip ODL down to the bare essentials and use that as a lean agent on a packet forwarding device. It has some way to go but it is progressing quite well.

Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Fwd: Thanks & next steps
message_text:
Hello Advisory Group Members:

Thanks to Clyde for presenting our training efforts at this morning's
meeting and for the excellent input the Advisory Group members had
participating on the call.

Clyde asked that I forward the note below.  As those on the call know, we
are looking for feedback on the existing course and your suggestions on
what course material would be most useful to your organizations in the next
6 to 18 months.  Please let us know your thoughts!

See everybody at the ODL Summit!

Best,

Phil.
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Clyde <cseepersad at linuxfoundation.org>
Date: Thu, Sep 15, 2016 at 4:03 PM
Subject: Thanks & next steps
To: Phil Robb <probb at linuxfoundation.org>


Hi Phil,

Thanks again for arranging for me to connect to the group this morning. I
don't have access to everyone's email from the invite so could you please
distribute?

Link to the free survey course (range of cloud technologies, including but
not limited to SDN): Introduction to Cloud Infrastructure
<https://www.edx.org/course/introduction-cloud-infrastructure-linuxfoundationx-lfs151-x>

Link to the paid introductory course: SDN Fundamentals
<https://training.linuxfoundation.org/linux-courses/system-administration-training/software-defined-networking-fundamentals>,
use this coupon code to check out at no cost: SDNreview (made this good for
20 so folks can share with team members)

Look forward to getting some more detailed feedback on how to make this one
better.

Regards

Clyde



-- 
Clyde Seepersad
General Manager, Training & Certification
e: cseepersad at linuxfoundation.org
p: 404 964 6973




-- 
Phil Robb
Sr. Director Of Technical Operations
OpenDaylight Project
(O) 970-229-5949
(M) 970-420-4292
Skype: Phil.Robb

subject: [advisory-group] Performance Requirements for ODL Performance Tests
message_text:
At the ODL Summit there was a discussion of input/requirements to the performance testing group. We thought that the advisory group might actually be a good source for where we would want to run automated load/scale testing of ODL. Perhaps some common use cases that the different applications needed to understand better.

I took an action item to start the discussion.

Areas that come to mind; some are already covered in the performance report and others may be too hard to actually test.

Comments ?

Brian

https://www.opendaylight.org/sites/www.opendaylight.org/files/odl_performancetechnicalreport_1-1_052716.pdf



1.       BGP testing

a.       Internet IPv4 route table testing to 1 Million routes

b.      Multiple peer common RIB to 10 Million routes (5 million IPv4, 5 million IPv6)

c.       BGP LS RIB testing [TBD size and rate]

d.      As a route advertiser - BGP updates/second - app -rib to peer path

2.       PCEP testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

3.       Netconf testing

a.       Number of sessions per node

b.      Updates/second per single session - 10K update size (need to look at typical edit-config size and emulate with netopeer)

c.       Clustered NetConf testing

                                                               i.      How long to bring up netconf sessions on new shard leader when moving from 3 node equally distributed netconf cluster to 2 node netconf cluster after failure

d.      Need to test with more typical size yang aggregate model size that we see in production routers/products

                                                               i.       a fake 3 or four tiered yang model could be used.

                                                             ii.      Need to look at the difference between all yang data in one model vs multiple yang models (200+ per device)



4.       OpenFlow testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

5.       OVSDB testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

6.       MD-SAL object scaling

a.       Confirm MD-SAL scale/performance for 3 node cluster with SSD storage

b.      Confirm single node MD-SAL performance with no storage (quoted to be order of 10^6/second)

c.       Maximum number of objects in md-sal / GB of available JVM memory [needs discussion]



-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/advisory-group/attachments/20161003/7e227ebe/attachment.html>

subject:
[advisory-group] Performance Requirements for ODL Performance
 Tests
message_from: pedroa.aranda at telefonica.com (PEDRO ANDRES ARANDA GUTIERREZ)
message_text:
HI folks,

For BPG-4 I miss:

1.       VPNv4 (and possibly VPNv6) support both as a feature and with targets?

2.       Robustness against flapping (routes flapped/sec before rouer collapses)
BR,/PA

---

Asunto: [advisory-group] Performance Requirements for ODL Performance Tests

a.       Internet IPv4 route table testing to 1 Million routes

b.      Multiple peer common RIB to 10 Million routes (5 million IPv4, 5 million IPv6)
-------------- next part --------------

subject:
[advisory-group] Performance Requirements for ODL Performance
 Tests
message_text:
Hi,

I agree, based on our use-cases and implementations, reality might differ from the technical report.

Now that ODL supports RFC7432 it should also minimally include:

?         EVPN route table testing

?         Mass withdrawals

?         Convergence (MAC Mobility)


I was also wondering about performance metrics when running multiple services concurrently. i.e. impacts on scale when running BGP and OVSDB/Openflow concurrently.

Regards,

Daniel Bernier

At the ODL Summit there was a discussion of input/requirements to the performance testing group. We thought that the advisory group might actually be a good source for where we would want to run automated load/scale testing of ODL. Perhaps some common use cases that the different applications needed to understand better.

I took an action item to start the discussion.

Areas that come to mind; some are already covered in the performance report and others may be too hard to actually test.

Comments ?

Brian

https://www.opendaylight.org/sites/www.opendaylight.org/files/odl_performancetechnicalreport_1-1_052716.pdf



1.       BGP testing

a.       Internet IPv4 route table testing to 1 Million routes

b.       Multiple peer common RIB to 10 Million routes (5 million IPv4, 5 million IPv6)

c.       BGP LS RIB testing [TBD size and rate]

d.       As a route advertiser ? BGP updates/second ? app ?rib to peer path

2.       PCEP testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

3.       Netconf testing

a.       Number of sessions per node

b.       Updates/second per single session ? 10K update size (need to look at typical edit-config size and emulate with netopeer)

c.       Clustered NetConf testing

                                                                       i.      How long to bring up netconf sessions on new shard leader when moving from 3 node equally distributed netconf cluster to 2 node netconf cluster after failure

d.       Need to test with more typical size yang aggregate model size that we see in production routers/products

                                                                       i.       a fake 3 or four tiered yang model could be used.

                                                                     ii.      Need to look at the difference between all yang data in one model vs multiple yang models (200+ per device)



4.       OpenFlow testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

5.       OVSDB testing

a.       Anything beyond current performance tests ?

6.       MD-SAL object scaling

a.       Confirm MD-SAL scale/performance for 3 node cluster with SSD storage

b.       Confirm single node MD-SAL performance with no storage (quoted to be order of 10^6/second)

c.       Maximum number of objects in md-sal / GB of available JVM memory [needs discussion]

In term of network size BGP LS and PCEP SDN should control 1000 to 4000 nodes.
Concerning PCEP  performance, it's expected to manage 20 tunnel per second ( 1 -16 million of tunnels for NxN network).

subject: [advisory-group] February AG call conflict
message_text:
Fellow AG members,

The February AG call conflicts with a Linux Foundation leadership summit.

I'm polling to find out if people prefer we:


-          Try to schedule for the week after.

-          Skip the February call; the next one would be the usual date in March.

I suspect trying to schedule for the week before is less likely to succeed since that would be next week; though feel free to indicate this or any other preference.

Please reply to the list or to me; will collate the responses before the end of the week.

Thanks,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] No meeting tomorrow
message_text:
A reminder that, per the discussion a week or so ago, we're not having an AG meeting tomorrow given the conflict with the LF Open Source leadership summit.

Hopefully we'll reschedule it for next week.

Current agenda includes Colin, the TSC chair, giving some updates and seeking feedback on planned features for the Carbon and Nitrogen releases.

Cheers,
Chris.


-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/advisory-group/attachments/20170215/3d7f48b8/attachment.html>

subject: [advisory-group] Agenda for AG call tomorrow
message_text:
Fellow advisors,

Tomorrows agenda is light but we've never had a problem finding things to talk about! We'll ask the TSC for an update and then we can have an open discussion.

One hot topic that has come up is SD-WAN. I'd like see if anyone who has been working on SD-WAN would be willing to talk tomorrow, and perhaps present more fully later. Phil is curious whether people are looking at commercial solutions involving ODL in this space and I am curious how people are stitching the moving parts together. I'll bring up the topic and we can see where it goes.

Also, for anyone planning on being at ONS we might want to talk about organizing an informal gathering.

Thanks!
Chris.
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/advisory-group/attachments/20170315/ce224d16/attachment.html>

subject: [advisory-group] Agenda for AG call tomorrow
message_text:
Hi Chris & team,

Sounds like a very interesting discussion on the positioning of ODL for SD-WAN. Not to precede that discussion, but I think the bigger play for ODL is always going to be vCPE/uCPE use-case. We will probably have 20 different opinions on what the difference in definition is.
Especially considering you ought to look at a "uCPE" as a distributed single-tenant (customer) NFVI - and then start to question what the difference to vCPE is in every other regard than different NFVI tiers. Also, with that in mind, there's nothing stopping you from combining the deployment scenarios that originally were labelled separately as SD-WAN, vCPE and uCPE.

Supposedly, and at least according to our marketing department, we were the first operator in Europe to onboard a customer onto an SD-WAN platform just a few days ago via our Finnish OpCo - Sonera:
http://www.teliacompany.com/en/news/news-articles/2017/sonera-launches-the-first-new-generation-enterprise-network-service-in-europe/

BR,
Johan Gustawsson

Le 15 mars 2017 ? 23:41, Luke, Chris <Chris_Luke at comcast.com<mailto:Chris_Luke at comcast.com>> a ?crit :
Fellow advisors,

Tomorrows agenda is light but we?ve never had a problem finding things to talk about! We?ll ask the TSC for an update and then we can have an open discussion.

One hot topic that has come up is SD-WAN. I?d like see if anyone who has been working on SD-WAN would be willing to talk tomorrow, and perhaps present more fully later. Phil is curious whether people are looking at commercial solutions involving ODL in this space and I am curious how people are stitching the moving parts together. I?ll bring up the topic and we can see where it goes.

Also, for anyone planning on being at ONS we might want to talk about organizing an informal gathering.

Thanks!
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] April Advisory Group Meeting Agenda
message_text:
Hello, everyone.
In this month's Advisory Group call, Olivier Augizeau from Orange will talk
about their transition from an IP/MPLS backbone to SDN.  Would anyone else
like to offer their feedback on their transition efforts or offer insight
as to why they decided to forgo a migration.  There will also be an
opportunity to discuss the ramifications of migration.

Chris will also reserve 10 minutes to discuss agenda topics for May.

As a reminder, the next Advisory Group meeting is on April 20th, 2017 at
8am PST / 15:00 UTC
The Advisory Group wiki page
<https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Advisory_Group:Main>
contains details on how to connect to the meeting and an archive of past
meeting recordings.

Regards,
Casey Cain
-- 
Casey Cain
Technical Program Manager
Linux Foundation
_________________
IRC - CaseyODL
Skype - wrathwolfk
WeChat - okaru6

subject:
[advisory-group] Tomorrow's Advisory Group meeting agenda
	reminder
message_from: paaguti at gmail.com (Pedro Andres Aranda Gutierrez)
message_text:
Hi folks,

maybe one of the topics that could be discussed next month is
repeatibility. As part of my post-Telefonica life, I'm currently teaching
an ODL lab. I decided to use stable/Boron-SR2 for repeatibility. Before the
Easter break, I could generate all the sub files for my projects flawlessly
with mvn archetype. But as of yesterday, it stopped working. It complains
about the default-cli target not being supported.

Problem is the lab is today (Aamof in a couple of hours) :-(

I don't mind (and I even expect) this happening on a development branch,
but I think it should not happen in a stable branch (otherwise, why call it
stable?). Can this be a topic for next month's telco?

Talk2U soon, /Pedro A. Aranda

subject: [advisory-group] Next AG meeting: move it back a week?
message_text:
Fellow Advisors,

Casey noticed that the next scheduled AG meeting falls on top of the Beijing OPNFV summit and suggested we move the AG meeting to avoid it. I propose we push it back one week to the following Thursday.

If nobody objects before the end of Monday next week then that's what we'll do.  (Perhaps let me know if that window is too short; I just want to try to action it before it's forgotten!)

Thanks,
Chris.

message_text:
Colin,

At the ODL Advisory Group meeting this today the question came up about ONAP upgrades and the work with Karaf4 in Nitrogen.

Do you have a set of requirements on upgrade that the community is assuming like making it easy for Service Providers and their developers to do the upgrade of production data and upgrade of their application code to work with Nitrogen ?

Brian

subject: [advisory-group] September ODL AG agenda
message_text:
All,

We cancelled todays call for light attendance; likely everyone is on vacation!

For the September 21st call, we have these topics in mind:


  *   Ahead of the DDF meeting in October, what features and stability improvements are end users looking to see in OpenDaylight? Feel free to discuss on-list, but we'll also make time at the next AG call. Current topics can be found at the wiki: https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/Events:Oxygen_Dev_Forum
  *   Several large changes are upcoming in OpenDaylight which may have significant impact to existing installations of ODL, including in the Karaf 4 and Yang projects. We should discuss ways in which these sorts of changes can be communicated to end users, not least to minimize surprise when they do land.

Cheers,
Chris

subject: [advisory-group] More on the maven issue
message_from: paaguti at gmail.com (Pedro Andres Aranda Gutierrez)
message_text:
Back from holidays, I have retaken the issue on the instructions to create
a development infrastructure. I'm on Carbon-SR1 and when I follow the
instructions on the WIKI (see screenshot) I receive the same error (see log
for better legibility) I did just before the crisis. Obviously the docs
have to change. Now I have the recipe for
Boron :

#!/bin/bash

mvn archetype:generate -DarchetypeGroupId=org.opendaylight.controller
-DarchetypeArtifactId=opendaylight-startup-archetype \
-DarchetypeCatalog=remote \
-DarchetypeVersion=1.2.2-Boron-SR2

However, I have not succeeded in finding the archetypeVersion for
Carbon-SR1.

If someone can tell me what the right versions are, I could give the WIKI a
try and correct the whole procedure.

Best, /PA

PS: I have received a couple of comments from people facing this very issue
and for many it is a showstopper in using ODL. How can they recommend ODL
if the docs are wrong in something as fundamental as this? And I hate to
have to agree with them...

-- 
Fragen sind nicht da um beantwortet zu werden,
Fragen sind da um gestellet zu werden
Georg Kreisler

subject: [advisory-group] Next AG agenda
message_text:
Advisors,

The next AG call is next Thursday, October 19th. https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Advisory_Group:Main#Logistics

I asked Casey if we could have a summary of the DDF which was held this week. He also suggested these topics that ODL would like feedback on:


*         Ask for feedback on stable/experimental features, and breaking up the ODL distribution to a more core release with core features.

*         What might be the next "carrier grade" feature to work on besides In Service Software Upgrades (ISSUs) and what HA metric or scale metric to drive for?

As always, if anyone has other topics please let us know.

Cheers!
Chris

subject: [advisory-group] ODL Advisory Group straw-poll
message_text:
Hi all,

I'd like to find out why attendance on the monthly AG calls has dropped over the last few months.


  *   Is it something simple: The invitation is no longer in your calendar?
  *   Is the timing too inconvenient? (The current time is obviously unkind to our Asian colleagues)
  *   Is the discussion not relevant enough?
  *   Or are you perhaps no longer involved or interested with OpenDaylight?
  *   Too busy and it was the thing that dropped?

And finally, what changes might help increase your participation? What topics or areas of discussion are important to you?

Thanks,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] OpenDaylight Distribution Questionnaire
message_text:
I've invited you to fill out the following form:
OpenDaylight Distribution Questionnaire

To fill it out, visit:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfot_tIffYaIAVE5sjEUzQuLPZ2cs7NGAV79jbkCLA81x8yyQ/viewform?c=0&w=1&usp=mail_form_link

Hello, Advisory members.

The OpenDaylight technical community is seeking feedback regarding the  
distribution of OpenDaylight.

We ask that you complete this poll to help OpenDaylight determine how it  
should distribute OpenDaylight in the future.  There is a discussion on  
releasing a "Core" distribution that may not include all features  
commonly included in the distribution. Other artifacts considered unstable  
would be available as a separate download.  The questions are designed to  
determine how they may affect your Organizations and if you would find  
value in this style of Distribution.

Thank you,
Casey

Google Forms: Create and analyze surveys.

subject: [advisory-group] Today's call
message_text:
HI All

Sorry I cannot join today as this is the last day f SC17
and we have a 3 Tbps Networks for Science
multicontroller and high throughput
setup we are demonstrating.

I need to say that after updating to Carbon our Dell Z9100-ON and
S6100-ON switches would not work and so we were obliged to fall back to 
Boron SR4.

What I think is lacking in the release procedure is an in-depth
validation process on all major switch/routers and their various
firmware releases. This would server to verify that the ODL release is 
fully functioning, OR
to identify problems on each switch/firmware combination so that they
can be dealt with - by the switch vendor or by the ODL community.


Best regards
Harvey

multicontroller and high throughput

I need to say that after updating to Carbon our Dell Z9100-ON and
S6100-ON switches would not work and so we were obliged to fall back to Boron SR4.

What I think is lacking in the release procedure is an in-depth
validation process on all major switch/routers and their various
firmware releases. This would server to verify that the ODL release is fully functioning, OR
to identify problems on each switch/firmware combination so that they
can be dealt with - by the switch vendor or by the ODL community.



Best regards

message_text:

The December meeting of the Advisory Group falls on the 21st.  Due to the
holiday season, I propose that we cancel this month's meeting.

subject: [advisory-group] End User Advisory Group Meeting at ONS
message_text:
Hello ODL EUAG Members:

We wanted to let you know that we are hosting an open meeting of User
Advisory Groups at ONS. It will be a F2F meeting only (no telephone bridge)
and we are extending the invitation to the ODL EUAG, OPNFV EUAG, LFN member
representatives, and other service provider companies.

Now that we have established LF Networking, we'd like to talk to the
operator community about how to evolve the OPNFV EUAG and ODL EUAG going
forward, how to engage with more of the projects within LFN, and to ensure
that we have a strong end user voice in the work of LFN.

This meeting will take place Wednesday, March 28, 2:30 - 3:50 PM in the
KTown Room (across from the business center on the 5th floor on the ONS
venue). If you're going to be present at ONS, we hope that you will attend
this session to give us your views. If you will not be present, but you
will have colleagues in attendance at ONS, please forward this invitation
on them. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out.

Thanks!

--
Min Yu
Senior Operations Analyst
The Linux Foundation
+1(530) 902-6464 (m)
myu at linuxfoundation.org
Skype: minyudecorah

subject: [advisory-group] ODL AG topics for this week?
message_text:
Chris,

Here is my suggestion.

Multi-site clustering using non-voting member provides baseline support for geo-redundant operation but there are limitations both in the degree of automated failover and the performance impacts of large MD-SAL datastore replication during return to service operations.

As more and more applications include micro-service components the interaction of micro-services with MD-SAL and MD-SAL clustering becomes an important design consideration.

What is the roadmap for clustering and in particular geo-redundant operation ?
What is the roadmap for MD-SAL ?
Are there plans for support of micro-services and or broader support for containers as part of ODL ?

Brian

subject: [advisory-group] Reminder: ODL AG call today!
message_text:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Advisory_Group:Main#Logistics

Reminder, there will be an AG call today on the topic of clustering in ODL. I've had confirmation that at least one developer will be able to attend to participate.

Brian gave us some talking points to start with; more discussion obviously welcome:

Multi-site clustering using non-voting member provides baseline support for geo-redundant operation but there are limitations both in the degree of automated failover and the performance impacts of large MD-SAL datastore replication during return to service operations.

As more and more applications include micro-service components the interaction of micro-services with MD-SAL and MD-SAL clustering becomes an important design consideration.

What is the roadmap for clustering and in particular geo-redundant operation ?
What is the roadmap for MD-SAL ?
Are there plans for support of micro-services and or broader support for containers as part of ODL ?

Cheers,
Chris.

subject: [advisory-group] Announcing the LFN End User Advisory Group
message_text:
Members of the ODL Advisory Group,

As you are no doubt aware, the harmonization that LF Networking is enabling is resulting in alignments in a number of areas.  One of these comes in the form of a new LFN End User Advisory Group which was recently given the go-ahead by the Governing Board.   There was an open meeting at ONS in Las Angeles to discuss the focus and composition of the new organization. The wiki page (still under development) and minutes from that initial meeting can be found here: 
LFN End User Advisory Group (EUAG) <https://wiki.lfnetworking.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=2916362>

Comprised of members such as telecommunications carriers, cable operators, network, application, compute or storage service providers who are responsible for the implementation, deployment and support of LFN solutions, the Charter <https://wiki.lfnetworking.org/download/attachments/2916362/LFN%20EUAG%20Charter%204-13-2018.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1523664238000&api=v2> of the LFN-EUAG includes among other things :
Strategy and long term planning of feature and functionality alignment across LFN Projects
The identification of functional and/or operational concerns which are inhibiting the adoption of LFN solutions
Architectures and technical requirements that serve these business areas 
Providing end user perspectives on value and usability of LFN technology
Areas of focus to address short term business requirements
Project testing environments, test cases, and/or Proof of Concepts
Membership eligibility is based upon an individuals job role within an end-user organization and is capped at no more than three individuals from the same company at this time. Membership in the Linux Foundation is not a requirement. The LFN-EUAG operates in purely advisory capacity and will subsume any of the Project specific advisory groups which may have previously existed. 

There are no limits on the total number of members at this time, however consideration will be first given to those currently serving on one of the existing Advisory Groups.

If you would like to become a member,  please review the End User Advisory Group Charter <https://wiki.lfnetworking.org/download/attachments/2916362/LFN%20EUAG%20Charter%204-13-2018.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1523664238000&api=v2> and the End User Advisory Group Membership Agreement <https://wiki.lfnetworking.org/download/attachments/2916362/LFN%20EUAG-Agreement%204-13-2018.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1523664218000&api=v2>. Questions and signed agreements should be sent to euag-info at lists.lfnetworking.org <mailto:euag-info at lists.lfnetworking.org> 

Please reach out directly if you have any questions.
Best Regards, 
-kenny

Kenny Paul, Technical Program Manager, The Linux Foundation

message_text:
Reminder that we have an ODL AG call today at the usual time/place (https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Advisory_Group:Main#Logistics)

We intend to have an open discussion about the Linux Foundation Networking End User Advisory Group (LFN EUAG) which you all should have received a note about earlier in the week.

Chris.
